description:
Euphoria, my dear Gloria!

This review is long overdue. Visiting this incredible little gem will leave your entire being suffused with fresh oxygen and an uncommonly grand high from the terrifically humidifying Divine botanical specimens!! No sweet leaf needed, heh heh. Olde Ozzy Osborne song....  Each room has its own version of plant paradise, with scented and unscented flowers and other showy hot-to-trot plants that I had never seen in person before. I could spend hours in here wandering around reading, writing, playing my flute, praying and praising and traipsing around, were it not for the other visitors who sometimes make it difficult to move around. Not their fault for having the good 'scents' to come here! 

So very inspirational!!! I truly think that a place like this raises your vibrational frequency.

This domed dream may be no big whoop to people who are not that interested in horticulture, so please don't drag them here. There are plenty of other things to do and see in Golden Gate Park! 

The people who work here have been brainwashed by the plants to take on a kinder aura. 

Orchid delights abound ici! "Orchid" was one of my favorite Crayola crayon colors when I was a kid. I'm one of those women who loves shades of purple. Okay, I will stop rambling now.
author: Chanda M.

description:
We were cruising around the city of San Francisco at dusk, trying to figure out what to do, when I suddenly remembered that the Conservatory of Flowers showcases a nightly light art installation for free! The all-white landmark becomes a canvas for an illuminated spectacle of beautiful flowers and various art and it is way cool! This all happens outside the Conservatory!

Lights. Cameras. Action! This year's summer installation called "The Surrealistic Summer Solstice" was produced by Dawn Holliday with the musical direction of Dan "Lebo" Lebowitz. The various flower displays were just awesome eye candy! We thoroughly enjoyed the series of scenes on display and had so much fun admiring the art, recording video, setting up our boomerang shots, and snapping selfies. All for the gram!

The installation was first launched in honor of San Francisco's city-wide celebration of the 50th Anniversary of the Summer of Love in 2017 and it now runs nightly from sundown (around 7:40pm) to midnight through August 28, 2018. Check the website for other upcoming exhibits and events.
author: Jessica P.

description:
I have to agree with the saying of "SF Hidden gem that people don't know about". This place is located close to Golden Gate Park, at Inner Richmond aread. Once you enter the area, you will be greeted by a large, green stadium where you will be making a right turn where you will see flower area right in front of the building. Such a nice spot to take some afternoon walk, or just to snap some pictures. 

Inside the building is more like a green house filled by mostly tropical plants, orchids, tropical flowers, potted plants, and the most sought flower, the "corpse flower". There is some interesting history behind this corpse flower. When we visitted the corpse flower, it was not very smelly. And one of the worker also gave a brief history about the corpse flower. 

Parking is on the curb, not too busy during weekdays. But it could be hectic during weekend.
author: Maureen M.

description:
Nice collection of interesting plants in a forest-like setting. You walk through several sections of the large greenhouse to see different varieties of plants. Depending on the time of year, you get to see different flowers. If you aren't too interested in flowers, it might be a tad bit boring.

I've been here several times. One time they had a butterfly exhibit where beautiful butterflies flew around inside one section of the greenhouse and you could walk among them. Some even landed on us.

Today, I went to see the rare Suma the Titan, commonly called the Corpse Flower because it smells like a rotting corpse when it first blooms. Cool stuff and there are staff members to answer questions. Very educational.
author: Lily L.

description:
1. The illuminations and music are amazing

2. Love how they opened till 10pm just for the corpse flower viewing! (Such an amazing beast)

3. It was nice walking around after too, such big and beautiful are to take aesthetic pleasing pics.

4. They sell Venus flytraps here for I think a lil more than $10

Sad I didn't buy one but I'll be back :)
author: Jray M.

description:
I have always driven by this place but it's been forever since I've been. I was eager to come check it out on a beautiful SF day. 

The price to get in is between 6-9 dollars, I used my student card and paid only 6. Sweet! This isn't a huge place so it's not a whole day activity. 

There are so many beautiful flowers and plants which one would assume. Lots of great picture taking to be had here! Prepare for the humidity once you are inside the building. I was not ready for that! 

We got through the place in about 30 minutes and then explored golden gate park some more. It's worth it to stop by and see the unique plants next time you are in the area!
author: Issy D.

description: We really enjoyed visiting this botanical garden. There is lots of free unmetered parking nearby. The water lilies and carnivorous flowers were our favorites. The atmosphere is gentle and meditative, and we enjoyed a peaceful break from the business of the city.
author: Elizabeth G.

description: Breathtaking. Everyone was in awe at the unique plants and flowers - and I got a super cute mug at the gift shop. $9.00 a person to get in, but there was no time limit and so we could take our time and take photos galore!
author: Alison C.

description: Great attraction to see in the SF area. Entrance is $9 for adults and takes at maximum an hour to walk through unless you're trying to do a photoshoot.
author: Elizabeth H.

description:
If you're looking for tranquility and relaxation in the hustle and bustle of golden gate park look no further. 

Before you get inside, be sure to check out the clock made up of all kinds of different flowers. The building itself is really rustic and cool looking. Inside there is so many flowers and plants, from all over the world! They also have a gift shop located inside that sells cute items including a cactus gardens and postcards.   

I would recommend bringing a light blanket if you wanted to lay down in the park. We went to the bathroom and ended up laying down in the grass and just relaxing. 

Pros: The price is reasonable, They have signs placed by each of the flowers/plants so you can learn about each of them, and super relaxing  

Cons: They don't have a bathroom inside, you have to walk out into the park and then re-enter 

Tips** If you're a student, bring your student ID. They give student discounts! 

There are parts inside the building where the rooms are humid for the plants/flowers so prepare mentally for your hair to be in the humidity!
author: Carly E.

description:
U.S. National Register of Historic Places

I came in on the first Tuesday of the month (free). I wouldn't say the conservatory is big, but there are a lot of different plants. I will need to come back in the spring to see more flowers in bloom. What I was mostly looking forward to was the illuminations on the facade (sundown to midnight). Right now "Photosynthesis: Love For All Seasons" is playing. I enjoyed the show and the music that went along with it.
author: Helen H.

description:
I absolutely loved that place.
Everything was so pretty, so green and calming.
I got to see many different plants I had no idea about, and even took a picture with a leaf bigger than me! 
This is a great spot to visit, and I wouldn't get tired of going there. The staff is very nice and informative, they love to talk about the varieties of plants and are able to answers any question.
The tiny gift shop is very cute! They sell small plants, flower pots, magnets, seeds.. 

Great spot to take pictures too!
author: Melissa G.

description:
Enjoyed my recent visit to the Conservatory of Flowers this past Sunday... It's been ages since I've been inside and I had been wanting to visit for a while now. Now that I no longer live in the city, I had to pay the $9 non San Francisco resident entrance fee. I thought that was a little steep but with every type of cost in the city on the rise, I should not have even been surprised. Still a little high for my liking. 

I really enjoyed the plants inside the structure and the displays outside. Golden Gate Park is beautiful and evokes many memories of my childhood. The Conservatory of Flowers is certainly a landmark most are familair with at GGP. It was especially nice that Sunday as JFK Drive is close to public vehicular traffic. Everyone was free to roam on their bicycles, roller skates and skateboards.

The Butterflies & Blooms exhibit was awesome. It was cool to see all the butterflies about to come out of their cocoons and the ones inside room where they could fly about in safety. Very cool display. I also liked seeing the orchids and lily pads. The landscaping outside and the Dahlia Garden is also really cool. The flowers they have in that section are beautful. Real nice to see them all together in one area. Makes for great photographs. 

Conservatory of Flowers is a must visit whenever inside GGP. Great display of plants and flowers. An amazing variety open to the public.
author: Chuck D.

description: I went here with Debra R and Jose R. We saw a lot of flowers and the building was pretty. The customer service was good.
author: Julia R.

description: What a hidden gem. Just outside to the right of the place.  Just beautiful   I would suggest just walking but anytime you are in the park
author: Allen G.

description:
a must do! a free beautiful garden to view here with artistically arranged flowers. there is also lots of green grass so its a good place to bring your blanket &  lay down & chill. do not miss the giant flower clock which is made out of flowers & is beautiful. remember to check out the bridge as well. the conservatory is located in golden gate park on jfk drive not far from the de young art museum.  
it used to be, you had to have mega bucks & be really rich to have the good life, not anymore. the game has changed. you've been upgraded. now you can 
live like a king on a limited budget!
author: Stephen Z.

description:
For the love of botany, I was enamored, but never more so than in the Butterfly Room. Still, let's be forthright here, I can only take about an hour, or less than, of delight in such a place -- and a lot of that time is used to compose the perfect future Facebook picture. There are connected rooms, but there's only so much square footage before you've seen the whole place. I cannot find my spot and sit in tranquility, as I might have hoped, because there were too much bumper to bumper groups of people walking in front of me. I did find my one spot where I might have spent five minutes, but it's also easy to get fidgety here and I was back up on my feet. That's just me, maybe.

Since the Conservatory is found in the Golden Gate Park area, it is always a bit chilly, a bit nippy on most occasions. Yet it is too darn warm inside the atrium because those temperatures are needed consistently for most plants to thrive. So do come to the area with the proper layering of outfits, a sweater you can take on and off. If there is an added bonus of glee to the experience, it is the rolling lawn out in front of the premises. #goodtimes
author: Sean C.

description:
The Conservatory of Flowers is placed right in the heart of SF's Golden Gate Park and is a beautiful place to visit with a friend on Sunday. They have so many fascinating plants and I especially enjoyed the butterflies and watching the lil cacoons wiggle as the caterpillars try to escape! Only $9 for adults and $6 for students with ID. 

Also, if you're one of those people that likes a good photo op, this is the place for you!
author: Olivia L.

description:
We were playing the role of tour guide for my sister visiting for the weekend.  Its been many years since we visited the Conservatory of Flowers, a cool little museum of various tropical plants, house plants, aquatic plants, carnivorous plants, and a butterfly exhibit running through Jan 2018.  For just under $10/person you can have an hour enjoying this natural exhibit which technically is more plants than flowers.  However, Conservatory of Plants just doesn't sound right.  Walk around the outer gardens of the Conservatory and you'll find selfie heaven with lavender and red flowers.

Its cool how you can experience several microclimates walking among the rooms - it'll get hot and humid in the tropicals and then cool and pleasant in the aquatic plants section.  The butterfly exhibit is included in admission and is pretty fun.  I was surprised to see an active mouse running up along the trees and wall chasing them around.
author: Daniel C.

description:
Attended After Hours at the Conservatory last month and had an awesome time. I run past Conservatory of Flowers in Golden Gate Park all the time, but I never visited. Glad I got to combine two of my loves- nature and good old ale. 

Drakes was hosting this After Hours. Outside was a bar with wine and (surprise) Drakes beer options, and inside were two awesome, enthusiastic reps that walked guests through the process of creating the beer.

As for the Conservatory of Flowers itself, it was lovely. My sister and I enjoyed walking through the space and reading the various facts displayed along the walkway. My favorite by far was the butterfly room.
author: Nicholas G.

description: It's a beautiful jungle in the conservatory of flowers! There are rooms such as hot & humid and cool & damp. We went when the butterfly exhibit was running. It was really cool to see all the butterflies fluttering and emerging from their cocoons. The plants were beautiful and so unique, it was a great place to spend an hour of our afternoon here.
author: Jessica H.

description: Been watching their live feed with their corpse flower.  They actually open till 10 pm to accommodate opening of the flower.  This is a special place to just enjoy orchids, plants, and water lily.  Imagine you are in the jungle somewhere.   Price of admission buys a little oasis from the urban scene.  Night time they have light show.
author: Helen L.

description:
This greenhouse is so relaxing to be in. There are areas where it's cool and areas where it's a bit warm. It's also a wonderful place to take pictures if you'd like. The Conservatory of Flowers also offer discounts. I used a student discount myself which is pretty nice. I just had to pay $6. Do check out their gift store! I saw that they were selling Venus Fly Traps for $15 for a small bunch of mini ones. How cute! I also got the chance to take a picture with this big leaf prop that they had in the gift store. Oh! And checking out the lily pad ponds are a must. It's absolutely beautiful. The place is a bit smaller than I expected. And I wished that they had some open outlets available for visitors. That would be cool. However, I would totally go again. What an enchanting place to visit! :) 
P.S. I feel like this place would be a great place to go to if you ever need to wind down.
author: Kat C.

description:
This is a hidden gem! Nice little excursion within the beautiful Golden Gate Park. It's a good warm escape if the park is cold that day! Def worth the price. 

The venue is stocked with flowers and plants from around the world each labeled well so you can learn! They also had a butterfly special exhibit when I was there, so fun! They have cool sounds throughout the exhibit so it feels like your in a new exotic place! 

Fun place for dates and cool pics. Nice benches throughout to sit and relax.
author: Alex M.

description:
Hmm, was expecting a much bigger place.

Don't hate me, it was lovely, just was expecting more square footage! It looks much bigger from the outside. (Its smaller than a Home Depot Garden department) 

We left the butterfly room and my man said;

"There weren't any butterflies in the butterfly room!"

I had to take him back in to point out maybe 10-12 max butterflies! Perhaps it is seasonal? We were there in January. Didn't even see a lily pad in the lily pad section..... No, we weren't high. 

With that said, a pretty solid collection of all things greenery.... It smelled yummy, and at one point I said; "wouldn't this be a cool house?"

It IS lovely, but we were finished in 30 minutes max... I guess I was expecting it to be a 1.5 hour sort of place, maybe with a small cafe etc. 

Don't want to be a downer, who couldn't love this beautiful place?? We both just expected it to be much bigger.
author: Stylishshopper ..

description:
I live in the city and never tire of the Botanical Garden. It's very peaceful and therapeutic.
I did make the regrettable decision to go on 4/20, however. (I forgot what day it was, when I headed out).
There were over 30,000 people there celebrating the annual cannabis holiday.  There was an annoying helicopter, make that two loud and disruptive helicopters hovering about the entire day.
Fortunately for me, as I'm not a part of the cannabis counterculture, only a few people from the large crowd paid the fee to go in the conservatory, thus minimizing the second hand smoke exposure.
Also, I should mention, there were no cannabis plants to be harvested inside the garden itself.
Only 3 stars, due to unfortunate location of the Conservatory.
author: Christina P.

description: Small but beautiful little gem in Golden Gate Park. They host a few cool events in the evenings and have really knowledgeable staff that can answer any and everything about the plants inside. Coolest place? The aquatic plant house. Make sure you peek down at the glass and see how the aquatic plants grow. And check out the shop! They have great succulents, air plants, and conservatory swag.
author: Sarah N.

description:
Serene flora with labels of the plant family and species, beautiful Butterfly and Blooms exhibit (which ends June 30, 2017), and an adorable gift shop loaded with all of your seeds and planting needs. 

[General info] 
Bring you student ID and you can get in for 6 dollars! There is also a discount if you show a San Francisco ID! Otherwise, general admission for an adult is 8 dollars. In addition, every Tuesday is free admission!

We got here from by taking one of the metro lines, from our previous location. 

[The conservatory] 
My boyfriend took me here as a surprise for my 22nd birthday since he knows how much I LOVE flowers. Absolutely breathtaking inside. Each room has a theme and is well monitored in terms of temperature and living conditions for the various types of plants. 

There is plenty of bench seating to enjoy the scenery. This is where he decided to give me my birthday gift, which turned out to be a new camera! Perfect place to try it out as there is so much scenery and photo ops. 

[Butterfly and Blooms]
Lots of BUTTERFLIES! EVERYWHERE! Perfect if you like the up close and personal experience with free flying butterflies of all types. Beautiful and also a bit terrifying (if you're afraid of moths like me....) Prior to entering the butterfly exhibit, there is a very useful education area that shows the stages of metamorphosis and info about the life stages of the butterflies. 

[Gift Shop] 
I bought this really cute hedgehog planter that came equipped with wild strawberry seeds and soil for 9.00. It's tiny and fits comfortably in the palm of your hand. I think it's for starting the seeds off so that they can be transferred to a bigger pot, later on.It's much too small to fit a plant, but it was too cute to pass up. 

I can truly say that out of the 4 years that I've been with my significant other, he really outdid himself with this one. It's romantic, family friendly, and peaceful.
author: Emily T.

description:
I didn't get the chance to go inside but what a lovely place! We walked around the garden area outside where people were sitting around enjoying the beautiful view. 

Near the side there was also a tunnel like area with great acoustics where someone was playing the harmonica. V nice vibes overall
author: Christine W.

description:
I have mixed feelings here. 

My favorite part was the butterfly room. Although often crowded, it was somewhat serene and peaceful filled with pretty butterflies enjoying their afternoon lunch on fake and some real flowers. Another segment of the Conservatory I appreciated was the area with carnivorous plants. It is pretty neat to know they catch an insect as if they were animals themselves.

While the conservatory appears grand from they outside, inside there are only a few rooms. For San Francisco, it just does not seem enough. At the same time, the cost is only $8, so I can't really complain about the price.

Overall, it is an ok place to stop by if you have nothing else to do.
author: Christy W.

description: This was my first visit to the Conservatory and not my last. It was a little packed but thats ok. Its to be expected in that type of setting. I was able to do a photoshoot with a model and got some exceptional images that I am excited to add to my portfolio. I also spoke to the lady in charge of events who was very helpful and got pricing in case I wanted to place to myself, although I opted out of that option its nice to know its available. Cant wait to come back.
author: MJ L.

description:
um, a monarch butterfly landed on me in the butterfly room. It was hands down the most magical moment of my entire life. If you are in SF, the conservatory of flowers is a MUST. forget cal academy of sciences - for 6 bucks (if you're a student or old person) you can experience the actual magic that is flowers, green things, and butterflies.

bring an ig husband to follow you around and take cute candid pics of u
author: Olive X.

description:
Super cute place to come.  They separate each room by climate.  Each room was so beautiful and smelled so wonderful.  

The butterfly room had to be my favorite.  It really was a unique experience.

Wish this place was bigger so I can explore a lot more.  It felt so quick.
author: Jackie N.

description: Beautiful indoor conservatory with many potted, tropical, and other plants.  Parking is available on the street, or in the parking lot nearby.  Look for the white building with the clock in front.  Locals can get in for $6 and all others are $9.  Its worth the money!  It has multiple rooms with floor to ceiling plants.  Most all plants are labeled with name and some feature educational information.  On one end is a gift store.  You can stay as long as you want.  Inside is warm and humid.
author: Alan H.

description:
Beautiful place to see and learn about different types of flowers and plants. There is a cost to enter and I believe it's $6 if you're a student (don't quote me on that, it's been awhile since I went). There's three different areas you can go and each place has flowers/plants and humidity level. I'm not into plants but it was pretty cool reading about some of them. 

There is also a butterfly area on one side of the conservatory. It's pretty small and there are really friendly and nice people there that can answer any of your questions about butterflies and how they live. Along the way, you'd most likely pass by workers who are more than happy to answer questions or take photos for you. We were really fascinated with one tree looking plant right in front and one worker told us it was called the "Traveler's Plant" or something like that (I know, I have terrible memory!). She was so informative about it and told us that traveller's use it like a compass. 
 
I heard the area have a light show at night, so I will definitely come back to check it out.
author: Sheila C.

description: We were married here last weekend, and it was so beautiful it makes me want to cry! Jessica and Will were so great to work with, and along with my coordinator managed the event perfectly. I'm so grateful to this amazing venue and the team for making our night so special.
author: Katie S.

description:
Stunning light show tonight. Lots of spectators and admirers of the Summer of Love exhibit.

Lots of bushes and flowers and a nice vibe in the evenings when the sun goes down. Super athletic type runners going by don't flinch though. 

In this most beautiful park is this gem... go out for a night walk - I'm not so much into running.
author: Stefan T.

description: This was such a relaxing little place to visit. I just wish the inside was bigger and there were even more plants and flowers!! The building is adorable and it's super warm inside just FYI! Lots of beautiful flowers and it's a great place to take pics. It seems like a nice place to visit if you're on a date at the park.
author: Alyssa H.

description: Maybe it's because I've been to the San Diego Botanical Building and some others (Seattle's Volunteer Park Conservatory) similar to the Conservatory of Flowers, I was underwhelmed by their selection of plants and the expensive entrance fee. I walked through for 15 minutes if that.
author: Julie L.

description:
Visited the Conservatory of Flowers yesterday and was disappointed to stand in line for admission, pay for a ticket, and walk in after purchasing a pass to find out the full main section of the Conservatory was closed for roof renovation. Very disappointed that there was no sign, notice at the Front, or confirmation from the staff when I purchased the ticket that about 60% of the Conservatory was closed for renovations and fenced off. The corner special exhibits on both sides were open but the main area/main exhibit was fenced off from viewing. 

Since the main area was sectioned off, the side sections were very crowded and I was a little embarrassed to have brought a guest and have this be their first experience at the Conservatory of Flowers.
author: Heather J.

description: Absolutely beautiful with the garden and bushes of flowers outside. Perfect to sunbathe or picnics or just to relax!
author: Steven W.

description: I visited for the first time on Saturday. It was inexpensive ($6 with a student ID) and not crowded at all for a Saturday afternoon. There were several rooms with plants and flowers from different regions around the world. The ticket even includes access to walk among the butterflies. There were so many great photo ops, and an opportunity to buy some potted plants if you want.
author: Brittany B.

description:
This review is specifically for the Butterflies and Blooms exhibit currently on at the Conservatory through June, if I'm not mistaken. 

Just past the gift shop (for those of us who have not been to the Conservatory in ages, yes, there is now a gift shop on premises) stands a rather modest area housing both a 'pupa hut' & 'free range' butterfly zone. One enters the sort of forechamber where the pupe, resembling little dead leaves, are hanging on wee sticks behind glass in the hut. Their camouflage helps make them look less appealing to hungry predators & undiscerning visitors. The standing area in front of the hut shows 3-D information on how butterflies come to be. It's both eye-catching & informative.

Step beyond the mesh 'doors' and be transported into a warm & cozy area with piped-in ambient sounds of nature mixed with soft strains of music. Its over all effect is calming. There's a koi pond in one corner and a variety of butterfly-friendly plants flank the walk space. The butterflies are everywhere one looks. They're hanging above along the mesh netting, resting on plants, enjoying a bit of nectar from the flowers, flitting about the air, and, sometimes--watch out!--resting on the ground.

There's usually a docent on-hand to help answer questions one might have & to prevent visitors from pestering the butterflies. Speaking of which, the winged ones hail from different parts of the US & are obtained from two different farms. 

This rather tidy exhibit is lovely and well worth a visit if you're at the Conservatory!
author: Bea B.

description: Such a lovely and serene place, reminds me a little bit of the conservatory at the Bronx Botanical Garden. Beautiful indoors and outdoors. Great for a little day visit while in the park.
author: Sela B.

description: Beautiful beautiful beautiful. That's all I can say. The  size and variety of the tropical plants were astounding. It was interesting to learn about the beautiful orchids and pitcher plants
author: Olivia K.

description:
Beautiful flowers! Free entrance every first Tuesday but super crowded on free days. I did that once & had to wait at least 30min before getting in. There was a massive line. 

After some research, I discovered that with my LA arboretum pass, I can visit 300 other gardens in the US for free. The list included Conservatory of Flowers & SF Botanic Gardens so went to both for free! Spent about an hour walking around and taking pictures. 

Tip- It's very hot & humid inside, so make sure you take off your jacket before entering. There's plenty of free street parking nearby.
author: Victoria S.

description:
The butterfly exhibit has been gone since January 2018, and there is no update/plan of having them back at the Conservatory of Flowers. 

I used to come here to spend my time with the butterflies, but now it's summer and I don't have anything tentative to do, I found out that the butterfly exhibit is gone. Yeah, I was pretty heartbroken because it's the only place I can hang out with a pool of butterflies around me to ease my stress. 
Other than that, the conservatory did a great job of maintaining the plants and expanding some parts of the exhibit. The lotus exhibit at the very back of the building is my second-favorite because of pretty lilies growing in a pond. 
I gave it a 2 star because they didn't have my favorite butterfly exhibit, and also they feature lots of greenery (which is still interesting!) but I'm a flower-person. I love wisterias, peonies, lotus sutra, ect., but the Conservatory of "Flowers" mainly consist of greenery and species of orchids. However the staffs are always helpful and very educated about every plant there, the place is very clean (no more on-going construction) and there are a quite a few interesting plants you never thought of. Not until I know that there will be a butterfly exhibit, I'll be hanging out at the CA's Academy of Science. 

If you want to still be surrounded by butterflies, you can visit the California Academy of Science's Osher Rainforest. These butterflies are native to tropical habitats, so don't expect them to be teeny-tiny (but they're not scary humongous either).
author: Jackie T.

description: This place is a magical wonderland of plant life. You expect to turn a corner and find a Victorian women tending her medicinal garden or preparing something to kill her husband. It's wonderful. I came to see the stubborn corpse flower who decided to continue to hold tight and refuse to bloom on anyone's schedule but their own. The volunteers at this place are top notch. Extra shout out to Lauren, who is funny and cool and super knowledgeable. Her warmth and genuine passion for plants shows when she interacts with guests. She's one of those people you just want to friends with and listen to them talk about plants. The gift shop is tiny but filled with great stuff. I picked up a book on poisonous plants and purchased a sensitive plant which is something I've always wanted to have and rarely see available.
author: Katie R.

description: Super cute and definitely worth checking out! The conservatory consists of about 5 different sections specializing in different plants. My personal favorite was the aquatics section with the water lily ponds and giant pitcher plants; close second was the butterfly enclosure.
author: Emily Y.

description:
One of the most beautiful places in San Francisco.
We like to take advantage of the free days and come often. Every first Tuesday of the month as free, and I believe they do other free days throughout the year as well.
A gorgeous Victorian conservatory and greenhouse. So well maintained by very skilled employees and volunteers. With a few rooms to travel through, you are taken from a humid such green rain forest, to a cool luscious botanical dream. The oldest existing greenhouse in the Western hemisphere. 
One area of the conservatory is always changing. One time they had a really neat cactus desert. Currently there is the neatest butterfly exhibit. They have a living wall where they have all different species pupae in different stages. From very early on to hatching right before your eyes! It is so neat to see. 
The perfect place for a first date, an anniversary, a great place for kids, perfect for the plant lover, etc, etc, etc.
Everyone loves this place. It is so beautiful on the outside, and inside is is a whole other world.
Parking is in the park, so have quarters ready is you cannot find a free space.
author: Kat R.

description: I'm a sucker for light shows and the one that just started here had me pretty awestruck. Come visit.
author: Linda H.

description:
I was not blown away.  The cost isn't super high at only $8 but I somehow thought there wold be more to see and it would be bigger ---- it's not.  

There are four exhibits and I think one changes --- while I was there it was butterflies and that was actually pretty cool.  They had an area where they had larvae and some of them were actually opening while I was standing there so you could see them coming out with wrinkled wet wings and slowly flexing them to dry them out and stuff.  Also you could walk into a section that was sealed off with mesh where butterflies were flying around from plants and flowers - very cute. 

The other three exhibits are mostly jungle-centric with tropical warm plants and a pretty section in the back with water and lilies.  

It wasn't awful - but it was about 20-25 minutes and $8 I wouldn't spend again.  This is not the kind of place you'd visit multiple times...
author: Alison M.

description: I enjoy coming to Botanical Gardens because of different variety of flowers it contains. Every time I come here, I find the experience different and beautiful on its own way. I have been there when it's foggy in San Francisco and when it's sunny. The weather plays a big park of your visit to the gardens. I prefer the foggy weather because I love taking images and the light is better!  Yesterday I went to the gardens and had an amazing new experience by listening piano performances. I really enjoyed listening to piano sound and being surrounded by beautiful garden and plans with funky lights. The event is happening today too and I strongly suggest checking it out.
author: Galya T.

description:
I took my niece (age 4) here a few days ago to see the Butterfly Exhibit. She was not interested in the other beautiful flowers and plants, so I didn't see much of that. 

The butterfly exhibit was really nice, but wasn't as spectacular as some I've seen elsewhere in D.C. and Panama. It's not the kind of thing where there are butterflies EVERYWHERE and they're landing on you. To get one to land on us would have taken a miracle, which sucked because I kind of oversold it to her given my other experiences. 

However, if it had just been me there, I would have had a lovely time. The butterflies (maybe 100-200?)  are sitting on plants or netting on the walls and ceiling. They are gorgeous. It's a very serene place to just sit and watch them. 

There's also a place to buy merch. 

But a 4-year-old really wanting one to be her friend ain't gonna happen.
author: Candice M.

description: Came here for the monthly free day and it did not disappoint! Beautiful flower exhibits, the butterfly room is magical and the docents explained a lot about the breeding and life cycle. The variation of plant life is incredible in one building. It was crowded, but it was on the free day so what can you expect? If you have an afternoon- 2-3 hours to spend here I highly suggest bringing a camera and taking in some natural beauty. It would be great on a rainy SF day. Also, make sure to donate even on free day to support them!
author: Lisa H.

description: If you are looking for a fun and relaxing place to kill an hour in the city, the conservatory of flowers is a great option, right in the heart of golden gate park. Admission is 6 bucks for students or sf residents (must show proof of residency) and 8 bucks for anyone else. Once inside there are 4 primary areas, with water plants, huge jungle like plants, and the butterfly room. I am definitely not a crazy plant person, but was still able to appreciate the structure of the building and all the exotic plants that were to offer. One of the last places to check off my sf bucket list, and I am glad that I did!
author: Ross S.

description:
A sign posted on the Conservatory of Flowers ticket booth touts the fact that some publication somewhere anointed it as "best place for a first date" several years ago and I find that just unbelievable.  Into my mind popped a vision of my oldest son here, trying in vain to think of something, anything, to say about the plants and flowers he'd be viewing on the most silent first date in history.  I not only don't think this is a first date place; I think it's a place best enjoyed solo.  

But that's just me.  

The Conservatory of Flowers is pint-sized when compared, say, to the botanical gardens in Rio.  As a result, it doesn't overwhelm.  It's nicely contained, quiet and mellow, and a good place to bliss out a bit just looking at - and sometimes reading a little about - things that grow.  Coming here high wouldn't be a wholly bad idea.  

Having walked in the park for a couple of hours prior to coming to the Conservatory I was in the right mindset to enjoy it for what it is.  Solo, not looking to exercise, and with nothing cluttering your mind, this is a perfect way to take the place in.  

The Conservatory of Flowers held my interest for about 80 minutes and that included a mildly interesting miniature exhibit (ended in April) celebrating the centennial of SF's historic world's fair.  Some have said there's not enough here to merit the entrance fee but really, how many plants do you want to see?  Or is it just that the admission fee seems too high?  Well, bring proof of being a SF resident, a senior, or a student and you can gain entrance at a reduced admission price which might leave you more enthusiastic.  

If you're in the right mindset the Conservatory is a great place to visit but not a great place for a first date.
author: Tracey A.

description:
Apparently this place has been around since the 1800's. Well color me surprised! I've passed this place a dozen times, but we have have never thought of dropping by. There is just so much to do in SF, but by the law of elimination, you'll get to newer things. 

It's relatively cheap to get in to look at plants and the what have you. It's not a really large place, but it's still very memorable. There is a lot to look at and experience here. You'll be done in about an hour or so, unless you really want to look things over twice. The weekend also gets packed, and the space is rather limited. 

Still, a fun time to be had, if you love plants and flowers.
author: Benny H.

description: I have been trying to get inside this building for countless years and each time they were closed. Finally I got to see the inside. Not as elegant as the Palm house in Kew Gardens, England, this green house has a large collection of pitcher plants. There is also an Indonesian giant arum lily the size of a 12 foot tree. At this time there was an exhibit of live freshly metarmorphosed butterflies which you get close and personal in secured room.
author: Keo N.

description:
Soooo pretty. $6 admission with a student ID.

 Everything about this place is awesome. The staff was so friendly and nice and we spent around an hour checking each room out, including the butterfly special exhibit. Parking was suprisingly easy to find for Saturday.
author: KK T.

description:
If you love nature and/or flowers, this is a must. It can get a little steamy in some of the rooms to preserve the flowers, but the lushness and vastness is amazing and worth some perspiration. My favorite room was the potted plants room. There were some variations of flowers that didn't even seem possible to exist! My boyfriend and I now of course want to buy 600 different types of flowers and have a conservatory of our own. 

M-R, it's $8 to enter for adults. We went on a Tuesday, around 2:30pm. There was no line, and we were were able to walk through the exhibit in a solid 30-45 minutes. The time really depends on how closely you want to examine each of the flowers. They have tours available too, but we didn't have time to take one. I definitely suggest stopping in if you are walking around the Golden Gate Park and have some time. This is one of those things we didn't plan for on the trip, but it ended up being one of our favorite surprises.
author: Nicole T.

description: This is a Really Cool place to see some unique and rare plants. And with this Summer of Love celebration in SF they light the whole building up at night. Its a neat show.  All the orchids are beautiful. The butterflies area is a great place to sit for a while. Bring the whole family. Kids will love it.
author: Ryan N.

description:
Though I'm originally from S.F., I don't recall going to the Conservatory of Flowers until last Friday.  Stunning Victorian style glass building with domed ceilings and two wings showcases tropical plantings from around the world. 

Our admission was free as reciprocal members of Descanso Gardens.  We also snagged free parking across the street.  

They also offered a free demonstration and tasting of exotic chocolates.  Score! 

The different sections of the building are divided into tropical regions, from lowlands to higher elevations,  with appropriate temperature changes.

Fascinating, mysterious, lovely.  Many gorgeous discoveries to be made.  

The Dahlia Garden outside adjacent was delightful, too.
author: Lianne K.

description: It was amazing, the best place to enjoy for only 6$. A lot of flowers from all off the World and butterflies. I hope my children will like it!!
author: Khamit K.

description: Wow! Just beautiful. Inside it is so full of so many different plants from different areas its incredible!
author: Brian A.

description:
The conservatory of Flowers wasn't on my list of places to visit, but I decided to stop by on the free day.  Every first Tuesday of the month is a free day to all visitors.  General admission is  $8 for adults, $6 for youths ages 12-17, and $2 for children ages 5-11.

This is a great place to visit on a chilly day as inside temperature is around 85F or 29C and humidity controlled.  I recommend taking the public tours which are available on most days.  The tour times are 11am, 12:30pm, and 2:30pm.  There were lots of beautiful flowers and plants.  The conservatory is broken up into 5 different galleries- potted plants, lowland tropics, highland tropics, aquatic plants, and special exhibits.  My favorite was the aquatic plants.  I would recommend if you are already in the park and looking to pass time.
author: Peter C.

description: This place was awesome. So many different types of plants. Feels like you are in a literal rainforest.
author: Liz H.

description:
This temple to the flora never fails to move me to that sweet spot of reflection, calm and awe.  The contrast of "the big city" - Market Street, big city politics, despair and the Conservatory  of Flowers; geographically so close, but so far apart in substance.  The collection of plants is an overdose of botanical magnificence!  I  want to race to the next display but force myself to sit on each  benches for at least 5 minutes so that I appreciate what is there.  Some of the flowers are so small or the details so subtle that it is impossible to see without giving the plant your full attention.  The experience is a bit like driving a car, riding a bike, walking or crawling.  Each mode of travel offers much more possibilities for experiencing the smells, sights and casual reflections:  why is the flower that color, that shape, and adapted for that location?

Being in the Conservatory with all of the different plants is quite comforting.  Had a bad day?  Not feeling secure about the future?  Go sit on one of the benches in the Conservatory and and carefully look at each of the plants that surround you.  Feel the harmony?  You are part of it all if you choose to be.  I was there on Thursday afternoon.  All the benches were empty - except when I was there... and I don't go there that often, so you should find plenty of room on the benches to rest and reflect.
author: Steve S.

description:
so I've been a sf bay resident for years but my visit to this place with my fam a couple weeks was the first time.  I have to say, I should've visited this place long time ago.
first, be prepared to get warm.... it gets hotter when u get to the butterfly room.  so don't bring a sweater.  the tropical plants-orchids, a few fruit trees, different plants from different countries were all great.  there is a spot where there's a water lilly pond in the middle and I think thats my favorite part.
the butterfly part is awesome.  I got to watch a butterfly come out of the cocoon and the kids loved it.  there are tons of butterflies and altho u wanted to get out coz its really warm in the room, you'll be tempted to hang out a bit.
a little store is located next to the butterfly room.  not much in it I think.
volunteers were all really nice and helpful. 
It wasnt crowded when we came in.. it was a weekday.
tons of parking outside...then again its also a weekday visit.
Id suggest to have a picnic on the grass in the area esp when its warm.  Its a great place to enjoy sf weather and flowers.
author: Learnee L.

description:
On my last day in San Francisco Bay area, plenty of time to kill.  I happen to go to Golden Gate Park, never been to this part of town despite many visits to the city.

I parked close to the SF Botanical Garden and paid my entrance fee when the lady told me this venue would be free to the public until 4:30 (it was about 1:30).  What she failed to mention was it was on the other side of the park, past other museums and attractions in the GG Park.  I did see more statues including Francis Scott Key (i took a pic and a very unflattering finger).  

Well to the Conservatory,  the place is not big but there are really nice flowers in view but mostly the more exotic ones including lilies, aquatic plants.  I enjoyed the walk through and since it was free, it was a bit tight.  Managed to take some shots with my companion.  He didn't appreciate the hotter rooms (for the orchids).  

Overall, it was good since it was cheap (free).  The walk back to the Botanical Garden didn't seem so long after all.
author: Melanio F.

description:
After 7 years of living in the Bay Area I finally paid a visit to the conservatory of flowers. GG park is jam packed on weekends so find street parking if you dare. We parked at the Cal Academy of Sciences which was super pricey. It's a bit of a walk to the Conservatory but we did the de Young Museum, which is why we parked there.

Adult admission is $8 with Seniors and Students getting in for $6. In all we spent about 35-45 minutes in this place which gave us plenty of time for photos. 

There are several different rooms within the Conservatory to represent various climates, from the most humid of rainforests to the dryer, arid climates needed for cactus/succulents (did I mention this area has speakers playing Ol' Western sounds, haha). I made a mistake in bringing a dying phone, so don't have many pictures. Luckily my GF came prepared with a camera so we can remember everything we saw!

You MUST checkout the variety of dahlias just outside the conservatory. Those are so beautiful, and amazing how unique each one is. These can been seen for FREE! Pay attention to hours, I believe they close at 6:30pm on Sundays.
author: Stephen R.

description: I got a private tour since there weren't other people and the guide had great stories to share about their plant selection and history. I had more fun because of the tour guide's added knowledge.
author: Ellen L.

description: I tried contacting this place because I was interested in having my wedding here, a couple email and a month later. No one has replied.
author: Annie Y.

description: My girlfriend and I went here on Valentine's Day! The staff members are very friendly and admission is very affordable. They even offer a discount to SF residents which is neat. Very photogenic place so if you're social media savvy, take lots of pictures! They even offer free tours if youre interested in learning about the plants in the conservatory.
author: Jasmine V.

description:
Plants? How boring...right? Actually, not in this case.

I actually enjoyed exploring this place and seeing plants you wouldn't think existed. It's almost like entering a forest more so than a green house. You can find quite a few plants scattered around with fruits that we know of and markers to identify them as so. The cinnamon tree looked as though it had been infested because so many people ripped the leaves to crumble and smell. The other exotic plants are labeled according to their scientific name and there is a link for you to grab more information about them. 

The conservatory is split into sections according to categories and environment conditions. If you decide to sit, I would suggest you sit in the potted plant area because the conditions aren't as humid as the others. This area is also located near the gift shop. 

The gift shop worker also mentioned that there used to be huge amazon lotus plants in the past but haven't been able to grow because the conditions weren't optimal. He also stated that the conservatory plans on bringing them back and how they you could place a baby on top of the leaf to show how much they can hold. That's something to look forward to. 

Admissions is $8 per person but $6 if you have student ID. The outside of the conservatory is already lovely to sit and relax especially on a nice day.
author: Jessica Q.

description:
What a gem! I've passed by so many times and never bothered to go in! It's very inexpensive (I think $6-8 and they offer student discounts with ID).

It was so beautiful inside! Amazing how the climates changed from each room based on the needs of the plants. It's quite a refreshing and soothing getaway from city life. They have plants and flowers I've never seen or heard of before!

They have more than just flowers! I saw a coffee and cacao tree for the first time! The lily pad pond was beautiful as well. 

The lady collecting tickets at the front when we walked in was a volunteer named Margaret. She was the cutest little Asian lady that had the most contagious positive energy about her. She was very helpful in knowledgeable about not only the conservatory but golden gate park in general. In fact, I'm writing this review solely to be able to give her a shout out!
author: Brianna T.

description:
The conservatory is a large greenhouse in Golden Gate Park.  It has several rooms with somewhat differing plants.  I have seen conservatories with more variety.  There are differences in the rooms but not much.

There are lots of tropical plants,  lots of orchids a pond with waterlilies... the room with the pond is more humid then the others.   
 
On the opposite end of the pond is the special exhibit room.  This trip it was under construction.  My  last visit it was dinosaurs with fake bones around...

Still I happened by here on another free day and I enjoyed a brief visit.  I just wouldn't go much out of my way for here.
author: Mark B.

description:
Such a hidden beauty in Golden Gate Park. 
Small price to pay for what you get to experience. 

Guilty. Took a class on Botany and remember 10%. It was still nice to somewhat slightly recall the different classifications and features. Nice conservatory with about 4-5 different rooms. Great place to take out your cameras as every flower is picture worthy. Just overall a good place to ease your mind.

Better think twice about flowers being boring. Let the SF Conservatory of Flowers prove you wrong!
author: Fiona L.

description: Such a beautiful place to visit! I got a couple discounts from being a student as well as a resident of San Francisco so it only cost $4 for my ticket! Very affordable otherwise. The Butterfly exhibit was my favorite part! Nice to observe nature up close and the gift shop was very cute as well. Spent about 30-45 minutes in here taking pictures and just enjoying our surrounding. Highly recommend if you're in the area!
author: Isabelle N.

description: Beautiful conservatory. I wish there was more outside and more special events or exhibitions during the autumn/winter months that most of the outdoor landscape isn't in season.
author: Lauren G.

description:
The rotating exhibits are quite good.

Right now, the exhibit is about Succulents and Cacti.

The permanent exhibits in the large white green house are very choice.
There are at least five large rooms. You start out at the 'floor of the jungle' and work your way up in elevation and unique plants of a particular region, aka flora. Note: from the entrance, the exhibit's lead you left to right. However, the current exhibit is located, all the way on the other side of the buildings. The Far Left.

Tip: the docent led tours are tops! and free with paid admission. You will learn a lot of interesting information.

Tip: bring a fine camera phone, that way you can take pictures and write notes and/ or look up additional information on the web.

Tip: if the weather is nice, bring a sack lunch and eat right out in front of the greenhouse.

Tip: if you face outward from the front door, look down the lawn toward the right and see a fellow with a push cart selling hot dogs and soda's.

Tip: right acroos the street from the green house, look for a 200 foot wide area of bromiliad's and palm/fern tree's. You know you are there when you see the Jurassic era fern's. It's a super cool seldom visited area. And tucked out back in a little pond replete with a love bench.

Tip: bathrooms and drinking fountains are located directly to the left of the greenhouse.
author: Bert K.

description:
Need an idea for a cheap date? Why not a place to explore the world of botanical gardens? This is your place for an hours worth of seeing, smelling, touching and hearing about a huge variety of gorgeous flowers, intrigue plants, and towering trees.

Super cheap to enter the Conservatory, it's well worth taking a stroll around the tropical rain forest-like rooms. The guides that walk around are full of fascinating information about the plants and facts about the building. Also, each plant is labeled, which I truly appreciate.
author: Lori T.

description:
Didn't think I'd fall in love here because once I dated someone and told her the L word after dating for nine months but then she got all weird at me for it so I've been pretty against saying that stuff but I do love the conservatory of flowers because it's a step back in time to a simpler time before all of these tech companies and apps altered experiences and the daily act of being present. 

San Francisco is a trendy place for bars and restaurants featured on Yelp but who doesn't love a nice greenhouse with old people who tell you that this flower is a Phalenopsis (moth orchid) or that the world fair took place on the north side of the city and everyone came to see mighty exhibits that showed off the city in 1915. Only one building (the palace of fine arts) remains from this pacific exposition and there is a great history that you can read about online, along with 135 photos. 

The greeter is very knowledgeable about the special exhibit, which closes on April 10. The next exhibit on succulence will open a few weeks later. 

This is a very cute and quaint place that would be great for a date because taking some chick to Dolores park after eating at Ike's place is so 2013. The flowers are pretty and I like how it smells in here. You feel inspired to create your own luscious gardens if God gave you a green thumb. We need to support these types of industries. 

It's very easy to walk around here. No drinks allowed so make sure you finish all of your bubble tea before throwing it away in the trash can to your left as you enter.
author: Jerry B.

description:
Beautiful place! Student discount is $5. We couldn't find parking closeby so we had to walk almost 10 min away. Not a bad thing though since the walk here is gorgeous.

Gets crowded here on a Saturday so it's a bit annoying to have to dodge people. I imagine the weekdays are better.

Very humid inside so be prepared. They have special exhibits sometimes so it's worth checking out once in a while.

The outdoor in general is beautiful as well. I will be back!
author: Michael T.

description:
The Conservatory of Flowers is one of my favorite places in San Francisco. Ordered from England as a kit and assembled and given to the city, it's been a landmark since 1878. A team of volunteers lovingly maintains this building and everything in it. Don't touch the plants! It's SO HARD not to but you understand why they say it. With as many visitors as it gets, they would be ragged. Kids, touch with your eyes.

Not unusual to find oneself freezing in San Francisco, a group of us headed here one weekend to warm up. Sure, you could sit in a bar and have a drink, but it isn't as magical as entering a tropical wonderland. It isn't a huge place, you can be done with it in an hour, but everything is so artfully arranged that you'll spend that hour in awe at the beauty of nature. It's worth noting that it gets hotter in here in accordance with the outside temperature so in summer there will be more blooms but it will be much hotter as well.

It costs $8 to get in or $5 for seniors, students and S.F. locals with I.D. There is a small snack cart outside but basically this is a standalone experience. The gift shop has a few items of interest but won't detain you. What might is the smashed penny machine in the lobby that attracted quite a bit of attention when we were there.

Photographers -- this is a fantastic place to take photos! Colors, details, patterns, textures. Incredible light. It can be a little crowded on weekends but people are very accommodating and polite in the calming presence of plants.

I saw a pineapple growing and cocoa pods on a cocoa plant, two things I'd never seen. I didn't know pineapple was a bromeliad! So cool. The last room has a changing exhibit and this trip is was How to Survive in the Tropics ala Gilligan's Island. It was so fun and whimsical, I really loved it. Totally entertaining and educational. 

This room has a resident turtle who poses for pictures on a rock and goldfish who gulp air in unison. I thought this was really cute until I Googled it and found that it indicates water with too much ammonia from fish poo in it. UGH! I don't like any animals in captivity and while they're cute, I'm not sure the conservatory needs these fish. Volunteers -- please investigate!
author: Angelique L.

description:
I love learning about plants, so I was pretty excited to see this conservatory in the park, and boy is it gorgeous from the outside. The inside has about 5 rooms with different climates and an array of plants. I like how well-marked all the plants are, and some even have signs next to them so you can learn more. The stand-out for me was the giant lily pads that are apparently so strong that a child can stand on them! Lots of other interesting flowers and plants to see as well. I just wish it was a bigger conservatory. My boyfriend and I got through it in less than an hour, which was a bit of a letdown, since the greenhouses at my college are bigger than that. The nice part about this place is that it isn't too crowded, but it's so small that I don't think they could accommodate more people.

I forgot my student ID so it was $8 for me, but $6 for my boyfriend. Sadly, I don't think this place is worth all that money. Not to say it's a waste of time, but I would definitely recommend it more if it was $5 rather than $8 for regular admission.
author: Katie H.

description: Hands down favorite spot in the city. The building is epic and surrounding gardens. I was surprised by coming on free day and the butterfly exhibit was fun, had a butterfly land on my hand! Yay!
author: Beatrice J.

description:
Ah nothing beats flowers, especially deep within the heart of San Francisco where most days it is cold and chilly. Located in the Golden Gate park lies a white colored green house called the Conservatory of flowers. There is a admission fee which isn't too terrible. First off before you go in, realize where you are about to enter is NOT San Francisco weather at all! More like tropical/warm weather. So take those clothes off! ( I meant just your jackets not everything because this is not a nude colony).
There are 5 sections here. First is the middle section which is a amazonian type forest. It is a circular room full of trees and lush plants.
Heading to the right from walking in from the entrance will take you to the rain forest setting. This room is more of a archway and the plants are in the middle of the room surrounded by two walkways on each side. These plants are unreachable due to them coming from one floor lower than the walkways. You might get some water misted on your face so do not freak out, the conservatory is not on fire. 
Heading into the room directly in front of you will be Asia settings where there is a giant pond chest knee high packed into a pool like structure. The plants are far more close by than in other rooms therefore giving you better selfies with plants (make sure get their good side!)
Back to the main entrance going to the left this time. This room is an open room connecting the main room unlike the others where it is divided by a door. This has a neat little garden area with a circle structure with plants surrounding in where you can look through the other side of the room. This room becomes fairly crowded here so depending on when you come there might be a lot of people.
Now for the fifth and final room! This room depends what exhibition is going on at that time so make sure you look it up if you are interested in that particular area. Between the 4th and 5th room is their small gift shop where you can buy magnets and whatnot.
I went during July so that was where the butterfly exhibition was going on. There are a few rules here and the workers get really touchy about these rules. For the butterfly exhibition only!
1. Don't touch the butterflies as your oil on your hands will kill them
2. Don't startle them
3. Make sure to look around your clothes to see if they are trying to escape with you. 

Because of the space constriction, this room is severely smaller than all the others.
If you love flowers are interested in a photo shoot , this place is an amazing area to get it down.
I highly recommend visiting this place!
author: Jason H.

description: This is one of the most impressive greenhouse buildings I've ever seen. Though it is gorgeous through and through, the conservatory is a little on the smaller side. It's a great spot to check out if you have an hour to kill, and a beautiful location for photos.
author: Hurley W.

description:
What an absolutely gorgeous location.

The conservatory is small, but it is packed full with gorgeous greens and flowers in this small-sized hot house of flora.

Go on the free day if you can, otherwise it may not be worth it.  Lots of photographers and people crowded into tight turns.  Information is around explaining what you're looking at, but you can complete a slow mosey around the entire building in a half hour.  Not much, but pretty just the same.
author: Jes G.

description:
Free admission day. Come, marvel at the magnificent diversity and microclimes in which they grow.

Adaptation and evolutionary features ( living in water) make one take heed and pause to appreciate this wild, woolly, wacky world of flowers!
author: Jana C.

description:
I've been to Golden Gate Park a number of times but finally made it to the Conservatory of Flowers last month. It's $7 per person and you can purchase your tickets in the booth in front. You get in and out privileges for the entire day. 

We went with our 9 month old soon and had to bring his baby carrier since strollers are not allowed inside. There is stroller parking available in the front. 

If you love exotic flowers and plants, this is the place for you. There were so many different species. The conservatory has five large rooms with different permanent exhibits and their special exhibit at the time featured cactus and succulents. 

Note: If you have never been to a conservatory before, be prepared for the humidity in some of the rooms.
author: Steph F.

description:
A worthwhile stop when exploring the park. The facade will stop you in your tracks with its simplistic beauty. Perfect area to pack a picnic and settle in the garden area for a snack or a nap.

Easy to find the entrance and pay. Purchased a map of the park for an additional $3. Made for a great souvenir for the scrapbooker in the family (my wife). Entry is a great deal at the student rate of $6 person.

Upon entry into the conservatory itself are instantly hit by the feeling of a rainforest. That is a great feeling in terms of the visuals you get (gorgeous, brilliant and lush flowers with pops of color as far as the eye can see). That is NOT a great feeling in terms of the wave of humidity that greats you at the door. This was expected due to the nature of the venue - flora don't tend to thrive in cold dry environments. I was prepared for my humidity filled experience but happy to leave the building for a breath of fresh, crisp air at the end.

The area is separated in 3 large sections. Going through all at a reasonable pace would be around an hour. Factor in additional time if you yourself are a shutterbug or you enter with a shutterbug. The additional time spent photographing flowers and plants is well spent as there are so many breathtaking flowers that stop you in your tracks.

The growth (overgrowth) makes navigation difficult as the pathways are small and you need to focus on not touching the plants. It makes it a challenge to maneuver in some sections.

Orchids were rampant as presented in a plethora of colors and hues I had never seen before. Hibiscus as large as your hand! The sheer volume of the flowers and plants is incredible - every inch of the building is packed with a botanical wonder!

The ticket offers in and out privileges which makes spending time in their easier. Exploring one area and then stepping outside for a brief respite from the humidity makes the adventure more delightful!

It's a great respite from the constant bustle of the city - a small space of calm amidst the chaos. 

*Small gift shop located on the left hand side for those seeking souvenirs!
author: Sabrina B.

description: There are tons of plants from all over the world here.  It is a must visit if you are in San Francisco.  If you love plants and fresh air than this is definitely the place for you.  The price of admission for an adult is $8 but it is $6 if you have a student ID.  The Conservatory has a sign saying that they are the best place for a first date.  It is definitely up there.  The only downside is that I thought there would be more flowers.  It has a lot more plants than flowers.
author: Dang L.

description: I went here on a date. I loved it.. if you're a huge fan of flowers.. and nature I recommend this place. It's so beautiful.. and I would be happy to come back.
author: Kaname S.

description: Beautiful tropical and non tropical flowers. I also loved the butteryfly room. Great learning experience and peaceful showcase of beauty. Prices to enter this conservatory was well worth every penny. Highly recommend this place.
author: Terry C.

description: Really awesome little oasis in Golden Gate Park with rooms full of so many different varieties and kinds of flora.  Kids love the "find a plant" interactive guide and it's easy to get lost in this place (in a good way).  Great spot for a rainy day as well.
author: Bob K.

description:
A beautiful day here in Golden Gate Park. Who would have thought it could be so warm in mid-February!
I walked by the Conservatory of Flowers and admired the lawn-floral display and enjoyed seeing all the families/couples/singles/tourists walking around admiring the structure.
There is a lot of history to the CF.
And inside the variety of plants on display from different global regions is impressive.
Where else can you see beautiful plants which my also have deadly intentions (eating prey)...
So the next time you walk through the park and you find you have some time, stop into the Conservatory of Flowers. You will be enthralled just as I am whenever I'm there.
author: Joanna T.

description:
One of the best sights in all of the Golden Gate park. The conservatory of flowers went through a major renovation some years ago (perhaps 10). 

The original structure is from the late 1800s and is a wonderful representation of the bygone era of San Francisco architecture.

Inside are housed some really beautiful botanical species. The outside grounds are just awesome on a warm sunny day...you will find people of all ages just hanging out: some sunbathing, some reading, playing, jamming on instruments, or many other things.

The conservatory has special exhibits and my all time favorite is when they have the butterflies freely flying inside. It is a great time to take young kids....to see the expression on their faces to see all those butterflies freely flying around is simply priceless.

Tourists and locals check it out!
author: David G.

description:
I'll just start off saying I'm a little obsessed with flowers, so maybe you will have a better grasp of why this magical place was one of the great highlights of my visit to Golden Gate Park.  It all begins with a ticket purchase... You then enter a huge room of tropical wonder, and the building branches off from here. There are separate rooms for different types of plants that need different  temperatures to thrive, and thrive they do! There must be an army of hidden elves that keep this place up and running because I only noticed 3 employees the entire time I was there.
There are a total of 5 different rooms: Aquatic Plants, Highland Tropics, Lowland Tropics, Potted Plants, and a Special Exhibit. The special exhibit while I visited was called Stranded Tropical Island Survival. They do offer free tours through some of the rooms, and the workers will walk through and inform as many people as possible the tour is about to begin so anyone who wants can partake. Maybe I should have done the tour, but I passed on it. Little regrets...
I'd have to say my absolute favorite room was the Potted Plant room. There was such a variety of plants and flowers in this room, and the flowers were vibrant and plentiful. I believe I spent most of my time in here with the potted plants. There are a few benches in the room and if you can take the time to sit for a few minutes as the other visitors wander about eventually you will find yourself in the room alone, and only then can you really appreciate the beauty and the hard work it takes to keep everything alive.
Some items that will keep me coming back to the Conservatory are the fact that they have a variety of flowers on the front lawn, so it will likely be different each time I visit, and it's always beautiful. They have different flowers in bloom at different times of the year, so that can make for an new experience each visit. Last, but not least, I'm a flower nerd. I'll always want to visit this beautiful place.

(If you have a valid San Francisco I.D. you get a discount on your ticket, and admission is free every first Tuesday of the month except for groups)
author: Kate D.

description: This is an amazing place.  There are lots of carnivores plants and orchids.  Well worth spending time here.  It is similar to the Crystal palace in Kew garden, London. However on a smaller scale.
author: Sheila F.

description: A zen and educational experience. A nice way to spend an hour in the park. Picnic outside in the gardens after your self guided tour.
author: Vicki L.

description:
I was exhausted from walking around the city on my one day in SF, but when I saw the pretty Conservatory of Flowers building, I just had to stop in.  It was a weekday so there were very few people in there, and it was so nice to just wander from room to room admiring all the different plants and flowers. 

The admission was $8 and the place isn't really that big, but you can certainly take your time and spend an enjoyable hour. It's humid in some of the rooms but it feels so great to breathe it all in. I had to go through rather quickly but I would definitely come back and spend more time. I loved the wall of flowers behind the reception counter!
author: Catherine B.

description: I loved it! Took my daughter and niece and they were so happy to see the butterflies and all the different type of orchids. Its a little small but worth the price. Outside they have a flower garden that is amazing. We had a picnic and had lots of fun. Definitely recommend coming here.
author: J C.

description:
I came here during the summer time. Bad mistake. It was an unusual hot day in SF and it was also humid and hot in the conservatory as well. I felt really unpleasant. I recommend going on a cool day.

The inside was really beautiful. I really loved everything about it. It was pretty cool reading about its history and seeing the pictures of how it used to look. It would be so cool if the conservatory stayed that way!!! It takes about 2 hours to see the whole thing and read everything. It perfect for dates or family outings!
author: Lynn C.

description: This place is truly magical. It's so worth a visit! The plant life in there is incredible and currently, they have a butterfly exhibit that is absolutely a must. The people who work there/volunteer are knowledgeable, kind, and helpful:)
author: Roxi P.

description: I have yet to visit during the day, but the light show is awesome. Even though it can seem a bit off the beaten path, there are a lot of people moving around in the area. Beautiful colors, calming atmosphere, a must see for the night crowd. Maybe bring a blanket to sit out on. Enjoy.
author: Charmi M.

description:
$8 for adult non residents & $5 for adult residents 
College students are $5 for non residents & $3 for residents

Absolutely worth the time to check this place out. Every time I drive or run past this beautiful building, I'm always curious as to what's inside. Now that I've had the experience, I definitely think it's worth the time. It's a tranquil place to spend with visiting friends or family. There is so much to see while you're there-- everything from plants that give food we see everyday at the grocery store to orchids and hibiscus. 

I love how each room is broken down into different themes. One room was the potted plants room which housed an assortment of orchids and vines. The other rooms include lowland tropics, highland tropics, aquatic plants and the special exhibit. Until October, the special exhibit is themed CHOMP! They came from the Swamp. They did a good job showcasing all the plant kingdom's carniverous plants, including venus flytraps and pitcher plants. I was scared to even go near them at times. My favorite plant at the conservatory was definitely the cacao plant (I'm a chocoholic). I really enjoyed my experience and I know you will too because this is definitely a place worth checking out!!!
author: Brittany D.

description: You can find a variety of flower gardens scattered about Golden Gate Park, but this is where the tropicals live. Reasonably priced, easy to get to via public transportation, and breath-taking. I'm particularly fond of pitcher plants and there's a large variety of the little carnivores here.  Bring lunch and picnic on the lawn.  It's a lovely way to spend an hour or an afternoon.
author: Teri L.

description: Go during the Spring when the butterflies are out adn eat some lsd and come up in the Butterfly Room and watch them Do Their Thang While U Do Ur Thang
author: Sophie Z.

description:
Out of all the things that you can do at Golden Gate Park, the conservatory is for sure one that you should check out. If you like greenhouses or admire plants and flowers, then this is an absolute NO BRAINER for you.

I would check out some free days or discounts because even though it's only $8 per ticket, if you have a group with you, they add up. So I'd definitely ask about student discounts or other discounts in general.

It's a beautiful conservatory. It felt like a dream inside to be honest. It was expectedly hot and moist inside so be prepared for that.

I recommend checking out the lily ponds and taking a lot of pictures. It's a really photogenic place. And also when you're done, right outside is a huge field where you can just relax.

Overall, it's a great section in Golden Gate Park and if you're questioning where to stop at and you don't have much time, I definitely recommend going here.
author: Kairos A.

description: I had an amazing time at the Conservatory of flowers. Main event: the butterfly exhibit! The flowers were amazing. It was quite fun and I recommend going there.
author: Leslie C.

description: Came for the light show.  It was so late starting on Saturday night, we thought there were technical difficulties, especially since there weren't any sounds from this Summer of Love sub-spectacular.
author: Patti S.

description:
Do you like plants? Are flowers really a girls best friend? Do you like to breath clean oxygen? Then you should visit the Conservatory of Flowers inside Golden Gate Park. The place is teeming with plant life from all over, and it's seperated into different sections that make for an informative and somewhat romantic journey throughout the plant world. 

They are closed on Mondays, so be sure to check dates and times before cabbing it over (rookie mistake on my part). While I really enjoyed my visit, I do wish there was more to see or do there- the husband and I got through the entire greenhouse in about an hour, going slowly and taking lots of photos. If you like intersting plants and flowers, you'll love it, but for $8 per adult it seems a bit steep for only ~1 hour of enjoyment. 

The place also boasts of "Best place for a first date in SF", so if you're looking for a great first date spot, maybe give the conservatory a thought.
author: Melinda R.

description:
Okay, you really can't complain about the crowd if you go the first Tuesday of the month because general admission is FREE that day! It was super exciting to check this place out. When we walked in, there was this adorable little old later in a gardening apron who greeted us & told us to enjoy. NOTE: Although it is fall in SF & quite chilly, once you open the doors of the conservatory, it really does feel like you walked into a rainforest--it's humid.
