Not only was this cool considering it was like a mini escape from suburbia/downtown, Idunno, there's something therapeutic knowing that these plants are being taken care of by professionals who know A LOT about plants and the type of environment each one needs to be in to remain as beautiful as they look on everyone's instagrams. 

There is a tour provided, but to be honest the place is so compact & since it's in a dome like construction, you can hear the tour guide pretty much wherever you walk. This is also a very cute daytime date to do & you can have a picnic in front right after or walk along the trail of the park to check out California's Academy of Sciences &/or the de Young (which is also free on the first Tuesdays of the month) and take even more great pictures on the Music Concourse! If you're into scenic or looking for something of that sort in the city, this is def a good go-to spot.
author: Chelsea C.

description: Even though part of the central room was closed off for renovation, we really enjoyed our visit. An impressive number of flowers and plants. A little spendy, ($8 each) for it being under construction, and the open to the public areas on the inside are small compared to how large it is on the outside. We enjoyed the nostalgia of the building, and the beauty of nature and the building itself, right down to the fancy grates on the floor.  If we ever make it back to San Francisco, we'd definitely bring our daughter here.
author: Lisa H.

description: Not bad for the price.  Of course, one has to be into nature or botany to really have a joy for the beauty found here.  Kids tend to like what's inside for a little bit but really this place is more suitable for the adults.  Lovely flowers and great staff around help answer questions and inspire one's own garden fantasies.  I enjoy it as a treat from time to time when I visit Golden Gate Park.
author: Angela K.

description:
Absolutely gorgeous. I love playing tourist in my own city. They have all sorts of plants and trees inside. My personal favorites are all the orchids.
Tip:
Every first Tuesday of the month is free
If you're coming on the free museum day, prepare to wait in line
author: Mindy Y.

description:
Breathtaking construction houses spectacular plants and gorgeous flowers.  What could be better?  Oh, walking through to park amid Redwoods and other natural wonders?  PERFECT!  There are a few things as beautiful in SF, and this is a MUST-SEE.  

FYI, there are "free entry" days 1x monthly, but for us, it was worth $8 each to avoid huge crowds in humid greenhouses with little space to move.  You've been warned. 

In this case, the photos really will be worth 1000 words each.  Enjoy them and plan a great trip soon.
author: Cassandra C.

description: I've being going here since the 1970's, and the place has never, never looked better than it does now. WOW! Really worth the price of admission. If you like plants, this is a must-see. In fact, I'm going back again this Sunday. The plants are really beautiful and weird too. There's a lot of those plants that eat bugs. And I think I spotted the plant they used in the 1970's Body Snatchers movie. Also there is a whole section with tons of butterflies, wonderful different kinds.
author: Terri J.

description: Waited in a long line on free Tuesday but someone came by with yogurt samples which was a nice touch. Did not do a guided tour. Basically you see everything  with stops for photos in about 45 minutes. Beautiful, peaceful place. If we had to pay I would reduce to 3 stars.
author: Joe M.

description:
Beautiful everything. My mom would love it here so much and I will definitely take her next time she's in town. 

I loved all the orchids. The different rooms were fascinating with all the weird/wonderful/beautiful/exotic plants. I loved the little pools with fish in them. This is a great place to come and play with your camera doing nice macro shots of petals with dew drops on them. Make your own postcard style! 

I also came during the "Stranded! Tropical Island Survival" exhibit. While it was hard to know what plants they were specifically referring to in their signage, it was so much fun reading all these facts and survival tips on how to live off coconuts and palm trees. 

Free entrance on the first Tuesday of every month, but be prepared to wait in line a bit. Don't let that deter you though!
author: Carol M.

description:
Another of golden gate park's hidden gems! 

I absolutely loved this old Victorian greenhouse! I think I read that it's the oldest Victorian greenhouse and it's so pretty! All the old woods and even some stained glass and I loved the transom - although I love all transoms! :)

We went in January and even on a cold day, it's really warm and humid in the greenhouse! It is a greenhouse after all! But that's something to keep in mind if you're sensitive to that kind of thing!

They had tons and tons of tropical plants! Some carnivorous ones! Lots and lots of orchids! Some interesting and brightly colored tropical plants! As well as some interesting food related plants - think cinnamon, vanilla pods, bananas and pineapples! 

It truly is a unique and fun place to at least experience once - especially if you love plants and flowers! 

*Also, if you're into those penny press machines - there is one as soon as you walk in to the right of the door!
author: Sam L.

description:
The Conservatory of Flowers is a beautiful sanctuary of plants. They have wings dedicated to aquatic plants, rainforest plants, and orchids in addition to an awesome butterfly exhibit where the butterfly flutter around freely as you explore their garden. The museum itself is not very large so when it gets crowded (as it does on free days), it can be difficult to really lose yourself in this garden because people are always trying to get by you or there will actually be a line to take a picture of a specific plant. 

Tips:
1. The inside of the Conservatory is humid and the ground is wet so wear proper shoes.
2. There is a guided tour at 11AM which is pretty interesting to follow
author: Elaine Y.

description: I love this place. I've visited many times but each visit is different. The plants are always know different stages of growth. I love seeing the different kinds of Hoya plants, orchids, and bromeliads. What a magical place to be.
author: Dahlia L.

description:
I visited the Conservatory of Flowers on a Friday afternoon and it was fun! The garden outside the conservatory is beautiful so if you don't want to pay anything, this is free to enjoy. There is a discount of $2 I think for San Francisco residents but otherwise, tickets are $7 for adults, $2 for kids 5-11 and $5 for kids 12-17, seniors 65+ and students. It's also free the first Tuesday of every month and you can check http://freemuseumday.org/sf.html for other free museum days. 

When we first walked inside, it was really humid. There are three rooms filled with plants, flowers, and fish. There were a lot of interesting plants I had never seen before including a giant lily pad and carnivorous plants. There is also a room filled with butterflies and a box full of caterpillars. We watched around 5 caterpillars come out of their cocoons and become butterflies which was interesting to watch. We also took several pictures of the butterflies in our hair, on our clothes and on our hands and legs which was fun. They're attracted to bright colors so if you want one to land on you, make sure to wear something bright orange!
author: Karen L.

description:
The front lawn was the most popular place! When I came here, there were several picnics and activities going on. It would definitely be a perfect spot for a nice afternoon meal. 

Admission into the conservatory is relatively cheap but there isn't all the much to see. Plus, it was extremely hot and humid in the building. I would say, go on a cooler day when it isn't too warn out. You will probably walk though it slower and enjoy it more.
author: Alyssa K.

description: A recent visit and docent led tour was an afternoon outing well spent.  A true San Francisco treasure full of history and glorious plants and foliage from around the globe.  A must see.
author: Nancy M.

description:
Beautiful exterior, flower party inside.

My parents really enjoyed it.

Beautiful waterscapes adorned with equally beautiful flowers.

Well done, GGP, well done.
author: Gabriela W.

description: A truly magical place full of plants from around the tropics.
author: Lauren S.

description: A great place to visit.  Located in Golden Gate Park, this structure is the oldest wood and glass conservatory in the country.  It houses a great variety of plant life.  Admission is $8 and worth it.  Best to come in September when the dahlias are in full bloom.
author: Anthony G.

description: The conservatory of flowers is amazing and Drew is an amazing tour guide. My family was visiting me from Seattle, and we decided to go to the conservatory for the free day. We paid $20 to release a butterfly into the butterfly exhibit. In addition to releasing the butterfly we got a tour, a pin, and a butterfly headband. The guide, Drew, was so knowledgeable. Every single one of us learned something. (Not to mention the building and the plants are beautiful.)  I'll definitely be taking people back in the future.
author: Gretta S.

description: OMG.  What a beautiful place to explore!  I cannot even describe the flowers inside this building, to give them justice.  Very informative free guides to tell you all about each one. Humidity was 90% in the lily pad area, and it was interesting to feel what that felt like! Tons of orchids, huge palms, and a great many very unusual species I've never heard of or seen before. It only costs $8.00, so is a bargain. The grounds are just gorgeous, too. Part of the Golden Gate park, it was no problem to find a parking place. (And did you know Hillary Clinton helped SAVE this wonderful place, in 1998 as First Lady, by securing funding to keep it open?)  Wow!  It is officially the oldest glass and wood structure in North America!  A Must See, if you are in the San Francisco area!
author: Maria B.

description:
This 19 century building, IMHO, is the prettiest building in the park. I must not be the only person who thinks it is. The Conservatory is on at least four historical landmarks and historical status list. I just enjoy looking at it.

Housed inside this Victorian greenhouse is about 1700 species of tropical plants. If you have only driven by before, stop it is worth a visit. If you can go on a weekday you might enjoy the tropical interior more. It is hot and humid inside and the weekend crowds make it more so.
author: Terry T.

description: This is a must visit if you find yourself in the park. Bring a packed lunch and eat it on the grass in front of the conservatory with the school groups, tourists and locals alike! The special exhibits are well thought out and incredibly immersive.
author: Oliver A.

description:
The Conservatory of Flowers is a big glass building with several different rooms (maybe like 6?).  Each room represents a different climate and contains plants that come from that climate.  There are tons of plants (many of which have some flowers).  They have a walking tour (free), and the accept credit cards.  

Pros:  The plants are beautiful.  The fish tank section is the best part! (But this is only a limited time exhibit).  It's like a small tropical oasis within the Golden Gate Park.  Relatively close to the museums and Japanese tea garden. 

Cons:  The place is pretty small.  Not worth $8 to spend the 30 minutes it takes to walk through the entire place.  You spend a lot of time waiting for other people to move as the walkways are narrow and the plants are overgrown into the walkway.  

Overall:  It's a cool spot in Golden Gate Park, but I would only stop there if you already in the area, have extra time, and have some extra cash to blow...
author: Paul W.

description: Wow so, I really didn't know what to expect (despite reading the reviews) but I was really impressed! Just the outside and walking up to the conservatory is totally worth the visit, it's beautiful!!  Be prepared, it's humid in here! It's amazing all the different kinds of plants and flowers they fit. When you walk into the center room, then there are two rooms out to each side so a total of 5 spaces of flowers. The Amazon soundtrack adds to the ambiance and everything is labeled well. A fun, different way to spend the morning in the city. Would definitely recommend.
author: Inês L.

description:
You may think the Conservatory of Flowers would smell of old lady, but it doesn't. It is old but lovingly restored. Opened in 1879, it's one of the finest examples of Victorian architecture in San Francisco. Not only is it the oldest building in the park, but it's the nation's oldest municipal wooden conservatory. With a central dome rising nearly 60 feet high and arch-shaped wings extending from it for an overall length of 240 feet, it houses an important collection of exotic plants. Sitting atop a gentle slope overlooking Conservatory Valley, it features projecting gables on its central rounded roof, stained-glass windows along the first story cornice, square Gothic corner towers and Oriental roof line.

At the beginning of each summer, the glass windows are white-washed to keep the UV levels down and protect the delicate plants against bright summer sun. Colored glass window vents around the building add variety to the tints of plants and flowers as the sunlight shifts during the day. The unique Victorian construction gives the greenhouse a whimsical feel with almost two thousand plant species represented in its floral displays (see photos). Even though the beauty of the exhibits can be astounding, the focus is really on conservation, illustrating the rapid changes in tropical habitats worldwide and spotlighting efforts currently underway to conserve these special places. 

Just finished there was a special exhibit recalling the the legendary Playland at the Beach. Now there's a new special exhibit that just opened this month and will continue through October, the Plantosaurus Rex. It's a replication of what plant life was like in prehistoric times with giant ferns, spiky horsetails and primitive cycads. There are model dinosaurs like the armored Stegosaurus foraging for the vegetation they loved best while learning about the symbiotic relationship between ancient flora and fauna. Obviously the Conservatory is putting in a lot of effort to broaden its appeal beyond seniors and wedding parties, and it's definitely worth the $5 admission for San Francisco residents ($7 for non-residents).
author: Ed U.

description: A San Francisco institution!  The building has stood unchanged for nearly 100 years.  The different rooms are amazing featuring everything from Rainforests to Deserts!  We went to see an exhibition of Cactus and Succulents that was very cool and gave us planting ideas for our garden.  We had a blast and will be back for sure!
author: Jim P.

description:
Hot and steamy but absolutely gorgeous! Played hooky from work on a Wednesday and spent the day in the City with my daughter. Bay Area natives and neither of us have ever been to Golden Gate Park or any of the amazing sites it offers.  

This exhibit is small but if you're into flowers or plants at all, it's worth the admission price. Chomp was the main attraction and honestly we were less than impressed.  But the rest of the tour was stunning to the eyes and we got a ton of great pictures.  

Outside if the Conservatory is a huge field of flowers that the caretakers were diligently  working on.  I noticed one particular older gentleman showing two young boys how to properly plant and engaging them in a way that had them both in deep concentration.  Super cute! My daughter and I were especially captivated by the dahlia garden.  This was STUNNING! The colors and sizes and varieties were breath taking as you'll see from some of the pictures we took. The best part was this exhibit was FREE so everyone can come and enjoy it.
author: Christie B.

description:
It was lovely, it really was. I have been to San Francisco several times and I was looking for something to do. I have already been to the museums and had little interest in the $40 price tag at some of those places. Then I heard about this place. It was $8 and in Golden Gate park. Sweet. 

I went along and it was actually really nice. The building is very cool and they had a carnivorous plant exhibit when I was there. It is super warm inside the building (It's a green house - duh) and I did get a bit of water on me when I got too close to a sprinkler/the sprinkler came on unexpectedly. 

Overall, a lovely time. I didn't spent that long there but then again, it was $8. Definitely worth a visit. Also, they have a pineapple in a pot plant. Nice.
author: Cat W.

description:
This little hidden gem in Golden Gate Park is always a treat. It's not huge, as it appears so from the outside, but that doesn't mean it lacks in content. Yesterday, we went and saw about a bazillion* different kinds of orchids, not to mention a ton of other amazing and beautiful plant specimens.

In the past, I've gone during their carnivorous plant shows. When you see a Pitcher Plant large enough to lose a foot in, you know it's legit. My point is, they rotate out shows regularly, and the place is always a great learning adventure for kids of all ages (like even old kid/guys like me). 

I'd even say this might be a great First Date spot. [hint, hint, nudge, nudge]

*a bazillion is no exaggeration. It's a literal scientific fact!
author: Cade P.

description:
Now's the time to go!  Awesome exhibits with everything in bloom.  Makes me turn to my plants and go, "Why can't you be like those flowers."  Thus perpetuating feelings of inadequacy and costly therapy for my petunias.

Side exhibit (Chomp) on carnivorous plants is also very good, if small.
author: Seth E.

description:
I watch romantic comedies (shut up) and in them, rich people be having their wedding at this giant white greenhouse. I'm, like, "One day, I'm going to meet a handsome, well educated man with a career and no commitment issues and we are gonna get married at that greenhouse." As upper middle class people who are in love do.

It does not look like that is going to happen any time soon, so....I finally went to the Conservatory of Flowers with a not-so-handsome, married friend who was sweating through the whole thing. 

A girl can dream, right?!

The oldest wood and glass greenhouse in the United States! 
GIANT LILY PADS!
PLANTS THAT EAT ANIMALS!
DINOSAURS BREAKING OUT OF THE ROOF!

PRO TIPS:
1. Wear proper shoes as the floor is permanently wet.
2. If you have a problem with humidity, even for short amounts of time, you have been warned.
3. It's small but beautiful.
author: Tara H.

description:
Perhaps February isn't the best time to visit a flower conservatory... Not a whole lot of cool flowers to look at. Plus, one wing was closed for renovation/planting. Maybe the good stuff was in there? Despite it being off-season, this is still a recommended place to visit! They had a special butterfly exhibit which was pretty sweet. Free-flying butterflies in a confined space!? Dreams realized. They also had a cocoon display with real cocoons. You could see 7-some different species of butterflies. Some hatched, some incubating, and some half-way-there. Quick-tip: where clothing that breathes. It's humid in here! 

*need to come back in the spring*
author: Yuhi K.

description:
My girls loved this place. It's a great learning opportunity for kids. I went when the butterfly exhibit was going on, but I know they switch it up throughout the year with other neat ones.

Go for FREE on the first Tuesday of every month!
author: Ashley E.

description:
I have been to the Conservatory of Flowers for many years, and today I came specifically to see the Aquascapes exhibit.  The Conservatory has a main dome, with a long wide tunnel on the left and a long wide tunnel on the right.  The special exhibits are on the far end of the left side.

Entry is $8 for adults and $5 for youth 12-17.  It's free on the first Tuesday of every month, but I don't recommend the free day if you can afford it.  What I love most about the Conservatory (and miss about the old Academy of Sciences) is that it is cozy.  You are in rooms densely packed with plants and flowers with very narrow walkways.  Imagine narrow walkways clogged with people try to pass by each other.

The Aquascapes exhibit was quite impressive.  It reminded me how much I've always wanted a densely planted freshwater aquarium.  I noticed all the tanks were for sale once the show was over, but no prices were posted.  I guess if you have to ask you cannot afford it.

I love the aquatic plants room on the far right side, with the huge pond in the middle.  Be sure to compare what you see with a picture of that same room over 100 years ago.  This room also houses the carnivorous plants.
author: The Bottomless Pi T.

description: Really cool building. Love all of the interesting plants! There's not much else to say about this, I just wandered around looking at plants.
author: Samantha O.

description:
My wife and I held our wedding reception at the Conservatory of Flowers in September and had an exquisite experience. Samantha was our main point of contact and helped ensure that everything went incredibly smoothly. She worked seamlessly with both our wedding coordinator and our caterer to ensure perfect setup and tear down, plus went the extra mile to ensure the finer details were addressed (i.e. setting up the photo booth, providing extra pillows, etc).

All of the staff we interacted with truly sought to ensure the day turned out how we envisioned it. Would highly recommend the Conservatory (and Samantha!) as a great venue for a wedding or other occasion.
author: Hugh W.

description:
With out a doubt, this building and the gardens around it is one of the most beautiful spots in the city. The contrast of the stark white building with the lush foliage and flowers is always a sight to behold. This sounds way dramatic but seriously, this spot is awesome.

The botanical gardens itself are somewhat small but still beautiful and a varied selection of flowers to see and read about. Definitely a spot to check out if you are in San Francisco even for a short weekend.
author: Steven N.

description:
This was a quick stop before the California Academy of Sciences. It was a nice walk thru of some unusual plants and flowers, and also some common ones we eat/use daily but never get to see the actual plant (I.e. cacao, cinnamon, coffee, etc.). Beautiful place to take pictures. I think a guided tour would've made this place way more enjoyable. 

It was very warm and humid of course, which I underestimated. Not a great place for an infant or a toddler. My 4 year old wanted to get thru it as quickly as possible. Overall, good value for the price.
author: Selina R.

description:
I've been to the Conservatory three times, once as a tourist and twice as a semi-local. Each time I go, I find something new to wonder at and like to keep on top of what special exhibits are being shown. Most recently, it was the Playland recreation. Their model of Playland at the beach, complete with dwarf plants, a Golden Gate bridge replica and a model train was extremely well done. It was worth going back a few weeks ago for this exhibit alone.

This is the kind of place you can spend 10 minutes or several hours depending on how much you want to soak in the scenery and well documented plant info. As a gardener and lover of all things plants, I can't get enough of this place. The building is beautiful from the outside and even spending time on the grounds out front is a magical experience. 

Once inside the various climate zones provide you with a nice frame of reference for the types of plants housed here and there is a cute little gift shop to boot. 

If I lived in the city, I can see getting a membership here. I think it's a must see place to bring family or friends from out of town. Simply beautiful!
author: Jennifer N.

description: As a native San Franciscan and professional wedding planner, it was a true joy to be able to do one of my dream wedding venues, the Conservatory! The event coordinator, Samantha, was an absolute JOY to work with, and so was her two staff members on the night of the event. They were so absolutely helpful, with smiles on their faces and a willingness to do anything and everything they were asked to do. They were so proactive! I can't recommend this venue enough for so many reasons: the beauty, the uniqueness and for how they took such great care of my clients. A class act and venue that deserves your serious consideration for your wedding day.
author: Genevieve R.

description:
From now till October, check out the butterfly exhibit inside the Conservatory of Flowers.

Guaranteed to delight, especially the princess "high maintenance" types (young and old, and uhm....female or male or male pretending to be female, or male who acts effeminate but is hetero http://www.hulu.com/watch/281966)
author: Ken K.

description: Beautiful of course, educational and love how they kept so many of the vintage details that makes it beautiful.
author: Ranee W.

description:
Nearly perfect weather and the Conservatory was moderately crowded for the end of the Wicked Plants Exhibit.  The Wicked Plants Exhibit was well documented and a fun Halloween related twist - who knew Cashews were so dangerous!  The rest of the Conservatory is bursting with different types of flora and fauna waiting to be captured by your camera.  Charge your batteries because we easily took 80 pictures.

I highly recommend catching a tour by one of the Docents.  The tour added to the depth of the experience and gave us a greater appreciation of the Conservatory.
author: Scott P.

description:
I was told about the butterfly garden a while ago but haven't had the chance to check it out so I randomly did recently. Apparently the exhibit was supposed to end in OCT2013 but it was extended until 16MAR2014. Timing couldn't have been better because I planned to go 15MAR2014.

Anyway, the conservatory itself was not impressive to me, possibly because I've been to many botanical gardens around the world. I can see that it would be pretty cool to someone who has never left San Francisco or never been to a garden. Also, maybe I'm just not that into plants/flowers. Like someone else said in a Yelp review, there are more plants than there are flowers and you might as well call the joint Conservatory of Plants. I did go in the winter so maybe if I waited a few months until spring the flowers would be in full bloom.

The butterfly exhibit is pretty awesome. You're basically in a huge butterfly net and there are lots of random pretty butterflies flying around. You're not supposed to touch them--don't bring your pet chameleon either. There was a pretty cool exhibit in the middle that showed lots of old cocoons. Worth the $5 I paid to get in? Yes. Too bad the entire thing is now closed.

This conservatory is a great place to start/take a date and a gem in Golden Gate park. Lots of people have wedding receptions here too--I saw a few people scoping out how their reception would look like. There are many things to do in the area like see the museums or grab food in the Richmond or Sunset which makes the conservatory a good stopping point during your day.

I'll be looking out for any special exhibits in the future. Entry fee is $8 unless you are a student, military, SF resident, etc.
author: Marlon T.

description: Very lovely place to take friends or family from out of town. My mom enjoys the trip very much! We would totally come back again.
author: Ting T.

description:
I had passed by the Conservatory of Flowers many times and finally decided to check it out. From the outside, I knew it was small but I didn't realize how small until I was inside.

There are some beautiful flowers and exhibits, but for ~$10 per person, it's on the pricey side, especially relative to the other activities in Golden Gate Park. 

If you are at all claustrophobic, the conservatory is not the place for you. It is very humid and hot with narrow aisles so not a place to linger for very long (tough to spend more than 30 minutes in there).
author: Wendy L.

description:
This is a quick stop in Golden Gate Park and is only $5 with a student ID, so I figured, why not stop in? I am glad I did. It is beautiful and includes multiple sections inside the main building. 

I especially enjoyed the orchids and the tropical plants. There were fountains and it was nice and warm in there. It is nice to be able to stop and sit on the benches in there and just look at the beauty. 

When I went, there was a special exhibit of carnivorous plants which was cool. I liked reading the facts about the history of the conservatory and how it has been saved and protected by different donators and politicians. 

Be sure to stop by on your way through Golden Gate Park.
author: Kelly C.

description: Beautiful and so much so see. Only wish it was larger! Very peaceful stop- definitely a must if you are visiting the GG park
author: Talon Z.

description:
Are you looking for a place to learn more about botany and do you want to see some butterflies? Well, this place has your answer. Botany is the science of plants. I went here on a stroll through the Golden Gate Park after a morning in San Francisco, and my family decided to take a look at this place. The building itself is not really big, about the size of a really large house, but you could spend more than a couple hours here just looking at some interesting plants and learning about butterflies. 

The butterfly exhibition was really cool. I haven't seen a butterfly in years, so it was great to see some butterflies fly around the building. I also got to learn a little about metamorphosis again, which is the natural process of a caterpillar becoming a butterfly. This place has a large collection of chrysalises (the "transformation" stage), so you can possibly observe a new butterfly coming out of its cocoon. 

As for the plants, the fascinating plants that I found interesting were the ones from the Amazon jungles of Brazil and the jungles of Papua New Guinea. The lily pads and the flowers were really nice. You may need to be careful when you walk around, because you don't want to slip and fall into the small pools they have. There's a nice unique and fresh smell, which gave me the slight feeling that I was in a jungle somewhere. I also got to see some somewhat "freaky-looking" carnivorous plants, which are these plants that eat insects. These plants were called "pitcher plants". 

Overall, if you are really into looking at exotic plants and butterflies in a city like San Francisco, this place is a pretty good choice. Although I am not really that interested in plants, it was cool to get glimpses of exotic plants that I probably won't see for a really long time. It's also a great place to learn some facts, and it makes me wonder if being a botanist is really that fun.
author: Ambrose C.

description:
This place was bigger than I thought. The middle of March is usually the best time I take my gf out to a flower place. She loves flowers and I wanted to take her to something with lots of variety. So the Conservatory of Flowers was what I went with based on previous reviews. Thanks YELP! They had about 4 large scale rooms with 1 bonus exhibit. Each room looked like it had plants from different parts of the world. I was able to see lots of ferns, orchids, and cocoa plants when i was there.

It's somewhat humid inside, we skipped the tour part because sometimes you just want to just stare at the plants and enjoy the moment instead of listen to an old person talk for days. Sorry, please don't hunt me down. 

What's really nice was afterwards, we were able to sit in the grass out in the front near the field of flowers and listened to the nice sax player and his band play romantic music!

5$ for Students. Bring your ID!
author: Jeffrey L.

description:
This is one of the most beautiful places that I have ever been to. I love to bring my camera and spend hours upon hours capturing shots of the flowers and butterflies. I know that it seems like the kind of place that you might be tempted to skip if you are a tourist, but I highly suggest at least ducking in to give it a try. I doubt that you will want to leave or regret your stay. 

On cold or rainy days it is truly a bit of warm paradise. On my last visit I had a stuffy nose from a cold that wouldn't go away. I noticed that the humidity took care of that within minutes. In fact, the whole place is great therapy. 

Note that strollers are not allowed inside, but there is stroller parking outside and the ticket booth seller watches the strollers. I was told that there has never been a stroller robbery.
author: Jenny M.

description:
I can see myself, in the past, agreeing to go to the Conservatory of Flowers just to please a girlfriend or to look cultured and botanically friendly in a dating situation, but I would have been wrong. I know this now not just because I have a great girlfriend who actually makes me want to do these things while on vacation in the Bay Area, but also because the Conservatory of Flowers is a treasure trove for everyone to enjoy.*

The Conservatory is small, but if you take your time and observe you could spend between an hour and two inside. Be prepared for the humidity and bring a camera; there are so many things you can take close shots of that later, you will be impressed with yourself.**

The exhibits were beautifully curated and the addition of plenty of water sources in the forms of larger pools, smaller fish bowls inside of things you wouldn't expect and fountains really enhanced the feng shui of this entire place. The butterfly exhibit was a bonus and very well done.

The Conservatory of Flowers is a can't miss in my opinion. The building is the perfect setting for its contents and it is a very nice and relaxing way to spend an hour or two enveloped with nature.
________________
*If you are just trying to impress a date, you will probably be in very good shape. Just actually pay attention while you are in there. You're welcome. As if no one knew this, I saw it got voted Best Place for a First Date sometime in the not so distant past.
**Unless you really don't know how to take a picture, then you will just delete them because you're not going on that second date anyway.
author: Jonathan G.

description: Wonderful magical fairy tale place. Came here right after the botanical gardens so I thought I'd be flowered out but it was such an interesting unique place i was amazed! The gardens outside are great for picnicking or lounging in the sun. The inside is full of unique flowers from interesting climates. They have a eye spy map to keep kids entertained and the rooms are truly  breathtaking.
author: Kate L.

description:
I was prepared to be blown away at this place and was very excited to visit it. Made it there, took a ton of photos outside and walked in. Walked right back out within 3 minutes. Not sure what qualifications I needed to be able to appreciate this. Perhaps I went at the wrong time? (February?) Barely any flowers and it was VERY small. Just a room to the left and another to the right. It was incredibly hot and humid although the weather was beautiful outside. DId I mention how hot it was?

Not sure where I went wrong. I thought there was another room towards the back perhaps with an actual display of gorgeous flowers. I asked and the woman that worked there who looked at me like I was an alien and she said " this is it". Oh well, that was that. 

Walked right back out and really thought (considering I was in there for less than 5 minutes) I should get a refund but honestly, did not even try because it really was not that expensive.I must be just missing the point considering all the love this place has on Yelp but also felt I needed to voice my personal experience here. Maybe give it a shot if this is your thing and looking at green leaves everywhere you look is appealing. 

If you expect to walk in and be floored by display after display of gorgeous flowers, all in your face, everywhere you look and be comfortable while there (as in not sweating) then skip it! Not going to happen, at least not in February.
author: Brenda P.

description:
Loved this place! It's not big yet there is some much to see and so much to learn.
We had our 8yo with us and did the little Treasure Hunt sheet-it was amazing-I learned with my little one and it was just fun. Beautiful place! Good job!
author: Natalya V.

description: Super cute place with so many variety of flowers in bloom! Although it is quite small--you can go through it in 30 minutes--I love the orchids and the indoor lily pond they have. I came here on the free first Tuesday of the month and De Young was also free that day so I was able to go to both and explore the vast Golden Gate Park. Next time, I will bring lunch and picnic on the green lawn in front of the Conservatory.
author: Karen T.

description:
This place is a landmark and yet most of us pass it by, on the way to the De Young. It is full of interesting, astonishing, and curious plants and flowers. If you love orchids you MUST go. It is always warm, always misty, the perfect place for a "get away" from the cold fog. There are a few benches and places to sit, and rest, chat or study your favorite plants. Most plants are tagged, and there are docents available for questions.

You'll love the butterfly exhibit, they zoom past you, flying all over, landing on flowers, taking a drink from their feeders. You can get really close and see their delicate wings and colors. It is very large for a conservatory, but you'll be able to see everything in an hour or two, even at a slow pace. 

Bathrooms are nearby outside. You can go in and out. There is a small kiosk for a snack or drink. And after all your exploring you can sit outside on the lawns and enjoy the planted gardens in front of the conservatory. Remember, this area of Golden Gate Park is closed to cars on Sunday, so on that day you'll have to walk in. However you get here, bus car or by foot it is a wonderful respite.
author: Jacqueline S.

description:
Highlights
- The perfect tourist and local hidden gem spot to check out. 
- The architecture of this conservatory always intrigued me to come visit and the gardens directly outside and rose garden beside it are beautiful. 
- They have special exhibits that rotate out every so often, which makes it interesting. I've visited twice one for a dinosaur exhibit and another for a miniature SF landmark exhibit. Both were really cool. 
- Orchids didn't really impress me, but the other types of flowers and being able to experience this in the city is very cool. I loved the miniature SF landmark displays. 

Improvements
- If you can't handle heat and humidity, this place is not for you. It definitely feels like a rainforest when you venture inside. It makes sense in order to keep the flowers and greenery alive, but I would recommend to avoid coming during a warm day (not that you have to worry about that in SF for most of the year). ;) 
- No bathrooms inside the conservatory, only public bathrooms shared with park patrons are located outside. 

Tip
- Come on a weekday to avoid crowds, take your sweet time, and easily snag a parking spot right outside.
author: Tracy T.

description:
The Conservatory of Flowers is part of San Francisco history, but it's also part of my family's history in San Francisco. It will always have a special place in my heart and city. One of my favorite pictures is of my Grandparents standing in front of the Conservatory of Flowers, looking so dapper and in love. Maybe some day I'll have the same photo.

I love flowers and plants, but when I arrived at the Conservatory of Flowers this weekend, it was closed so I was only able to enjoy it's outer beauty and surrounding foliage. I did get a peak inside and spotted the Carnivorous Pitcher plant, which I saw earlier on Haight for sale. 

The Conservatory of Flowers was purchased as a prefabricated building by James Lick and after his death, it was purchased, donated and erected in Golden Gate Park in 1868. This always amazes me with the thought of pre-fab buildings dating back to the 1800's. 

I had the opportunity to work on the Rehabilitation project, while working for a building subcontractor almost 10 years ago. Another opportunity to work on a San Francisco Historical project, in the city I call my home.
author: Rebekah T.

description: My friend took us to this greenhouse located in Golden Gate Park, which is known to house over 1700 exotic plants. This is one of the first municipal conservatory ever built in the US. For a cheap entrance fee of $8 (tourist)/$5 (with San Francisco ID),  this place definitely is worth checking out if you love exotic flowers and plants. There are so many different type of plants that I can't name them all. You'll just have to take my word and check the place out for yourself. The area to and from the conservatory is also very serene and beautiful. There are plenty of other things to do in the Golden Gate Park as well (ie. Japanese botanical gardens) when you are there.
author: Vi T.

description:
There aren't that many flowers here... which is why they maybe need to be conserved?

There are about four rooms of ferns, fronds, and trees... They're labeled.  It's cool to experience so many plants from so many different parts of the world in one place, but I'll be honest: the dinosaur plant room they advertised was a little bit of a letdown.  How can a room with dinosaur noises be a letdown?? About half of it was a gift shop, and there weren't that many dinosaurs... or even plants!

Overall, it was more enjoyable to hang out on the lawn in front of the conservatory... It can get pretty hot and humid in those tropical rooms!
author: Allison M.

description:
The park itself is gorgeous and well kept.  Seems like a nice place to get away from the "city" to just lay on the grass and relax.  There is a Segway tour that goes around for a moderate fee.  There's occasionally some live music done by the locals.

The California academy of sciences is just a nice walk from this place, as well as the de Young Museum and the Japanese Tea Garden.
author: J.P. B.

description: Ok if you like flowers / botany this is beautiful.  I try to like it, I really do.  But after seeing a few flowers and plants, the rest all blend together.  Don't get me wrong, this place is cool.  Cool history.  Super unique and charming architecture.  I love having this in SF and love it that people go.  Just not sure I'll be going back.
author: Joshua W.

description:
I approach the front door and quicken my step in anticipation of my first slow, deep breath of the air within. I call it instant relaxation.

Each room is it's own little world of living wonder. One room is cool and slightly moist, radiant flowers of all sizes springing out every which way. Two steps through a door and the humidity hits, damp hot air getting me as close to a rainforest as San Francisco can offer. I look down on plants that look strangely familiar... I guess I've never seen a pineapple still growing before. Is that a cocoa bean on that tree?

With benches sporadically placed throughout, I can sit and just breathe the air and stare off into the flora. It seems to put my mind at ease. Observing vivid orchids or twisting my neck to look up into the vines, this place has a way to drain away stress. The special exhibits room is always icing on the visit, glaring at carnivorous plants (the poor ants!) or looking at replicas of SF's notable landmarks made from recycled materials. I feel like a kid in a candy store, I only wish the Conservatory were a bit bigger.

It's no replacement for being outdoors and experiencing nature in it's true element, but when you live in a major city it's surely a treat to have a little piece of it just for us.
author: Justin N.

description:
My wife and I chose to have our wedding reception for ~130 people at the the Conservatory of Flowers this past July. We met in San Francisco, we spent a lot of time in Golden Gate Park, and the Conservatory of Flowers was the perfect choice for a venue that provided beautiful views, an outdoor feel, and an iconic San Francisco landmark for our guests to enjoy. For those of you looking for a shorter review know this; our wedding reception could not have been more perfect. If we could go back and re-do our wedding 100 times we would always choose the Conservatory of Flowers over any other possible venue. 

The Conservatory Manager of Special Events, Samantha Ordway, was an absolute pleasure to work with as she was extremely professional, provided excellent communication, and was attentive to everything we wanted for our wedding reception. She went out of her way to help coordinate the entire event and everything went off without a hitch. This went a long way in relieving our stress with wedding planning as we knew we could rely on her/her team's execution to get everything done just right. WE EVEN HAD PARK RANGERS PROVIDE SECURITY FOR THE EVENT!  

Our rental included the entire Conservatory greenhouse for the cocktail hour as well as the Orchid Pavilion for our four hour reception. While we did not get to enjoy that much of the cocktail hour (busy taking photos), our guests raved about how beautiful all of the exhibits were and many remarked that it was the most beautiful wedding venue they have ever visited. We were very fortunate to have superb weather on the day of our wedding which made the photos we took out front of the Conservatory come out incredibly gorgeous. The setup of the Orchid Pavilion was ideal for a wedding of our size. We had enough room for all of our guests to sit comfortably while also fitting our taco bar, DJ booth, bar, and photobooth. All in all, we could not be more satisfied with our choice of wedding venues. The Conservatory of Flowers provided us an experience that felt authentic, unique, and was just a fun place to visit for all of our guests. This venue will always hold a special place in our hearts and we highly recommend the Conservatory of Flowers to other couples seeking a wedding venue.
author: Ryan B.

description:
Orchids, palm trees, and trains, oh my! The CoF is living history in green-o-visionary pleasure. The Victorian glass-and-metal frame, restored with love, care, and millions of donated dollars between 1999 and 2003, shines in wintry splendor. The holiday train and flower display, which recreates landmarks of San Francisco in exquisite miniature fashion (replete with a daily dose of "fog" that comes in from the Bay) is very cool, photogenic, and family-friendly.* I got to practice my photography skills capturing the sights, sounds, and motions here.

And then there are all those flowers and plants. This is NOT London's Kew Gardens, the DC National Arboretum, the Royal Botanic Gardens in Sydney, the Berlin Botanischer Garten in Dahlem, the Schönbrunn Palace gardens in Vienna, or the Kokyo Higashi Gyoen in Tokyo. It's a lot smaller here, but their handful of rooms and well-chosen selections of green and prettily-colored things do indeed pack a punch. We loved the winter holiday decorations (see photos) and the great sense of style here that blended the best of old world, European collecting and display practices with those of the Pacific Rim. 

For $7 (the cost of a Blue Mountain coffee at Philz), you can while away many precious and unforgettable moments. Forget the long lines at the CA Academy of Science! Forget the $30+ weekend admissions fee at the De Young Museum! Come here to the CoF and have some cheap fun!!

(*) Note: I decided to do a separate Yelp entry for this special annual holiday exhibit.
author: Bradley N.

description: Came here on a beautiful Sunday afternoon.  It was one of those rare days in San Francisco where you get to bask in the sunshine.  At the suggestion of my friend we decided to come to the conservatory.  There was all sorts of beautiful flowers, with the Venus Fly Traps being my favorite.  Be warned however, it is HOT and humid inside this place so dress appropriately.  I also uploaded a couple of pics, one of the Fly Traps and another of Butterwort.
author: Mark S.

description:
Came here using an awesome Groupon coupon for buy one get one free admission. Not sure how it's like the rest of the months, but I went late February (a a week ago). Lots and lots of carnivorous plants (scaryyyy) and orchids. Mostly lots of green, so don't think you'll be seeing blooms everywhere (as the name suggest); again, I came during Feb so I don't know how the rest of the year is like. 

Honestly though, was a little small and we spent only a little over an hour here. However, really cool how it's like you're entering a whole different country when you go in the conservatory! Some of the rooms are cold and damp, others hot and humid.

I think my favorite was being able to see a coffee plant in person. Ah! I love my morning cup o' joe.

I love the gift shop! Cute train goes weaving through tiny made-from-recycled-things buildings. The gift shop has lots of those mini plant growing kits! Super cute.
author: Jennie C.

description: This conservatory building is modeled after one in Southampton, England. They have wonderful exhibits of hothouse plants and flowers there. When my kids were small they especially liked the carnivorous plant and butterfly exhibits. The gift shop is also a lot of fun. Lovely. A little pricey, like most things in San Francisco, but lovely and worth it.
author: Merry P.

description:
They don't allow strollers so I wasn't able to go in. Parental discrimination. 
It says it on the website, but I wasn't aware I needed to check as it just seems so ridiculous. I have an 11 month old the size of a 2 year old that they wanted me to carry the whole time and they wanted me to leave my $200 stroller on the lawn. I think not.
author: Nina S.

description:
FREE First Tues of the Month.  Took Bart & N-Outbound Muni, supposedly N is every 7-min, but it feels much longer.  From the DeYoung, continue Right on JFK, then past the Rhododendron, it's on the Left-side.

Bathrooms outside.  Women's 3 stalls/1 sink.

Many warm rooms suppose to be like a rainforest. 

Playland exhibit now thru April 15.  Ant Plant - ants sleep during the day, come out at night.  Trains running.
author: Ann L.

description: Beautiful nature getaway in the heart of golden gate park for a rainy day (or any day)! To get the $5 price, you have to bring proof of SF residency, which I didn't have but paying the regular $8 admission fee wasn't a big deal. I was impressed with their international selection of exotic plants and pretty flowers, and I have to say that I was definitely tempted to touch the plants even though you aren't allowed to. I can see why this is rated as a great date place, it's calm and interesting to wander around with a +1!
author: Jing L.

description: A gorgeous remnant of a more awestruck time. I love this place with its white-glossed panes of glass, its miniature orange trees, its large jungle plants, and the special exhibits that cycle through. My favorite exhibits so far have been a set of miniatures of San Francisco landmarks set in greenery (see picture) and the Wicked Plants exhibit, which displayed dangerous plants and vignettes on how they have been deviously used in the past. It's set on a beautiful lawn, with many seasonal flowers going in and out of blossom in front. There is a less seasonal drum circle installed perpetually at the east side. :)
author: Sharon G.

description:
Beautiful large greenhouse of tropical flowers and ponds.  It's very warm and humid inside, it's a vacation to the tropics without the long plane flight or mosquitos. 

The conservatory can be viewed in an hour or so, it's not expansive, though it is packed with plants and it is enjoyable to linger inside.
author: N T.

description: Conservatory of Flowers is so great there are plenty of trees and flowers and plants to see here there's endless amounts amazing experience here 5 stars.
author: Jay C.

description:
Came to the Conservatory of Flowers for the very first time to see the WICKED PLANTS exhibit & to hear Amy Stewart speak about her book of the same title: "Wicked Plants: The Weed That Killed Lincoln's Mother and Other Botanical Atrocities" 

The Conservatory itself is fabulously laid out with lush plants & signage all over so we novices can learn about what our eyes are beholding & can appreciate the intricacies of the plant 

Different rooms feature different "themes".....but we made a beeline to the Wicked Plants room 

Very clever & tongue in cheek - music from the 20s playing & wrought iron fencing hold back the vicious plants that have killed throughout history.....some we even have in my house! Eek! Who knew!! 

Then moseyed back through the Conservatory to the Orchid Room where there was wine, cheese & crackers for mingling purposes before Amy Stewart took the stand & talked to us about her research for the book, her passion for dangerous plants. She was witty, had lots of great stories & brought it down to a level that both plant experts & this novice (again) could understand 

Will def be back here for sure to enjoy the gardens, walk through the Conservatory & to hear fantastic lectures!
author: Adrienne G.

description:
I took a long run today in GGP and was feeling cheerful and high on endorphins. I ran by the Conservatory and decided, for the first time, to run up and take a closer look. I didn't have anything on me but my iPhone and earbuds As my BMW was parked by Kezar Stadium. 

As I walked up to the front entrance two elderly people were manning the front entrance. It was about noon time. Both the elderly, white haired man and woman were rude, Gruffy and frankly not friendly at all. I asked a few questions about the Consevatory and they begrudgingly gave me answers like I was some homeless person. I assure you I was not. What a terrible duo to put at your front entrance! What a distasteful first impression. Esp when first greeted by a broad smile. Big turn off.
author: Moh T.

description:
Don't be fooled by the name or the gardens out front. The Conservatory of Flowers really only has one actual flower: orchids. But there are so many varieties of orchids, of every shape, color and size, that it kind of feels like many different flowers.

The conservatory is housed in an old, white "greenhouse" with several rooms. It showcases mostly tropical trees and plants, including an aquatic section. It's pretty warm and humid in there because of the tropical climate so make sure you dress in layers so you can peel them off. The walk paths are somewhat small and there are branches, vines and leaves everywhere, so it can feel a little claustrophobic. 

All joking aside, there actually are other types of flowers in the Conservatory, but they're less obvious and can be hidden by the dense foliage. I was less impressed by them and more so by the giant Amazon lily pads and carnivorous plants. Information plaques throughout give nice, succinct summaries of the various plant life and really help you appreciate how fragile, delicate and beautiful nature is. I think most people walk away inspired to do what they can to protect the earth. I know I was.

I happened to come on a day when admission was free, but it's normally $5 for SF residents, which isn't that bad. If you're craving more flowers after touring the Conservatory, there are several flower beds right out front and a garden of dahlias just off to the east.
author: Josephine L.

description:
I'm REALLY surprised that this place has 4.5 stars with so many reviews! Maybe I just went during a bad time of the year but I really was not impressed by this exhibit. I've been to many conservatories and gardens in my time so maybe I had high expectations going into it. 

Bottom line, I'd encourage you to save your $8 and the hour you'd spend here and just take a leisurely stroll through Golden Gate Park or visit the Japanese Tea Garden instead.
author: H T.

description: Best plant housing I have ever seen. Plants housed in three temperature zones. A lot of non native plants. if you are crazy about plants then this is the must see place. I have not been back here since 2003 restoration. Looks like same type plants with improved drainage and temp control. $8/person unless you come on free first Tuesday of month.  I recommend this for plant people and park free in park except Sunday when the park is blocked for bicyclers.
author: Clifford W.

description: It's very pretty outside. So many colorful flowers and gardeners. Inside is ok. Very humid, warm, and moist. I'm not a flower person but there were some nice looking ones. It's a good place for photographers lol
author: Tammy W.

description:
One the most beautiful places in all of SF. I got married here 3 weeks and all of my guests were blown away by just how gorgeous the conservatory is. 

For anyone thinking about a big party (anniversary, wedding, etc) definitely consider this venue. When it comes down to it the price is right and it is absolutely stunning. 

Shout out to Annie Abernathy who is the event manager at the COF and helped make our day super special, you're the best.
author: Nick O.

description: My buddy and I visit here seasonally.  A great place to spend a day.  The orchid displays are great today.  The worst smelling orchid ever!  We saw so many flowers that were new as well.  A very hot day in SF at 80 degrees and the conservatory was humid and hotter!
author: Tom A.

description: Great place to check out if you haven't been there! Cool plants I've never seen before. Look into when they have free entry days! We got lucky and that was the case for us.
author: Jenny J.

description:
Pretty awesome place whether or not you like flowers. I went there last weekend with my girlfriend and we both really enjoyed it. They give a discount on admission if you have a valid student id. Bring a blanket and hang out on the huge lawn before or after your visit! A must-visit place in SF. Here is a link to some photos I took on my visit...

http://wp.me/p3GisD-4X

-Chris
author: Christopher R.

description:
Beautiful plants throughout this pleasantly warm (for San Francisco) greenhouse in Golden Gate Park. The colors are almost too much to take paired with the all of the smells of flowering plants. 

It's a cheap place to take a date to if you're on a budget plus its pretty romantic. You could spend a good hour here or longer if you have a seat and take it all in.
author: Justin C.

description: Came here to look at different flowers for my upcoming wedding and I now know that I want to go with Orchids! It was also cool to see all the bananas hanging from the tree. It was a little crowded for my taste but overall a BEAUTIFUL place!
author: Sarah T.

description: Greeter Dennis Scacco was so pleasant and helpful! We were blown away (no pun intended)  at how beautiful the conservatory was. Love the orchids! Thumbs up to the tropical exhibit! $5 tickets for locals with a San Francisco ID.
author: Louisa D.

description: If I hadn't been to several botanical gardens on several Hawaiian Islands I would give this 5 stars. To see what is in these hot houses outdoors and times 100 makes these seem, well, pale. However we are in California, not lush, lush Hilo and for this area the big leaves, sexy orchids, and eyeball trunks are magnificent. The carnivorous plants with huge hanging pitchers are magnificent. Spent a lovely 45 minutes or so looking at hundreds of plants in the various hothouses.
author: Marco M.

description: The Conservatory is stunning, instructive, historical and a real treat. I can recall the dark days when it was so badly damaged during a massive storm so many years ago. I think it took over a decade and the dedication of countless individuals (including many donors) to bring it back online for SF. What a loss it would have been had these people not helped out. SF has lost enough cultural and historical beauty in the past few decades. I am so pleased that this wonderful "botanical museum" is still with us! I hope all SF visitors are encouraged to put the Conservatory on their agenda.
author: Cherry S.

description:
It's been said before, and I'll say it again.  I don't do too much credit to the fairer sex.  I've never had a mani-pedi, I never listened to New Kids on the Block, and I can't put on my own eye makeup to save my life.  I also don't know too much about flowers, except that they're extremely pretty.  So I wasn't sure how much I would get out of the Conservatory of Flowers.  I had a really exceptional time both because it was definitely not required of me to know anything about flowers, and also because it wasn't really required that I pore over each and every placard so as to learn about flowers, either.  It was a hypnotically chill place to spend a couple hours, and I am most certainly impressed.

The Conservatory of Flowers is composed of five rooms, each containing a varied array of plants.  They're in various stages of growth and bloom, from various parts of the globe, and the temperature of each room takes you from climate to climate.  In the first room there's a delightful little pond full of delightful little koi, but it also contains numerous plants that you may have encountered in your daily culinary adventures.  Banana trees, different kinds of palm trees, ginger, cacao, and vanilla beans are to be found all along the exhibit, some plants tiny and colorful, and other plants with leaves easily the size of an adult human being.

But it goes on!  There are plants named for their appearance, plants named for their region, plants named for the taste of their roots or fruits - exquisite plants, simple plants, large plants, small plants, aquatic plants, deadly plants (per their current exhibit) - I can honestly say I never got tired of looking at plants while I was there, and that's kind of remarkable for someone with my attention span.  

I do wish that some of the plants had been marked a little better, as there are still some flowers of which I couldn't locate the names.  But I think that's also part of the charm - you're in a controlled wilderness, and barely-ordered chaos has never looked so beautiful.  I found myself itching to take pictures "a la tourist," and just when I thought I might be getting tired of flowers, my eyes grew wide with the sight of something even more unreal and fairy-tale-like than what came before.

If you're into botany or horticulture, this is your place.  If you're not and you just want a place to kill a few hours, this is also your place.  It's a wonderland of green and heat and information, and you would be remiss to pass it by.
author: Becca S.

description: This was one of the attractions on my San Francisco Go Card, so the husband and I wandered over from the nearby museums to check it out.  It is a super cute little conservatory crammed full of flowers (mostly pitcher plants, really) and a great place to find a hidden seat and take a load off of over-walked legs.  I enjoyed the various rooms, especially the one full of orchids because, well, orchids, and was a little sad to reach the end and not have more to see!  I'm glad this was part of our Go Card package or we might have missed out on this little gem.
author: Alison M.

description: Just love this place, a must see in GG Park.
author: Jon U.

description: This place is a treasure. A must see if you are visiting San Francisco. Walk in and lose yourself for a while in a tropical oasis. The outside grounds and Golden Gate Park are breathtaking. I feel very fortunate to be able to visit pretty much at will. Do yourself a favor and spend a day here and through the park. If you live local (in the Bay Area), there is NO excuse!
author: Josh D.

description:
Groupon Deal: $7 for 2 people

Can I tell you this was so worth it instead of paying $7/person?

I don't know if it is just me, but I have experienced way better varieties of flowers/plants before.  I left there not impressed and disappointed.  I can even say that Berkeley's Botanical Garden is ten times better than the Conservatory of Flowers.

There wasn't much flowers in the first place!  All the orchids, I can see at the asian market... with even MORE varieties too.  There were way more plants than flowers.  There are a total of about 4 rooms, where 1 was the special display for the holidays I am guessing.  Small gift shop available.

In general, I thought this place would provide us more amazing flowers and varieties.  I, instead, got more green plants than anything.  If anything, you can name it, Conservatory of Plants, instead to not mislead people.

The one star only goes to the beautiful white building, that eventually fools you into coming in. :/
author: Kathy D.

description: Great scenery and flowers, design elements of a different era.
author: E W.

description:
I'm not much of a flower person but it's a nice place to go either way. Tickets were $7.00 for adults and it's at a booth outside the conservatory.

When you enter, it's like you're transferred into the Amazon jungle. Nothing but trees, flowers, bushes, ponds, and the sorts.
author: Scott N.

description:
This review is long overdue - I went in September and they had a Dahlia exhibit - yes so many beautiful Dahlia's were in bloom and just absolutly stunning.....

Another beautiful peaceful place to visit in San Francisco-
This was a photographers dream!!! Just take a look at some of my pics....

There were alot of Bees but they don't bother you - if it's between a human and a flower I'm guessing the Bee would pick the flower.
I can't believe just how many variations there are of Dahlia's.
There are Dahlia's that look like 2 to 3 flowers in one - crazy but in a cool way.

I thoroughly enjoyed my visit to the Conservatory of Flowers- so much to look at, nature at it's finest and hey, it's free!!! Can't complain about free....

I would definitly without a doubt visit again....
author: Ursula U.

description: Just had my wedding the CoF in July and I couldn't have been happier. Samantha was extremely easy to work with and the whole evening was perfect. People are still mentioning what an awesome venue it was! Thank you!!
author: Penny S.

description: With out a doubt, this building and the gardens around it is one of the most beautiful spots in the city.
author: Gavin M.

description:
Opulent. Decadent. Beauty. All housed in an classic setting.  

Even if looking at flowers isn't your thing, this place will thrill you and peek your interest in new and exciting ways.  

Admission prices are cheap, and they offer discounts to SF residents, so bring your ID :)
author: Sunshine S.

description: Affordable ticket prices, friendly and knowledgeable docents, and an amazing panoply of flowers and trees in this conservatory. Many of the tropical plants brought back nostalgia for my parents too. Definitely a place worth checking out if you have a green thumb.
author: Susan A.

description: So warm & pretty inside.  Like a trip to the tropics!  Love all the orchids.
author: Kim S.

description:
Day 6 of MWLAWMBF:
We had actually planned to come here on a different day, but we finally got around to it on a nice sunny Sunday in San Francisco. It seems a bit oxymoronic I know, but the weather was absolutely beautiful for a great walk in the Golden Gate Park. The original prices aren't too bad, but I got a Groupon for the Conservatory that was a 2 for 1 deal. Not too shabby.

There were so many flowers and plants in this small little greenhouse. I was amazed by the variety and difference between them.  Most of the flowers were blooming so I got great shots of flowers that would be gorgeous as art on walls or things like that. 

The special exhibit was about the city and made these different landmarks from  ordinary everyday items. It was really cool. It was called like Garden Train or something like that. 

I thought there were some beautiful flowers that you could smell inside. Although they don't have a great variety, it's still nice to see them in their natural habitat and it's great to be a little warm and take off that jacket inside the Conservatory - afterall it is a greenhouse. It's like a little summer during winter!
author: Nina Y.

description:
We had our wedding at the Conservatory of Flowers in September. The venue was unbelievable and the price was great. 

We were thrilled when we found out there would be a dinosaur exhibit during our wedding, it added such a fun touch to the day. The Orchid room was perfect for our reception and the executive restrooms were a hit.

The one disappointing part was that one week before our wedding all of the flowers beds in front of the Conservatory were taken out. I understand that the gardens are managed by Golden Gate Park and not the Conservatory, but we were not told they were removed before our wedding. We showed up for our rehearsal and there were no flowers. Luckily, guests didn't seem to notice as much as we did. 

Beautiful venue and very happy to have gotten married there!
author: Andie L.

description:
Love it! This is definitely one of SF's "hidden secrets" that mosts people don't know, or want to know about. I'm not a botanist nor did I get a 5 on the Bio AP exam, so I know absolutely nothing about the plant world. However, each species has an informative sign in front of it an walking through the entire conservatory, glancing at each sign, could easily take an hour or two. 

They did offer a guided tour and the guide (volunteer) had a lot of knowledge and background and could answer the groups questions. I spent most of my take taking photos - the highlight of my trip. There's actually a large patch of flowers right outside of the conservatory, on the left if you're facing JFK drive if you don't want to purchase tickets.

Tickets are fairly cheap, but when we did pay for the tickets and walked into the conservatory, there was no one at the door collecting them. I assume the people in front of us didn't pay at all and walked in for free. It probably isn't the best place for kids either.
author: Kevin L.

description:
The wicked plant exhibit at the Conservatory of Flowers is killer! Literally! 
Can't believe it took me 9 years to get here. Shame on me because I'm a gardener.  This is a must if you even own a house plant on the windowsill.
author: Roger H.

description:
My family has been coming here long before even my mother was a twinkle in her parents' eyes, and it still looks exactly the same -- after fires, earthquakes, and storms.  Stepping into the Conservatory is like walking into a Victorian postcard.  I'd be hard-pressed to think of a prettier building within the city, to say nothing of the exotic contents.

I remember coming here as a child during the holidays, and seeing the west wing of the building completely filled with poinsettias, but now the holiday exhibits are tiny railroads through slices of San Francisco history.  Last year: Playland at the Beach!  This year: The Barbary Coast (and I can't wait to see it).  The attention to detail and the ability to capture an atmosphere through plants and props is remarkable.  It's hard to take a bad photo here.

If only they would bring the Carnival of Color exhibit back -- with the carousel horses and huge lanterns -- I would be more than happy to walk through that again. In the meantime, I'll always have my photos.
author: Jennie K.

description:
This is a fun activity to do while near Golden Gate Park. It costs $8 which is a little expensive for how long it takes to look in every room (as an adult without children with us!). It is $5 for San Francisco residents. I'd say we were in and out in about an hour. All the rooms are super cool with different climates and plant species. TONS of stuff to look at. The butterfly room/exhibit is of course the most interesting with lots of varying butterflies flying around. Wear shoes that you don't mind getting wet because the grounds are permanently soaked with the constant watering and spraying of the plants. Also wear leayers because although it might be cold in SF certain rooms are SUPER humid and damp. Good for the plant..not so good for my hair. Mostly families and children but anyone could enjoy this place. 

In general a fun time! I recommend sitting in the park first and having a pre-plant and butterfly viewing cocktail or glass of wine..providing you're an adult of course!
author: Erika B.

description:
Beautiful! A little $$$ at $8/adult but it was a neat experience. 
It was nice to WARM UP in too!
author: Stefanie R.

description:
If you love flowers and plantlife (and if you don't love nature, like me), then this controlled environment filled with exotic flora and fauna is the perfect place!  Great for a photo op as well!

$5 general admission, $3 student, FREE on the first Tuesday of every month.  If you're coming from Union Square by bus, take the #5 on Market Street by the GAP and get off at Arguello and Fulton.

On my visit, I got to see tons of beautiful orchids and the special Golden Gate Express exhibit.  I LOVE looking at all the different leaves and greens.  I noted to my friends how it must be a wonderful life as a caterpillar to be able to munch on and explore these bright green plants and then turn into a beautiful butterfly and fly away! :D  Haha.  Anyone see A Bug's Life?  Heimlich!!  Heehee...

REALLY humid in the lotus room (one on the very right end) and the lens of your camera WILL fog up.

The special exhibit was so cool! Famous SF landmarks made out of things like buttons, rulers, beads, cassette tapes, corks and stuff.  Make sure to see it before it's gone mid-April.
author: Ruth C.

description: This place is smaller than I had imagined and we went through the entire place in about 15 min. There are 3-4 rooms with exotic plants, and a final one at the end with live butterflies. For an admission price of $7 it's not bad, but I was expecting more. The place is pretty much a giant greenhouse with plants inside. Dress lightly though because it was really hot inside! I would recommend this to anyone that likes plants/flowers but I don't think I would return...it just wasn't for me.
author: Brian P.

description: This is a fun and interesting place filled with flowers and plants from many different Eco-systems. There are the upper and lower rain forests, and water plants, and even a very cool butterfly house. The place is filled with info, stories, and lots of orchids - the best thing about the giant house. It is in central Golden Gate Park in SF, so there is lots to see in the park as well.
author: Jeffrey K.

description:
Good "bang for the buck" compared to many other botanical gardens and while the collection is somewhat small the "Wicked Plants" exhibit was quite interesting from a scientific standpoint while the old Victorian Era greenhouse itself is quite eye catching as well.

Having been to a number of greenhouses and gardens in my travels this certainly is not the best of the best, but for $8 it is a great way to spend a couple hours and the orchid exhibit is quite nicely done.
author: Michael U.

description:
Cute exhibits, very nicely designed and pretty.  Seems they change them up and add new things here and there, having different special exhibits.  Very cool building.

Their exhibit on "Wicked Plants" right now is neat, very antique vibe with cool music and interesting sound effects but in not too hokey of a way.

Only thing: be prepared to sweat.  This place is quite warm.

It's a $5-7 sauna...with nice plants as a bonus.
author: Kes D.

description:
A nice place to stop by on your visit to Golden Gate Park.  The historic glass building looks bigger in a picture than when you actually get close by, so don't expect to spend the entire day here.  Depending on your interest of plants and flowers, plan on spending 45-90 min here.  

Walking from section to section with different temperature and humidity is pretty cool.  During my visit, they had a special exhibit of butterflies which was nice.
author: トモ T.

description:
I came here on a Saturday to put my camera to use.  The Butterfly exhibit has been extended so i was super excited!  

It was VERY humid in there, each room at a different level.  But it's for the plants, so i can deal.  There were so many gorgeous orchids!  Such a wide variety of plants, flowers and trees.

The Butterflies were amazing!  You walk into this room and they are all just flying about!  I had one land in my hair and hung out there for a while.  It stayed there until the lady was able to get a picture for me.. then it flew off.  Thanks little butterfly!  The lady (docent?) at the exhibit was very nice, conversational and helpful! 

I like having a place i can go to with my camera and walk around at my own leisure taking photographs for my personal enjoyment (i do not do commercial photography).  This is one place that was perfect for that.  I got a lot of great shots, and would be happy to come back again as the season changes.

i'll probably go back at least one more time while the butterflies are still there.  :)

Also, the Dahlia Garden is just to the right of the Conservatory.. another great place for some macro shots.  Full blooms of various dahlias, very colorful and very beautiful!
author: Char B.

description: The place is actually quite small. From the photos that I saw online I thought this place would be ginormous! But this place is really great, there's a lot of variety with the plants. I highly enjoyed the different atmosphere every room has to offer. The gift shop was quite lacking so don't expect to get good souvenirs. But really all in all this place is beautiful.
author: Vivia D.

description:
We redeemed our 2 for 1 groupon last week and also visited the Japanese Tea Garden 1/4 mile up within GG park.

There were many people including a group of preschool kids and parents on an outing.  You're not supposed to pick the flowers in the various flowerbeds on the lawn; however, the kids were trampling the flowers and even picking them!

Couldn't help but chuckle at the chaos.

Inside, it's broken out into four separate galleries of tropical plants, orchids, and a special exhibit gallery.  When you first enter, it feels like a sauna; but then you acclimate to the humidity of the place.

You'll recognize many of your houseplants but in extreme mass and size.

Your admission ticket is good for same day in & out privileges.  There's public restrooms adjacent to the building, and a permanent snack kiosk in front.

Note:  the first Tuesday of the month is free admission.
author: Shirley N.

description:
My dad swears I've been to the CoF as a kid, but I didn't remember it, so it's been on my bucket list for a while.  I can see now why I didn't remember it.  Sorta underwhelming.  It's 5 small galleries of plants and flowers, including quite a few orchids.  It's nice, and relatively cheap to get in, and you'll probably find a few things to marvel at like the giant waterlilies.  My 11yo son was most interested in the few food related plants - cocoa, bananas, cinnamon, etc.  You should go if you are in the area, especially if it's a cool day outside...but it's not something I'd go too far out of my way for.
