An extra 1/2 star for the sweet, sweet docent working the front door.  Easily walkable from the Academy of Sciences, DeYoung, Japanese Tea Garden, etc.

Unfortunately the current dinosaur "exhibit" (and I use that term loosely) is a dud.  If your kid likes dinosaurs the best part of it is the dino head sticking up through the top that can be viewed from outside.
author: Linda M.

description: It was a ok place to stop by. I had very bad allergy so this wasn't the place for me. I went in for 10 minutes and had to leave because the pollen was so overpowering. Lot of very interesting flowers and plants. If you like flowers, please stop by.
author: Jenny L.

description:
OMFG! PLANT HEAVEN!! Okay, seriously, I wish I can just make love to a freakin' tropical plant already. Everything here was just screaming at me. 

I totally get why people grow old and take up gardening as a hobby now. Screw watching the television when you can "watch" something much more beautiful and interesting!! 

I mean, seriously, they were exhibiting carnivorous plants during my visit. These plants EAT bugs for a living. Am I trippin' or is that cool as f*ck?!

A lot of these plants are tropical, meaning, they absolutely and positively MUST live in a humid, yet wet habitat. In this conservatory, we're living in THEIR world, not ours. That is AMAZING!
author: Frances T.

description:
I was not having the greatest of days.  I started out in the morning to go the Conservatory of Flowers, but a combination of trains that never showed up, missed connections, and wrong turns delayed my arrival.  I never quite got around to eating.  By the time I did finally make it there, several hours later than planned, I was stressed and frustrated and I had a headache.

Within 30 seconds of arriving, my headache was gone.

The Conservatory of Flowers houses an amazing collection of plants and flowers and other horticultural wonders nestled in a beautiful, tranquil environment.   I spent at least an hour, wandering the various galleries, taking in the sights and scents and the fabulous (lack of) sound.  So peaceful and so relaxing.

When I was there (a while back), the special exhibit was "Wicked Plants," a variety of poisonous plants and other "botanical atrocities," displayed in a Victorian setting.  So interesting and so fun!

Next time I am fortunate enough to find myself back in the magnificent City by the Bay, I'll definitely be making a return trip to the Conservatory of Flowers.
author: Elena M.

description:
There's plenty of flower here at the Conservatory. Small ones, large ones and all of them colorful. It's a small conservatory, there's only four rooms but they are densely packed with a wide variety of plants and flowers. 

If you take your time and examine each plant and flower you can be here a couple of hours. I like to take a couple of rounds  each time I come here since it always seems I miss a flower or two or the plant I really want to see is being blocked by a photographer taking their sweet time.
author: JD R.

description: A further reason why Golden Gate Park is one of the best -- lots of amazing tropical flowers and a stellar exhibit overall. Definitely recommend!
author: Mel G.

description: Waste of time really. We took a 20 dollar cab ride to see three small rooms of plants. Your time would be better spent walking the parks / neighborhoods.
author: Ryan N.

description:
The Conservatory of Flowers is one of the cheapest things to do in GG Park.  A living museum where you can check out some rare plants and warm up on a chilly day.  

With the horticultural staff always rotating in the most dramatic plants there's always something new to see.  Plus the plants that are permanent fixtures often change through the seasons.  

Lately the COF has also been hosting a bunch of cool events ranging from stuff for kids on weekends to Nights at the Conservatory (usually on Thurs) for a 21+ crowd.
author: Matthew M.

description: Come check them out! I really enjoyed their selection of carnivorous plants as well as other varieties of the plant kingdom. I thought that the place is very well preserved with nice staff who were also very helpful and knowledgeable. Make sure you stop by and ask for the tour.
author: J C.

description:
I went to the Jill Tracy & Paul Mercer concert last night inside the Orchid Pavilion at The Conservatory. What a terrific venue! My husband and I got to enjoy all of the lush and beautiful plants and flowers while sipping an adult beverage after hours. We then indulged in a decadent chocolate tasting by the lovely ladies of Vice Chocolates from Oakland.  Next, we sampled rich, varied and compelling scented oils from Nocturne Alchemy.  I purchased an intoxicating combination of amber and vanilla called eternal Ankh and I look forward to its scent adorning me daily. 
 All this was followed by the incredibly talented Mercer and Tracy. I have appreciated the gorgeous natural beauty at the Conservatory for many years and always recommend it to visitors. This was my first concert experience at that location and now I recommend it to you!
author: Rayleen W.

description:
This was the feature of our Veterans Day morning in SF, and it was a nice visit. It's basically a greenhouse with a facade, but it's only $7 for standard adult admission. There's a lot of flowers from different parts of the world, and the tropical-like conditions of some rooms was also enjoyable on a relatively cool SF morning. I also enjoyed the SF Giants-themed arrangements on the slope outside. One of them said "SF Champs" and was clearly done after the World Series win! Definitely got pics of those in addition to much of the flora inside.

The one star off is because there just wasn't a huge abundance of flowers. That's understandable due to the time of year, but I still wanted to see more flowers overall.
author: Chris V.

description:
A truly magical place located in beautiful Golden Gate Park. Love all the different climates, each with its own array of vibrant, exotic, well-cared-for flowers. Very relaxing and uplifting. The Playland exhibit was smaller than I anticipated but was still quite fun! Definitely check this place out if you're in the area and don't forget your camera! 

P.S. If you present your Cali ID you get a discounted rate!
author: Leigh W.

description:
This place is incredible! The location is the middle of it all - so it can easily be a vital part of a day long trek through golden gate park. I like the way that they have the entire exhibit arranged. I was, however, a bit shocked by the lack of variety in their flowers. Yes, they do have more than 200+ blooming flowers! That's really awesome - but considering some conservatories in Chicago (lesser known) have more variety, I was expecting more. The flowers are beautiful - however, they do show more Orchids than any other flower. Beautiful, regardless. 

I think I'm going to go again next week. It was that awesome!
author: Jane E.

description:
At $7 for a 25-minute visit, it's not the best bang for your travel buck, but the Conservatory has two exceptional things:
1. They have the best collection of insect-eating plants I've seen.
2. Although I've been to places with more orchids, they have the most unique collection I've seen.
The rest of the greenhouse is rather ordinary. Basically, there isn't much to see here, but what there is to see is outstanding.

Like the Olympics, they take Visa (and MasterCard), but not American Express.
author: Brian U.

description:
A tropical oasis at Golden Gate Park housing exotic plants and flowers.

Flowers mocking the male and female genitalia in their subliminal beauties.  (Don't tell me I have a dirty mind.  Nature is sexual, intriguing and beautiful at the same time.)http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/TRN1vdp0-og9M-3AgKmZZg?select=G9RtWK6n7kiDbkoHuBlC1g

Male:http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/TRN1vdp0-og9M-3AgKmZZg?select=wFwT3ZAVWSm7dt6eXAMCyw
Female:http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/TRN1vdp0-og9M-3AgKmZZg?select=fIDFWt-BeerOXdhj8uiGvQ
A nice day for a quick but informative and enjoyable leisurely walk through the Victorian greenhouse.  Humid at 85 degrees because of the kind of plants it was cultivating.  

Beautiful exotic flowers including orchids and roses native to hotter climates some dating to Victorian times.  A beautiful huge pond in one of the rooms where water lilies peek out of the water like in a fairy tale book.  Natural bright light. 

My mom and dad enjoyed their visit although my parents who are from the Philippines kept on saying, "We have those growing  in the Philippines."  I guess exotic for others are common for some.http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/TRN1vdp0-og9M-3AgKmZZg?select=Z6XvIuLGImt3DQ4bmeDPWg

It was a beautiful and relaxing morning. Great for people watching or sitting on the beautiful spacious well-tended lawn in front of the Conservatory.  A must-visit in Golden Gate Park if you are in SF.

$  5.00 for adults
$  3.00 for seniors and students.
author: Leah E.

description: Very very cool carnivorous plants exhibit try have going on right now. The whole place is kinda on the smaller side, but it's HOT. Easy way to get out of the chilly San Fran wind. Don't forget your student ID like I did. It'll save you two bucks.
author: Mindy E.

description:
If you have ever seen pictures of San Francisco, one of the most beautiful and haunting things is the ghostly white palace that is the Conservatory of Flowers.  Iconic from the outside ; and on the inside, a beautiful tropical oasis.

Being a native to the bay area I wanted to find the perfect place for my wedding.  After looking at various spots from around the city, we decided on the Conservatory.  

Everything was perfect.  The venue, already filled with luscious plants and exotic flowers it doesn't need decorating.  Our wedding day in July was misty, cold and foggy, but our guests walked into the vestibule and entered into a different world.  There was room for people to wander and enjoy but not so big that people got lost.  There is an event tent nestled off to the side that you don't notice when wandering in the park, but is a great space that can be transformed into just about anything.  

Morgan, the Special Events Manager was great.  She was helpful in working with us and our vendors and making sure that our questions were answered.  We found out months in advance what special exhibit would be up during our wedding (it was the Wicked Plants - poisonous plants in a Victorian setting, we loved it).   

We even got a chance to see the Conservatory at night.  Night time inside the Conservatory is dark with accent lights, the sound of crickets and slightly humid and warm which you never get in San Francisco.  This was one of the most magical things we suggested to all of our guests to experience at some point during the reception.  

If planning a wedding or other event is not in your future, do find a reason to go to one of their after hour programs - or go to the Gala in November - always fun and supports the Conservatory.
author: Jeanie M.

description: Plants were beautiful, but it was busy and honestly took less than an hour. Didn't seem worth the $8 admission. Was hoping for a docent tour or something to make the experience a richer one.
author: Amy C.

description: REALLY enjoyed my time at the Conservatory of Flowers. The flowers were beautiful and our docent led a very interesting tour. If you are interested in plans or photo ops this is a good place to pop into.
author: Carlos A.

description: Really really cool. Lots of orchids, bromeliads, and other wonderful flora. Now through April 2015, they have a special exhibit on freshwater aquascaping with a dozen planted aquariums. Must see!
author: Don S.

description: I'll give this place a solid 3-stars. The conservatory is on the smaller side (the Brooklyn botanical gardens are WAY bigger, and that's my point of reference), and the cost of admission was $8/person, which seems a lot for something that we were in and out of in less than 10 minutes. The orchids were pretty, but the "predator plants" exhibit that was happening at the time left a lot to be desired.  Definitely something I could forgo on my next trip to San Francisco.
author: Courtney S.

description:
I love this place! 
Just walking by is a treat. Be sure to check out the Dalhia garden outside next to the building during the summer months. It has breathtakingly beautiful flowers. I honestly didn't know that flowers could be that large and colorful in real life. It is like they jumped out of a child's imagination into reality. So pretty. If you go early in the morning (or any day when the fog is still hovering over the plants) each flower will be covered in dew drops. *sigh* so pretty.

Inside the Conservatory is just a breathtaking. Each room has a different theme. I would caution against going on a particularly hot day because this IS a green house and it can get VERY hot and humid. So it is nice to be greeted by a cool breeze when you exit. Be sure to stop by the lily pond in the side wing and the orchid display in the adjoining room. If you love plants and flowers you will go crazy here. If you are so-so about flowers you will still like it, there are so many rare and beautiful things it is hard not to enjoy it.
author: Krystal W.

description:
I like plants a lot so I was surprised not to enjoy my trip to the Conservatory of Flowers. Actually, other than all the orchids everywhere there weren't many flowers inside. Just orchids and palms. I did enjoy seeing some of the spice plants. 

A large factor for me was the cramped feeling. The building is too small for the plants and trees it contains with narrow corridors clogged with people. If someone stopped to take a photo I would have to squeeze to get past them. There should be enough space for people to stop and enjoy the plants and for people to continue walking through. 

The botanical gardens close by are far more interesting to me. There are more varieties of plants, more flowers blooming, and much more space.
author: Grush K.

description:
Full of plants, very big and very small.  Orchids named "Dracula"?  Tropical rooms as hot as saunas?  Carnivorous plants?  Strange strange flowers?

Lots of things to see and learn.  An enjoyable serene walk through a variety of the planet's green things.
author: Don B.

description: The BEST site at Golden Gate Park.  Beautiful and serene, this is a must when in the area!
author: Virginia C.

description: This isn't a fair review because I haven't been inside, but the outside is beautiful! I pass by this place on my runs/walks through the park and I've even studied outside on the grass. First Tuesday of the month is free!
author: Leana L.

description:
So beautiful.  We saw the wicked plants exhibit today.  Crazy shit there!  

Only $5 for residents w/a valid id or bill.  $7 for non-residents.

Well maintained, nice staff, cool plants.
author: Alex T.

description:
- I DO NOT LIKE IT.
- $5 (Students), $7 (Adults)
- Conservatory of "FLOWERS". The title really throw you off because this place is FULL of plants, NOT flowers. I saw a lot of flower pictures on yelp so I thought it's a place of flowers. Sure they did have flowers but only one here and there.
- The only nice part is the special exhibit from now - April 18th.
- I walked through 3 different exhibits and it's different environment in each one. 
- NOT RECOMMENDED TO GO IN THE SUMMER or during hot days. One of the exhibits was freaking hot and humid.
author: Phung D.

description:
I finally made it over to this area of Golden Gate park this past weekend to enjoy the museum and all this gems the park has to offer, including the Conservatory of Flowers. I really enjoyed this place, it's very beautiful and the flowers in season there right now are orchids, which I love!

I'm only giving it 4 stars because although $7 to get in is pretty cheap, I expected more to see. There was only 3 or 4 rooms to walk through and I did it in 10 minutes. The plants are all tropical so it's pretty humid in here, but again you won't be in there for long. The de Young Museum was only $10 and that took an hour to go through. The Dahlia Garden to the right of the Conservatory of Flowers was awesome! They are both must sees at least once.
author: Brenna S.

description:
Victorian style conservatory, amazing natural light and gorgeous flowers? Hello?!?! Who wouldn't like this place?

Best $5 I've ever spent. I'll let my photos speak for itself.
author: Mona L.

description:
$7 well spent.
It's hot inside. This is important to know because it's usually cold in SF so as always dress in layers so you can peel them all off before entering.

5 "rooms" filled with interesting and beautiful plants!
I am sure I missed half exhibit because I did it in about an hour. 
If you like flowers and all things green you will love this place.

Don't miss the Dalia's outside- they are amazing. The shapes, colors and sizes are like candy for the eyes!

Many photo ops here if you are a tourist.

My only criticism is of the outdoor cactus area...come on! Cacti are so varied and interesting but it seems like they only had the basics
author: Edi B.

description:
Every first Tuesday of the month, you can get into the Conservatory for free. There would be no reason for me to go otherwise. 

There wasn't as big of a selection for flowers as I thought there would be, but beyond the gift shop was the carnivorous plant section. I've owned a Venus fly trap before and know a little bit about the types of carnivorous plants, but it was still a beautiful sight to see and imagine how the plants would be in their natural habitat.
author: April K.

description:
A real hidden gem in San Francisco.  It's definitely a quick visit, you can probably stretch it to 45 minutes.  There are different climate zones, lots of explanation, really neat plants to look at, some cool historical photos in the entryway, and great special exhibits including the wonderful train exhibit that's there until March.  This special exhibit is really fun, and includes a section made of recycled objects including old buttons, cassette tapes and what have you.

Though small, it keeps the kiddies entertained - our toddler requests visits on a regular basis.  A great way to instill appreciation of nature in the little ones.
author: Katy M.

description: Ill keep this review brief as I can only echo what many others have stated prior.  The Conservatory of Flowers  is expansive and impressive and quite easy to get to by many forms of transportation in the city.  The CoF houses a collection of rare flora which spans from simple foliage plants to rare orchids to bog and pond species.  If you are fan of visiting Conservatories, then this one must be on your bucket list.  They have neatly divided up the various wings to control the environmentals to support and encourage the plants to grow as if in their native habitats.  They do offer a guided tour which you can join at no extra charge if you arrive at the right times or you can choose to browse around solo.  I found the tour informative as the guide knew a lot about the history of the plantings but afterwards, I lingered to photograph some of the great items in the collection.  Cheers.
author: G M.

description:
I'm going to tell you right now that I think that plants are dead sexy.  The more exotic, the better - they showcase their colors and naughty bits like nobody's business.  And I like it.

So, I decided to join my friends for a walk on the wild side with the Chomp exhibit.  

On the approach to the Conservatory, you definitely feel like you are in Kew Gardens, which is what it was modeled after.  It was constructed in 1878 and is the oldest building in GG Park.  I've been to Kew, and I have to say that the plants in our conservatory are healthier than theirs.  It is fair to say that the structure looks huge from the outside, but is pretty contained on the inside.  Still, she is a grand Victorian lady with a world of wonders underneath her skirt.

Note that it is humid inside and strollers must be left at the door.  On a cold and cloudy day like today, feeling the moist, warm air was a welcome sensation.  Yes, I said moist.  And just like in a high-end strip club, you may look all you want but NO TOUCHING.  

The inside is divided into sections, such as Lowland Tropicals and Aquatic Plants.  There are descriptive signs and docents available to give explanation about the origin of the various species.  

To really enjoy the offerings here, make your eye like a zoom lens and look close.  Focus.  Look closer.  The architecture of nature is amazing.  The flirtatious flutter of a petal and the beckoning curve of a stamen serve the purpose of drawing you in, just like a happy little bee.  (see photos)

Don't miss the display case of found exotic items to see the double coconut that looks just like an ass.  Or whatever you see, I'm not going to put any ideas in your head.

The Chomp exhibit is not full of giant Little Shop of Horrors man-eaters.  The carnivorous plants are small, but nonetheless interesting.  Attach yourself to a docent and learn about what they do, and how they do it. 

It doesn't take long to walk through, and a ticket is $5.00.  A picnic on the lawn is a nice way to supplement your visit.
 
It's appropriate for anyone of any age, and good, clean fun.  Well....that really depends on your imagination, doesn't it? ;)
author: Liz S.

description:
a gem. one of my favorite spots in san francisco. 

it was a very cold day when i went, and was greeted by an adorable elderly woman who was handing out a map and eager to help with any questions. right after we paid (students get a discount!) we walked into the shabby-chic building and were greeted by thick, warm air. 

we stripped off our beanies, coats, and under jackets (we are from southern cali) and entered into an oasis in the middle of golden gate park. 

the air felt fresh, being surrounded by so much green and life. the humidity and heat was exactly what i craved at that moment, and being granted it rose my spirits. 

you go there to look at plants. what our mother earth has provided as something natural and beautiful, and to admire them. there are 5 different rooms, and each one has its own charm and temperature. i went on a day where there weren't that many people... i would imagine my experience would be hindered if there were more people there. 

it helped me reflect, appreciate, and slow down. it was a perfect end to my perfect trip to san francisco. we walked down the street to get some VERY affordable and DELICIOUS high-tea at Rose Tea (something i would highly recommend to anyone with the morning off and heading to the conservatory of flowers).

if you like flowers and plants and want to slow life down and take in natural beauty, please go. it's beautiful.
author: Ava M.

description: stunning. i've lived in sf my entire life and i just came here recently. the outside was spectacular! and i love how there are so many beautiful flowers planted before you even walk up the stairs. too bad they were closed at 4pm. :( btw, sf residence - it's only $5 to get in with a valid id of course.
author: Ann T.

description:
This spectacular living museum is housed in one of the largest green houses I've ever seen. The Conservatory of Flowers opened in 1879 and has since been home to rare and beautiful tropical plants that include orchids, palms and more. Located in Golden Gate Park, it is impossible to miss this amazing example of Victorian architecture nestled in the greenery near the Children's playground and just short walk from the DeYoung Museum. 

Take your train fans there between now and April 19 to enjoy the Golden Gate Express Garden Railway. Model G-gauge trains wind their way through a lush landscape of dwarf plants and steam past mini versions of the city's landmark buildings. You'll see some very creative replicas of famous San Francisco landmarks like Mission Dolores, the Golden Gate Bridge, Coit Tower and Chinatown's dragon gate made from recycled utensils, cassette tapes, mahjong tiles and computer parts. My kids had a great time trying to spot all of the items on the buildings that had prior lives before appearing here.  They even competed to see who could find the most.  Now that's artsy recycling! 

The Conservatory is open Tuesday - Sunday, 9am - 4:30pm (last entry is at 4:30pm, Visitors must leave the Conservatory by 5pm) 

Admission is: 
$5.00 for Adults 
$3.00 for Youth 12-17, Seniors 65 & over, and Students with ID 
$1.50 for Children 5 - 11 
FREE for Children 4 and under 
The Conservatory is free to all visitors on the first Tuesday of every month. 

For more info, go to: http://www.conservatoryofflowers.org
author: Kristine D.

description: This is a wonderful place in the heart of Golden Gate Park!  I had taken my grandma here and we came at the best time.  They had an exhibit of dahlias and I think that they are now, my most fave flower.  They are absolutely gorgeous and have such a range of varieties.  It's not a huge place which is actually good because my grandma can't be on her feet for too long but it just has these incredibly interesting plants and flowers that I was in awe.  I think I took a picture of just about everything growing!
author: Jen S.

description:
After leaving the stampede conditions at the Chihuly exhibit at the De Young this weekend, I strolled past the Conservatory of Flowers and decided to go inside. It was hot and sunny out, I had been on my feet for hours, and the sign said butterflies. 

The landscaping out front was covered with wedding parties doing photographs. It's a very San Francisco backdrop I suppose, but as I watched more than one bride hike up her skirts to get better leverage on the Bear's Breeches, my own resolve to elope in Reno (not vegas) some day was solidified.

The conservatory of flowers is the oldest public conservatory in the US, opened in the late 1800s. Thus it's more than a place to see plants; its tropicle jungle species crawl and bloom history. While not large, the old victorian structure is just beautiful, and strolling along the walkways between all the ancient and new plants it's easy to imagine people from all era's enjoying it here. It also has an Adams Family quality and could be a great setting for a man-eating plant story. Displayed notes from long-ago botanists, their specimens, and cases of indigenous plants add to the sense of science and adventure that's gone into this place for such a long time.

It was a hot day so the tropical environment inside was initially a little rough, but the moisture of the Amazon-type jungle helped. I've never seen such strange and beautiful orchids, and there were plenty of peaceful places to sit and rest. I did not see any butterflies; someone said it was too hot. Initially I thought it would be too stifling to stay long but even if you don't know anything about plants, the more time you spend the more interesting little things you'll notice blooming in the nooks and crannies. There weren't a ton of things blooming on first impression, but then I started noticing the green flowers and some super exotic blossoms which were camouflaged more like alien forest creatures. Wow! Read about the Amazon lilly, which invites hoardes of beetles in for a snack and closes on them while they perform sex change surgery on it!

If you're expecting a super slick highly funded exquisite botanical museum I'd say you need to ratchet your expectations, but it's apparent people have loved this place for nearly 150 years, and that some of the plants may have memories that long of their own.
author: Roxmarie M.

description:
Beautiful wedding location.  Staff is extremely helpful and professional.  Tourists kept commenting on how incredible it was to see a wedding taking place.  

The surrounding gardens, white exterior, and botanical theme provides a perfect backdrop for a wedding.  And if you're into flowers, there's not a more suitable place.  Also, a place like this gives guests lots to do and soak up in the downtime moments.

As a photographer its great to have such a wide variety of places to take the couple within walking distance.  Logistically it makes things a lot easier to be creative.  The new banquet hall area in the back/side area is suited for larger groups.  It had just opened up and ours was the very first wedding to be held in there.  Check out this slideshow:

www.MauriceRamirez.com/StaceyJeffreyWedding

One downside is its hours, since its open to the public for the day the weddings are limited to after-hours.  Which is not a limitation for summer hours but means that things get a bit chilly in the winter.
author: Maurice R.

description: Well, this place is basically a greenhouse that has tons of flowers.  My fav section would have to be the orchids.  My dad loved this place since he got to use his camera for great shots.  Admission is decent price and conveniently located to all the other museums in Golden Gate Park.
author: Phillip Y.

description: I cannot say enough good things about how absolutely amazing the Conservatory of Flowers is!  A GEM and a treasure of San Francisco. I don't think people stop enough to smell the rose.. and orchids and bromeliads and lotuses and....  I come here to find peace and serenity with nature when life gets a lil hectic.  My favorite rooms are the highland tropics and aquatic rooms. I love all the unique and truly stunning high altitude orchids and ferns crawling on the trees.  The aquatics room features pools that flow into each other with giant Amazon water lilies floating on the surface. This is an absolute must see for all visitors and Bay Area residents alike!
author: P.J. D.

description:
It's amazing how one can fully sustain such arrays of flowers and plants in one small greenhouse.  For someone like me who does not have the green thumb, I stand in great appreciation.  

Entrance is truly reasonable.  $7 for adults, $2 ages 5-11 and free for children under 4.  So why wouldn't you want to come visit this place?  Know what plants commonly grow in your area, get to learn their names and natural habitats.

There weren't many flowers blooming when we visited.  That big pink hibiscus really caught our eyes.  And that coconut in the glass box was just funny.  My daughter asked, "Mama, why did they put a butt there?".

I just wish they would do something about some of the information boards.  The letters are starting to fade and it's harder to read them.

The "train" room was the highlight of the day as far as my kids were concerned.  They enjoyed watching and waiting for the trains.  Thomas the tank engine was even one of them.  The train sets featured San Francisco landmarks made from materials we would have thrown away.  So creative!  They used cereal boxes, cds, tapes, buttons, chopsticks etc. to make something beautiful like the golden gate bridge or the coit tower.  We enjoyed naming all the materials they had used.

I'm glad for places like this.  A fun way to spend a day with the family.
author: Pam S.

description:
[M]ona: 5 Stars
[W]ayne: 4 Stars
Average: 4.5 Stars

+ Inexpensive
+ Discounts
+ Over 100 Years Old
+ Great Place for Picnics
+ Easy to find Parking

- Closes early (4pm)
- Hot Inside the Greenhouse

[W] We came to check out this place today because Mona had pre-purchased some tickets for us. The only thing about the conservatory is that this place closes quite early. I believe we got there at around 3:10 and they closed at 4. It wasn't too bad because the greenhouse was only about 4-5 rooms wide so you can easily walk it in less than an hour. I guess they had a "Chomp" exibition [http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/TRN1vdp0-og9M-3AgKmZZg?select=X38-VcqPImjX3e0oRSKKkw] that featured fry trap flowers. [http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/TRN1vdp0-og9M-3AgKmZZg?select=8FAX4TG6g_AlAUhMSToWng]

What's really nice about this place is that they have a beautiful lawn outside the greenhouse where you can just picnic or just tan and relax. They have several beds of flowers spread around the field and the upkeep of this place is really nice. It does have "no dogs allowed" signs everywhere and I wasn't surprised because they had those little beds of flowers set up around the lawn so the animals might run into it or eat it up and whatnot. [http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/TRN1vdp0-og9M-3AgKmZZg?select=Q9wLwCLxyliYAgyJhDZxQw]
[http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/TRN1vdp0-og9M-3AgKmZZg?select=c4bY2DSNAFEWgr2C5MIz0Q]

One thing to be prepared about this place is that the humidity of the greenhouse is pretty bad. It's great for the flowers but bad for us haha. Each separate room is themed accordingly. One room would be a tropical rain forest and another might be like Appalachian type flowers. I'm not a flower power guy at all so I wasn't too sure what I was looking at but I do have to say that the greenery was really beautiful and even I could enjoy beauty of everything. [http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/TRN1vdp0-og9M-3AgKmZZg?select=QExzi01cre5x1pI8HsoIlQ] [http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/TRN1vdp0-og9M-3AgKmZZg?select=iViSYrwPAPxuADI0QbNlfw] [http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/TRN1vdp0-og9M-3AgKmZZg?select=muQ9wvdS6ZkW4DSBjvktAw] [http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/TRN1vdp0-og9M-3AgKmZZg?select=StdVfIx6mbqDb-HmJyLJAQ] [http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/TRN1vdp0-og9M-3AgKmZZg?select=yW6kHHFEJq1kC2dWwHx6kg] [http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/TRN1vdp0-og9M-3AgKmZZg?select=kr75x9o28JEWSb8OlJzihg] [http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/TRN1vdp0-og9M-3AgKmZZg?select=K-WT-5khdJiUuf3fsvxdtg] [http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/TRN1vdp0-og9M-3AgKmZZg?select=hDzYA33g1SYmrLbnEYD__w] It was really cool to see some of the fly traps and read about how they work. [http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/TRN1vdp0-og9M-3AgKmZZg?select=ys_rRAnqzy3pqlX2HMUzJw]

For a novice like me, I really learned a couple of things just by reading some of their posters with descriptions of particular flowers. Like how the fly traps don't really "eat" only flies but ants and small bugs as well. It pretty much digests the bugs with it's liquids and that's how it feeds. All you flower people out there are like "he's got it soooooo wrong" haha. Anyways again the humidity was not comfortable for me at all but at least I had a chance to experience something nice that I would never stop to take the time to look at.

Overall experience was pleasant other than the humidity in the greenhouse. I got to see some cool and weird looking flowers. Parking was available everywhere on the streets and it was good for 4 hours I believe. If you have time afterwards, enjoy the park a little because there are hiking trails and just beautiful scenery altogether. [http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/TRN1vdp0-og9M-3AgKmZZg?select=c4bY2DSNAFEWgr2C5MIz0Q]

[M] ADMISSION PRICES FOR US RESIDENTS (w/ proof) 
~ Adults: $5.00
~ Seniors (65 & over): $3.00
~ Students w/ ID: $3.00
~ Youth (12 - 17): $3.00
~ Children (5 - 11): $1.50
~ Children (4 & under): FREE
[http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/TRN1vdp0-og9M-3AgKmZZg?select=YAMvBzqqUPQGr9nAN3EnwA]
author: Mona C.

description:
It's really just a treat to have something like this over in Golden Gate Park. I think the walk to the Conservatory is really relaxing.

Once inside, you get to explore the plants and you feel like you're one with nature :)

If you're not familiar with certain horticulture, it's okay because once you get to the main event (in my case, it was the carnivorous plants) you'll learn quite a bit simply by reading their stories.

I had no idea that Abraham Lincoln's mother died of a white snakeroot! Crazy!

ps: it can get hot inside so make sure you've layered your clothes
author: Eric A.

description:
I went today because it was the monthly free day (first Tuesday of the month--otherwise it's $5). Unlike many other places that have free days, the Conservatory closely monitors how many people are inside at any given time, so it's never very crowded. This does mean you might have to wait a few minutes, but given that there were probably 40 people in front of me (including a camp group of 20 or so middle-schoolers), my 15-minute wait was very reasonable.

Inside, there is so much to see. There are five rooms: one for special exhibits (right now, it's butterflies--more on that later); another which highlights seasonally potted plants, such as they would have been presented at the San Francisco 1915 Panama-Pacific International Exposition; a third for plants from the lowland tropics (i.e. lianas, coffee trees, cycads), which is kept quite warm; another for highland tropics (such as ferns and orchids), which is kept relatively cool to be like a cloud forest; and finally an aquatic plant room, with all sorts of waterlilies, orchids, and carnivorous plants.

The current "Butterfly Zone" exhibit is great, both for adults and kids. There are many different kinds of butterflies and moths (though there were really only five or six that I saw more than one of). If you've ever wanted to know what kinds of plants butterflies like, this is the place to go. I was especially intrigued by the fact that many of the butterflies and moths really like to hang out on the glass doors. Also, there's a neat case that houses the chrysalises and cocoons of a number of different species. If you're lucky, you may get to see one open.
author: Katie I.

description: Absolutely beautiful! The flowers, plants, trees, scenery, just the entire environment was gorgeous. The butterfly room was beautiful. A very romantic scenery and I'm sure a great place to take someone on a first date. :)
author: Daerleth D.

description: I really, really, really want to give this a better review.  But if I had to give a one-word review, it would be: underwhelmed.  The building itself is  interesting and beautiful, as are the grounds, but the actual botanical garden itself is extremely limited and small.  I mean, this makes sense, because it's all in that interesting, but small building, but I was *really* underwhelmed by the gardens.  I know I'm comparing this in my mind to other cities' botanical gardens (behemoth in comparison), which is unfair, because, fundamentally, this conservatory does a different job.  But really, it's just a very small experience, both in size and scope.  I saw a special exhibit there (the wicked plants one), that was well-designed, but (again) largely underwhelming.  Was it worth my $7?  No.  Did I begrudge giving my $7 to a flower conservatory no matter how underwhelming?  Not really.
author: Tarah D.

description: Visited here on 1/23/2013 and I have to say that in a world of hustle and bustle where wholesome non-electronic entertainment can be a challenge to schedule into your google calendar, this was literally a breath of fresh air for me. In a few hours the boyfriend and I got to take a short trip around the world of plants in a turn of the century architectural wonder and learn a ton about San Francisco's history in a plant room devoted purely to that. This would be a great way to spend a couple of hours with family of all ages or friends. We had a blast both there and walking around the gorgeous park afterward. Beautiful place for a little daycation. Will definitely come back and try to catch a free tour!
author: Courtney L.

description:
When I need a place to go just to clear my mind, this is a place to go.  It is beautiful and just makes me feel so much better -- no matter what.  They have a wide variety of flowers and I love seeing all the little squirrels.  It's like a park in a park, but this park is much more quiet and calm; unlike the outside park (golden gate =P).

On the next sunny day, go take a walk -- you won't regret it.  I always leave with a smile on my face.
author: Pia V.

description: I was only there for a short visit to see the Dahlia Dell, but want to return when I have more time to go thru the actual Conservatory.  If it's anything like the dahlia exhibit, then it should be very cool!
author: Elise G.

description: Tropical paradise in the city!! This place is amazing - a must-see when you visit Golden Gate Park. For a mere $5 you get transported to another world. I went yesterday on a dreary San Francisco morning, and suddenly I was in a warm Victorian greenhouse full of orchids, giant palms and ferns, water lilies, and all sorts of hanging vines and fruit trees I'd never heard of or seen before. Amazing! There were lots of kids there too with their parents, and everyone seemed to love it. This place is beautiful on the outside, but definitely worth the cheap admission to experience it on the inside! Just one more reason to love Golden Gate Park.  ;)
author: Betsy B.

description:
You want to see orchids, they got orchids, how about lily pads, they got them too.
Cute exhibit using recycled garbage to show SF landmarks, and a train running through.  Good through March.  Great for kids! 
Layer, its hot!
author: Pam M.

description:
One of my favorite places on earth!  I go as often as I can, camera in hand to see what is blooming or what new plant has been rotated into the displays.  

As an amateur horticulturalist and photographer, this is a great place to shutterbug. Be aware however that the varying humidity and temperature levels in each 'room' can cause lenses to fog up.

I would have given 5 stars but the one thing I find lacking is plant name signage. EVERY plant should have a name tag. 

You can't beat the price and the the rotating exhibits are always well done.
author: Lali B.

description:
Great for tourists and SF residents alike, especially those who like flowers.  bring your caera.  beautiful plants and flowers.

A true SF treasure.
author: Cynthia B.

description:
A great little conservatory in GG park.  I go by here all the time and it took a visiting cousin to get me to come in here (she's studying botany).  Now I'm sure if I knew what it was like, it wouldn't have taken me 2 years to finally visit.

For $5 you get to tour 5 different small biodomes: lowland tropics, highland tropics, aquatic plants, potted plants, and the butterfly dome.

Yes, it's small, but it's very enjoyable if you like plants (i do) and if you don't mind the heat and humidity (I don't).

I was surprised to see some of my houseplants in the tropics biodomes, which explains why most of them died in my dark non-humid cool apt but doesn't explain why one of them is growing like a weed.
author: Jean K.

description: What better way to spend a sunny day than to be surrounded by all sorts of blooming vibrant flowers?! I first came here back in 2006 and have been paying a visit here at least once a year. Sometimes we are so engulfed in our busy life that we really don't take the time to smell the roses. At the heart of Golden Gate Park, it's definitely a nice getaway from the bustling city. Perfect setting for a date or just for a leisurely stroll.
author: Danh N.

description:
I just realized I hadn't reviewed this, so this review is a bit overdue. I was a bit put off by the name, which makes it sound like a boring, stuffy place for older folks to hang out at on a Sunday afternoon. But it ended up being one of the highlights of our trip!

It's basically a giant terrarium, and you get to go inside! Being a science/plant/animal nerd, I thoroughly enjoyed myself, as did the significant other. We are both avid photographers and took easily a hundred pictures in there.

Right away when you enter, the wave of humidity hits you (dress in layers and prepare to strip down!). I'm always cold so I rather enjoyed that part. I also really loved the fish pond that's there when you enter. The first thing many visitors saw that day was me, crouched by the pond, saying, "Take a picture! Take a picture!"

The orchid room was awesome. I've always wanted to grow orchids but haven't yet figured out how to turn my house into one big terrarium. When I do, it will look like this room does.

The aquatic plant room was cool, too. I saw those giant lily pads I've only ever seen on Discovery channel. Some of them are strong enough to support a child! (We read this, haven't tried it yet).

The potted plant room was really exciting to me, too, since my house/yard consists of potted plants in every nook and cranny. I've heard they rotate all the plants out so you see them at their peak. Everything we saw did look really nice.

Chomp! Carnivorous Plants was the rotating display when we were there. We saw more pitcher plants than you need to in a lifetime, but they were super cool. My favorite piece of trivia from the day was that rodent skeletons have been found in large pitcher plants! How can you say plants are boring after that!?

Anyway, you don't have to be into plants or flowers to like this place. If you do, though, it will be just that much more awesome.
author: Jenny S.

description: This is one of my favorite places to go on a sunny San Francisco day. I love the diversity of people that you will find. The park itself is very beautiful and peaceful. There are so many varieties of flowers to look at. The bathrooms are well kept and there is a little snack shack in case you get the munchies. Although dogs are not allowed in the flower section, they are allowed on the open grass area. Perfect place for a picnic and to enjoy the sunshine.
author: Veronica H.

description: This building is so nice!! It sets the whole sf golden gate feel. I loved the butterfly exhibit. The butterflies rest on your finger. I also loved loved the orchids growing differently. Got free tickets from the library.
author: Diane S.

description:
A very nice place especially  the special exhibition Golden Gate Express "Garden Railway". The exhibition featured miniatures of San Francisco's most famous landmark buildings including Golden gate bridge, coit tower, China town gate, Mission Dolores, Transamerica Pyramid and etc.  The replicas were built by recycled materials, including tapes, Chinese game bricks, pc mother board and so on. 

For the garden itself, I wasn't good with tropical climate so I preferred the highland room to the others. 

It is no doubt a great place to spend one hour or so if around golden gate park area.
author: Ile F.

description: The Conservatory of Flowers is an excellent place to go and it's cheap (only $5.00/adult). I went on a Saturday around noon and there weren't very many people there, which is nice. Bring a camera and a loved one!
author: Jennifer P.

description: Lots of flowers, but they need to label more of them. Most weren't labeled so I couldn't properly ID them.
author: Sarah C.

description:
A lovely, vintage, fascinating place to spend a some relaxing time with unique horticultural specimens.  Another of those uniquely SF places and one that should be visited at least annually if not more often.  The annual carnivorous plant show is wicked.   

Spend an hour or two.  Your senses will be glad you did.
author: Russell D.

description:
I had a townhog coupon that got me and my husband in for $7 for the two of us.  It was a good deal and I've always wanted to check this place out so we decided to go a few Saturdays ago.

Well, first off I love the history of this conservatory, and the classic look of the building.  It's essentially a giant palace shaped green house : )  Many tropical flowers and plants, including those that are air plants and aquatic ones.  

I loved the overall charm of this place... however I must say I was a bit disappointed to find out how small it was.  The green houses/domes at botanical gardens in my home country are ginormous.  I guess it was unfair for me to compare an older, classic structure as this one with those that are made of modern materials that could handle a larger size though.  

So yeah, I love that this place is still around, and I think it's super cute... but we pretty much finished looking at all the exhibited plants in a matter of 10-15 minutes... if we had paid regular admission of $7 per person, well, that money kind of burns up fast at this place.  You are welcome to sit on the benches inside and chit chat... however, this being essentially a green house, it was super hot and humid inside lol so we didn't feel like sitting around too much.

They also have a miniature SF/Thomas train mini model exhibited right now... it must be great for little kids but I've wondered how much more plants they could've fitted in that hall where they had placed Mr. Thomas lol.

So yeah, I can see it's a good place to go with your family.  I think it falls a bit short for a date destination.  I'm glad to say we've been there, but I don't think we'd come back too often unless their plants are supposed to change up pretty frequently.
author: Sascha O.

description: Super beautiful. Plus if you go on a Sunday you can catch a free concert in the park across the path. Bring a picnic and your loved ones for an excellent day in the park.
author: gretchen t.

description:
The Conservatory of Flowers is an amazing building. Tickets are $7 for adults, $5 for students and kids under 18. The conservatory is divided into 5 sections each housing different types of plant, by climate I believe. Be prepared it is HOT inside. It feels a bit like you've walked into the jungle, there are trees as tall as the building itself with weird tentacle trunks, leaves of all shapes and sizes, gorgeous flowers and silly looking fruits. There are plants that grow down from the ceiling and even a tree that looks like it grows right out of the cement! 

The exhibit they're showing right now is Wicked Plants. I wish I had gone on the tour but the room the exhibit is set up in has loads of placards with anecdotes about how the plants have been used to poison someone. Also, there are turtles underneath the fountain in this room. I thought they were awesome. :) 

In front of the building there are flower beds that are changed four times a year and a clock face in the flower bed on the right slope. The view of the Conservatory from the 'bridge' is a great photo op too!
author: Sharan S.

description:
This place is pretty underwhelming.

I really like the structure itself, and they maintain it well.  And it's really pleasant to spend time on the lawn outside and to imagine you're in Disneyland without having paid $60 to get in.  

So everything is basically cool.

But I also (can) take my flora seriously, and while I do appreciate the physical limitations of the building, it's really easy to walk through this place in ten minutes and think, That's it?

The butterflies are cool, although I'm not sure they're always here.  I think it would be better if there weren't set prices, kind of like the botanical garden.
author: John S.

description:
What a great place to stroll through- no matter what the day is like outside. Just don't forget that it's 80 degrees and 100% humidity inside here like I did.

I got to see the carnivorous plants exihibit, which was cool. I just wished those plants could have been bigger- like what I imagined after seeing Little Shop of Horrors as a kid.

As a bonus, no photo here can come out bad, so you look like a pro. And you can get a year's supply of phone and desktop background pictures!
author: Jennie H.

description:
It seems like there's no end to the delightful treasures that Golden Gate Park has to offer and the Conservatory of Flowers is certainly one of them.  What a lovely way to spend an afternoon.  San Francisco residents get in for only five bucks!!

Enter this Victorian greenhouse to find every surface alive with flowering bromeliads, strange orchids and bizarre greenery.  In the Easternmost wing, prehistoric lily pads, five and six feet in diameter float among blooming lotuses and rare aquatic plants.  In the center, you will find a 100-year old philodendron reaching twenty-feet into the air, whose leaves are as tall as me!  Humidity and heat are used to simulate rain forest conditions and vines of every kind swoop down from the ceiling!

The Conservatory of Flowers is like a zoo for plants and falls nothing short of spectacular.  Please do take your time and examine every single petal!

If you want to make a day of it, try my Golden Gate Park "Stop and Smell the Flowers" tour.  Park up on Fulton near 12th Avenue, and start with the Conservatory. Next, head for a snack in the Japanese Tea Garden.  Cross the  street and enjoy a stroll through the Botanical Gardens.  Finally, head back up MLK and cut up through the Rose Gardens and back to Fulton.  (Download a PDF map of Golden Gate Park here: http://www.sfgate.com/traveler/acrobat/maps/1999/ggparkmap.pdf )  

San Francisco residents will know to bring layers.  The park gets cold, especially during Summer.
author: Amy A.

description:
Had a great time here during the "Orchids of the Americas" show and "CHOMP! Carnivorous Plants" show.

I also really enjoyed my volunteer tour guide, Ira, who was very knowledgeable and witty and just plain awesome.

Check out the coconut that looks like a butt/camel toe!!
author: Maria M.

description: Eh. Call me picky, but Longwood Gardens located by the Northern DE/PA border is 10X more worth your money. The small selection of plants on display were beautiful, but I would expect more "bang for my buck." Granted, this couldn't be the best time of year for certain flowers, but I wouldn't have paid to see this, and if ever coming back to the GG Park, would cruise along outside for free or spend my money at the de Young museum.
author: Katie-Rose N.

description:
I had always wanted to visit the Conservatory of Flowers. So, after getting a deal on Groupon, we ventured out to Golden Gate Park to see what the Conservatory is all about. 

The Conservatory of Flowers is located on JFK Drive. We didn't have to wait very long for our tickets. Once we ventured in, there are a few different room, full of different types of flowers with their habitat. It was really nice to see these type of plants and such. 

There are far more plants than flowers at the Conservatory, but it was a great reason to come visit the city nonetheless. Tickets are a good deal - usually $7 a person (and cheaper if you are a SF resident).
author: Jackie D.

description:
Beautiful! 

What a gem, I live within walking distance from here and it's my new favorite place to visit in the park.  3 dollars for SFSU students! Loved the aquatic room.  

Its a quick visit, it's no zoo or garden, a great way to see some history in sf.
author: Andrew Christian C.

description:
Walking into the Conservatory of Flowers I felt as though I walked into a tropical jungle. You are surrounded by gorgeous flowers, trees, and plants. 

There is nothing more relaxing that surrounding yourself with nature and learning all about it.  There is so much information and so much to learn about each type of flower, plant and tree that you could spend hours trying to retain it all.
author: Meghan B.

description: Free admission on first Tuesday of every month. The conservatory building is a copy of the conservatory of flowers in Queen Victoria's garden in London England. The collection of plants inside is amazing, a real treat for the senses. The vivid colors and wonderful scents surround you. The beauty possible in nature is mind blowing. Another treat is observing the interaction between Butterflies and the plants and people. There are also nice gardens all around outside the building as well. Casual attire. Easy street parking. $7 per adult most days.
author: Ron W.

description:
I don't think I would have thought about visiting this place if it weren't for the awesome deal I found on TownHog one day that had two tickets for just $6.  That's just $3 each and the current price is about $7 a person.  I added an extra star just for the price.  It's a place that so many people (San Franciscans) drive by but rarely enter.

I must've came at the perfect time - a Friday about 20 minutes after they opened and just beating a group of about 30 preschoolers eagerly awaiting their tour.  Lucky for me, half the preschoolers needed to potty so I entered the conservatory while it was practically empty.

The orchids are beautiful, banana leaves as big as I remember them as a child, and the botanist even pointed out the coffee beans growing in the main room.  I went because I'd heard about the Golden Gate Express Garden Railway.  I was impressed though I wish it were on a larger scale.  Many famous SF sights built with recycled materials like cassette tapes and little cars that actually move along the Golden Gate Bridge.  I really wish they could make an even bigger exhibit, but the size of the conservatory is just too small.  They even had a little AT&T Park with a real coke bottle inside and Renel Brooks-Moon's voice was annoucing a 7th Inning play.

The next time they have a special exhibit at a special price, I definitely want to go back.  Bring back the butterfly exhibit!
author: Stacey C.

description:
It's a nice place to visit if you are sightseeing at GG Park. 
However, they don't have a huge variety of flowers. I believe they could have more interesting flowers. It was a little boring. Very small place in general: not enough room for plants and frlowers.
We spent around 20 minutes there, because there are not a lot to see.
We also went there to check out the place for the wedding. My fiance and I, both, didn't like it. The ceremony and reception space was extremely small, and not that fancy as it looked on their website. It's very pricey for the space they have, and not a great menu for the dinner. Not worth it all!
author: Jenna F.

description:
For a place dubbed the conservatory of flowers, there were not the abundance of flowers that I would have expected.  I was there during the carnivorous plants special exhibit which showcased some venus' fly traps and pitcher plants which were cool to see.  I went to the exhibit primarily as a photographer to take pictures of flowers, which were pretty and accessible.  Please note that you are not allowed to use a tripod at the exhibit, so using a monopod and/or flash would be highly recommended for some macro photography.  

Also be forewarned that the place is very hot and humid, so dress appropriately.  I stayed in the exhibit for between two to three hours, and could have spent more time there.  While the price for adults is $7/person, you can get in for $5 if you have a student ID or proof of being a San Francisco resident.
author: Bowdoin S.

description:
Since I was a wee lad, I've always wanted to visit this place but never had the chance. I remember a time after I picked up a camera that I was fascinated by the tunnel in front of that white building but still, nary a visit within. Yesterday I went with a friend and made history by entering its mysterious glass walls, just a few decades late! It was sunny but nippy outside, so I kept on my jacket and I swear I never felt a sweat drop while inside, but I was "slightly" occupied. While I suffer from allergies from many things that include flora of all types, I did not have a problem. Recovered from my loss of voice while in Australia just a week ago, I was able to talk to the flowers to incite them to pose willingly for my camera. There are separate areas within the conservatory and as I explored each with my friend, I/we snapped many many flowers, as did many others. 

PHOTOGRAPHICALLY SPEAKING: No tripods allowed so don't take one. A nice zoom with a maximum of about 300 (which I use) will get you spying everything very nicely. Lots of unique colors and species so you won't be bored hauling your camera about. The only area you should worry about is the tropic area which has a high humidity level, which will fog your filter/glass in about 2mins after entering. I removed my filter as the fog will enter the space between filter and lens glass. Bring a soft glass-cleaning cloth to carefully clean your optics which should be okay about 10-15mins after your entry. Perhaps if the lens glass were "heated" by putting your camera within a warm spot (perhaps wrapped under your worn sweater/jacket) will warm the glass sufficiently so this won't happen? If you try this, please let me know if it works. I found myself using a ISO of anywhere from 400 to a high of 2500 to snap flora in the various areas with light, less light or none.

Take a very careful look in each area - there are delightful small/big flowers at every step. There's no time limit so come early to enjoy the sights...  you won't regret it!!! Though the conservatory closes at 5pm, the very last entry is allowed till 4:30pm; don't wait till the last minute though: if you enter at the time you'll not have sufficient time to view all of the fascinating flora so go early!!!

There is presently a train exhibit, the 2nd Annual Golden Gate Express Garden Railway, that will please kids of all ages. While the train is standard fare, the train landscape is not. It consists of recycled materials to build a "City" named San Francisco. It features just about all o the SF landmarks - all created with recycled things!! This special exhibit continues through April 18, 2010. More information at http://www.conservatoryofflowers.org/atconservatory/special-exhibits

$7.00 for Adults
$5.00 for Youth ages 12-17, Seniors age 65 & over, and College Students with ID. 
$2.00 for Children ages 5-11 and FREE for Children ages 4 and under

***Discounts available to all San Francisco City and County residents with proof of residency (i.e. bill, ID, etc)***

Open on Memorial Day, 4th of July, Labor Day, and until 2pm Christmas Eve. It is wheelchair accessible for both motorized and non-motorized chairs though some of the passages within are quite narrow BUT do not let this deter you! Just be careful of the running screaming unsupervised kids who seem to be everywhere.
author: Tony L.

description:
The Butterflies & Blooms exhibit was the most magical thing I have ever been to. A whole room was just filled with more butterflies than I've ever seen at one time flying around and landing on all sorts of beautiful flowers. If you stopped and looked at any one plant you would suddenly realize there were butterflies hiding, camouflaged, on the flowers.

$7 for an adult is maybe a little pricey, but for that exhibit alone it was well worth it.
author: Kathleen B.

description: Not somewhere I'd go all the time, but it was nice visiting and well worth it. Only $5 with proof of SF residency, or $7 otherwise.  There were five rooms filled with all sorts of interesting plants and ponds with fish and turtles.  Right now one of the rooms houses the Wicked Plants exhibit, which I enjoyed.  It was very interesting to read about how many plants kill/harm humans every year and to see them.  It doesn't take too long to walk through all of the rooms, probably an hour at most.  Overall it's something fun and different to do in SF, and I'd definitely recommend going at least once!
author: Kimberly K.

description: Cute space, takes less than an hour to view. Really enjoyed the special exhibit Boom Town, which showcases model trains in a miniature San Fran.
author: Chrystina Z.

description: My first visit here and I left surprised and in awe of the Butterflies & Blooms exhibit (that runs until October) and the Dahlia garden outside to the side of CoF, blooming with my absolute favorite flower.  We easily spent a couple hours strolling around and taking pictures until we got kicked out when they closed.  I left wanting to come back again soon to show friends this beautiful place in SF that might get a little overlooked in GG Park amongst the other museums.  I liked the low-key vibe here and the ability to find butterflies on almost every plant inside the room.  I'm also a fan on their facebook page and want to keep up with their new exhibits and activities.    Definitely a worth-while, relaxing activity in GG Park to be experienced, photographed, and enjoyed by all ages.  A great change of pace here if you need a break from the hustling city vibe and its tourist attractions/crowded museums.  Sidenote, lots of butterflies looked battered but not sure why.  Despite signs everywhere, I saw many children (AND adults too) touch and pick them up- Shame on you people!  I don't know why people can't just leave them alone to do their thing.
author: Alexandra P.

description: Such a great place to enjoy the afternoon and read a book. There are so many different plants here from all over the world. I will just suggest that if you have no appreciation for nature then do not come here.
author: Kayla G.

description:
My review is for a special event happening at the Conservatory now thru April 18, 2010:  The 2nd Annual Golden Gate Express Garden Railway.  
We walked thru the Conservatory looking at the flora first.  We saved the best for last to go thru the wing with the Garden Railway.
I took visiting family here specifically to see this exhibit and so glad I did.  It was amazing.   A model train, cable car, streetcars and more wind their way thru a landscape of dwarf plants and past mini replicas of the city's landmark buildings.
Ghiradelli Square, Golden Gate Bridge, Coit Tower, Chinatowns Dragon Gate,  PacBell Park, & Palace of Fine Arts are just some of the landmarks crafted from recyled and repurposed materials.  Creativity abounds in the artwork and in the plants that surround this mini city.  A couple times a day they have special effects with an earthquake and some fog that rolls in under the Golden Gate bridge and envelops the city.
First Tuesday of the month is free.  Fairly clean public restrooms outside to the left of the building.
If you are not a fan of flowers...go anyway...it's worth a trip to see the City by the Bay in miniature!
author: T F.

description: What a great find in Golden Gate park.  I stumbled in here as was pleasantly surprised by this attraction.  There are 3 rooms filled with tropical plants and flowers, including a lily pond, orchids, and trees.  I felt like I was in Hawaii!  Nice place to walk around, take pictures, and relax.  Saw several couples in here for awkward first dates lol.
author: Alli T.

description:
Oh holy mother, the flowers and the butterflies blew my mind. Orchids are my favorite flower, by far, and there was every color and kind you can think of. Just beautiful. And the whole greenhouse felt like home against the freezing cold outside. You enter a mini rainforest-like habitat. And there were so many butterflies I thought I was going to step on them. I mustve spent atleast an hour in the butterfly greenhouse alone. And we even watched them come out of their cocoons. 
My friend and I actually snuck into the place, so we didnt have to pay to get in, which was tight, and I wouldve seeing as the place is just beautiful.
It was just awesome. I took so many pictures. :)
author: Katie P.

description:
This place is truly a hidden gem. Once inside, you feel as if you are in the tropics somewhere. The humidity, the warmth, the sensational colors and the tranquility are awe inspiring! Seems like they have a new exhibit that changes every so often. Some of my other favorite things here are all the exotic orchids and the water Lilly pond, absolutely amazing! 

Make sure you bring your camera!!!
author: Chris B.

description:
Even though we went in the middle of October (not much in bloom!) the Conservatory of Flowers was still breathtaking.  Start off in the lobby with a little bit of conservation history, and marvel at the age of the all glass-and-wood building you're standing in (wow!).

It would have been nice to have caught some sort of guided tour, as my boyfriend kept making fun of me for reading the self-guided tour pamphlet and telling me I was reading instead of  looking at the plants.  But, I learned stuff while he just looked around, so HA!

The carnivorous plant exhibit was pretty cool, but it looks like I missed live demonstrations in there as well...next time I'll just have to time my visit better!
author: Cathy Y.

description:
Call me crazy, but this is one place I like enjoying from the outside more than going in.  Unless you're an orchid aficionado, or live for the minutiae of houseplant botany, save yourself $5 and just enjoy the Conservatory from the outside!

This victorian ice-palace of wrought iron and glazed glass is so perfect in its setting...surrounded by greenery in every direction.  On a sunny day I love sitting on the grassy slope facing the Conservatory and just admiring the scene (of course while music on my iPod kills the traffic noise on JFK Drive).  The outdoor displays are hit-or-miss; if you visit on a day they are changing the plantings you'll see nothing but roped-off mounds of brown dirt...but hit it when the bulbs and plantings are at high bloom, and the display of color can be beautiful.

I am always impressed with the two "artwork" displays made of flowers on the sloped hill in front of the building.  One is a clock with face and numbers made out of blooms, real watch hands tell the real time (hey! Its half past a begonia! quarter to a mum!)....and the other changes seasonally to celebrate holidays--the Christmas gingerbread house was cute.
author: SFnativeGal ..

description:
While I appreciate the concept of the Conservatory, I'm always a little disappointed when I visit.

I was there last Friday for the Orchids of The Americas and Chomp exhibits. The room with the orchids was ok, there were a few very beautiful flowers in there. However, there were also pots that had been knocked over and not righted, plants that looked like they had simply been chopped off in the middle, and plants that simply looked like they were about to die. The special exhibit room with the carnivorous plants was the biggest let down. It was half empty, and the plants that were there were smaller and less healthy than ones I've seen at hardware stores that sell plants.

I can't help but wonder if the reason for all of this is the rude, disrespectful people that can't keep their paws off of the plants. There were kids running around sticking their fingers in the pitcher plants and squeezing the fly traps shut, and I even saw an adult lift one of the lily pads out of the water to take a look at the root system as if she didn't read the sign on the door that said "don't touch".

Bottom line though, is that my friend and I spent more time in the gift shop outside than in the Conservatory itself.
author: Vanessa R.

description:
Beautiful! Last Saturday we piled in the car and drove to the SF conservatory of flowers. I had to hold on to my 6 month old since there are no strollers allowed in the conservatory. Oh, but what a delight! Orchids of every color and shape. Informed employees at hand to answer any question one could have on flowers and carnivorous plants. Plenty of little benchs to sit on to admire the beauty of it  all! ( and rest my arms from holding 17lbs of baby)

Even my 12 year old son, Tom was amazed to find a large cockroach being consumed by a large pitcher plant. Fun for all ages!
author: linda l.

description: Beautiful flowers! I like the pond plants section the most.
author: Cind Y.

description: My wife and my daughter and I decided on a day trip to San Francisco and one of the main reasons was to come to The Conservatory Of Flowers.  Our daughter is 4 months old.  We parked our car, walked a long distance to the entrance only to find out that strollers are not allowed in the conservatory.  We we stunned and more than a little pissed off.  They told us we could leave our stroller outside in an unprotected area on the lawn lazily marked for strollers, out in the open, no barriers, where anyone could take it!  Very disappointed, very put out, very inconvenienced by their ridiculous rule.  What a waste of our time and a long trip to the city.  Families beware!  They lost out on our business today and honestly, I won't come back when my daughter is older.  If there are no strollers allowed in, at least have a protected area to store them!!!!!!  A locked area where our stroller would be safe would have meant that you would have had our patronage today, but you ruined a potentially wonderful experience for our family.
author: Alexander L.

description: This was a beautiful stop on our visit to San Francisco. For only $6 per person with Student ID, and kids 3 and under free, the $12 for us was worth it. There are several koi ponds that my 2.5 year old loved to watch. Beautiful orchids and other flowers abound as well as a variety of unusual exotic plants that I've never had the opportunity to see in person until now. We especially enjoyed the special exhibit with the model train set. It is true what their website says about no strollers. We had read that ahead of time and left ours in the car. However the place where they ask you to leave your strollers is indoors and there is an attendant there at all times. Had I brought my stroller, I would've felt comfortable messing it there. As soon as you enter the conservatory, it is clear why they don't allow strollers. The walkways are very narrow and frankly I'm surprised this place is considered wheelchair accessible. I think anyone in a wheelchair would find navigating the narrow passageways a challenge. Thankfully we arrived early and we're able to find a good free parking spot on the street right in front of the conservatory but those spots certainly go fast and I believe there is a 4 hour limit even on weekdays.  We visited the conservatory first before heading to the California Academy of Science and we are glad we did. The conservatory is certainly not the buzz of excitement that the California Academy of Science is, but it is still a gem worth visiting.
author: Sarah T.

description:
A gorgeous house of flowers! The architecture of the conservatory itself has always looked so alluring to me. When I finally made my way in for a visit, it was such a delight! There are plenty of gorgeous blooms in various colors and as long as you can appreciate the small stuff...you'll find each leaf a spectacle to see.

A perfect rating especially due to the "SF WORLD CHAMPS" display spelled out in tiny (cactus?) buds. Very cool!
author: Sarah Z.

description: Such a gorgeous place to plan a picnic, bike ride, or just to relax for an afternoon. The variety and presentation of flowers show how work and pride they put into making this one of the most beautiful places in SF.
author: Mike P.

description:
This place was an enjoyable diversion.  It's full of plants upon plants which could probably entertain a plant enthusiast for quite a while.  That is if you can stand the heat and humidity and, in our case, hordes of field-tripping children with no regard for the personal space of people or plants.

The "Chomp" exhibit was pretty interesting.  However, a lot of the informative signs either had nothing to do with what they were next to or were covered up by plants, making them impossible to read.  It seemed really strange that they would make it so challenging to learn something from the exhibit.

If you go, I'd recommend dressing in layers and attempting to time your visit to avoid large groups of children.
author: Colleen M.

description:
Even if you're not a plant/flower fan, it's still a treat to go. I went on Halloween because my coupon was expiring and I was surprised how many different exhibits there were. Chomp 2 was amazing, I left home wanting to grow my own venus fly trap. There were just so many plants and flowers I've never seen in my life and what a perfect place to actually appreciate them. Plenty of benches to sit allowing you to take a moment admire your surroundings. 

Quick tip: Last entry is 4pm. Some rooms are more humid than others. Bring a college ID if you have one, admission is only $3!
author: Johanna P.

description: I went with a friend to the Playland exibit and I loved it! It was so worth the $3 with student ID to get in. I also got a nice facial in the Sauna hot rooms! Go check it out, it's worth the low price
author: Karen T.

description: We really enjoyed our visit, only five dollars for students and we spent a fun forty-five minutes wandering through the climate rooms. Really liked the train exhibit, but missed the earthquake a volunteer promised us. Definitely worth the visit, especially considering the prices of the other attractions in the park.
author: Lauren E.

description:
Quality: 3
Value: 3

I came here December 29, 2009 with my girlfriend. Tickets were $5 each with student ID. They definitely had quite a few flowers and plants on exhibit, but I was actually a bit disappointed. There were some interesting ones, but overall I wanted to see more, and I felt a little let-down. We were probably in and out of there in about 30 minutes.
author: David L.

description:
I remember the day I went here. It was the day the Academy opened. I got up super early, shaved my head bald, and headed out to the academy opening. After seeing the long lines in the sweatering heat. I had to do something. I decided to hit the Conservatory of Flowers.

I HAD SO MUCH FUN. Maybe it's cuz I love botany. But just staying here and looking at the plants was so much fun. I definitely want to go again. That is if the b/f gets overs his metrophobia.
author: Lana P.

description: After wandering around the Golden Gate parks for hours, we couldn't pass up exploring that beautiful giant white building. Not being SF natives, we seriously thought it was a museum or something but I'm so glad we went in! There were newts, crazy orchids and it smelled and felt hot and swampy like I'd imagine the Amazons to smell. It's separated into various rooms and the last one we visited was a huge gift shop and area where we could actually tough the plants. My friend bought a massive orchid poster for super cheap and we all tasted a bunch of vanillas or something. I have no idea what it was but it was a really cool experience and very cheap. It was a hike but we loved it and will definitely return on our next quest through the city.
author: Amanda M.

description: Beautiful place to take pictures of flowers and enjoy the scenery. The admission isn't unreasonable and there's a lot to see. Careful though, they're not open 7 days a week, make sure you check the website for their schedule!
author: Mrs. B.

description:
I once saw an exhibit here in which a piece of butcher paper was hung on a wall, and people were asked to write their favorite cutesy word for "butterfly" on it. I don't know why. Someone - an adult, I'm pretty sure - had written "flutterpony". It is impossible for something non-magical to happen within these walls.

I'm not even going to attempt a measured evaluation, because this is a collection of exotic flowers in a weird and beautiful Victorian greenhouse in my favorite park in my favorite area of my favorite city in the world. There's a room containing a huge pond covered with gigantic Amazon Water Lilies. Orchids are everywhere. There shouldn't even be reviews for this place. Its surpassing excellence is too obvious for that to have any purpose.

I don't want to read your scathing review, contemptuous world-class botanist. You hate flowers and YOU ARE WRONG.
author: Morgan P.

description:
I took it as a sign that I must visit the Conservatory of Flowers when tickets were featured on Groupon.  We almost give up and go back home though, after driving around in circles looking for parking (note to self, wake up EARLY for the Academy of Sciences).  I expected the Conservatory of Flowers to be larger (it looks pretty grand in pictures), but it was actually much smaller in person.  Still, they managed to pack every square inch with plants and flowers.
