I wish I had been able to make one of the docent led special demonstrations for Chomp! 2 (carnivorous plants exhibit), maybe next time.  Even without a guide, there are instructional boards, labels, and magnifying glasses to take you through the various carnivorous plants by region.

We were also lucky enough to see the Amazon water lily in bloom, which we were told only happens every 10 years.  So cool (they're also known to support the weight of a small child)!

Two tips:
- Dress in layers (with the ability to remove some) it does get warm in some areas of the greenhouse
- If you bring your DSLR to take pictures of the plants, please be respectful of other people who are there just to enjoy the flowers and plants
author: EurJean C.

description: This is a really pretty place, located in the middle of Golden Gate Park. They have a lot of beautiful flowers, and a lot of places to take wonderful pictures. We biked all the way here from Union Square, it was definitely an up-hill battle, but it was definitely worth seeing. Go check it out!
author: Janine R.

description:
Small, but I spend hours in there each time I go cuz there's so many tiny plants you miss if you just walk through looking at the obvious flowers at eye level. Right now the special exhibit is Chomp! a collection of carnivorous plants, and again, I wouldn't think much of it on first glance, but if you slow down and peer at the tiny things, some of them are incredible!

The highland tropics room is full of orchids. I overheard someone saying that the conservatory has the largest public collection of orchids in the world. The aquatic plants room is cool, but I wouldn't take an expensive camera in there cuz it's hot and humid enough that your lenses will fog up!

I put up some of my better photos here:

http://www.flickr.com/photos/iomarch/sets/72157600310857951/
author: Jin Z.

description:
This is a smaller, cozier conservatory compared to its counterparts abroad. We saw couples picnicking outside so even if you do think it can be quickly walked through, you should pack a picnic lunch and spend some quality time outside enjoying the peace and quiet :). It makes for enjoyable repeat visits.

Some of the rooms were convincingly tropical in feel but every time I started to feel a bit hot and sticky, there would be an adjoining room to visit that was nice and cool. It took us a little under an hour to walk through, but we took the time to take photos and explore some of the less flashy plants and flowers in the undergrowth. I think quite a few people miss out on the smaller, hidden gems or even the ones hanging above their heads. Look beyond eye level to see more.

There is something very soothing about all the greenery minus the worries (or as my boyfriend says, the fun!) of wild creatures lurking all around. The children were thrilled with their special holiday exhibit complete with model trains and trollies. The sound is buffered nicely so all the happy shrieks and train horns did not disturb the other exhibits too much.

I think it would be a fabulous place for photo shoots, inside or outside the conservatory!
author: Tiffany L.

description:
Wow!!! For $3 (per student) a person this place was amazing!!! So many beautiful plants in here. I was amazed. My boyfriend brought me here for our anniversary. We had a picnic on a huge lawn with a ton of other people but there was plenty of room for everyone and we still had enough privacy to enjoy our sushi and pour out small cups of sake (illegal i know- but we werent driving and we werent drunken idiots after either.)
this is a VERY ROMANTIC place to take your honey, so take notes guys. 
this is a great place to take pics and its not weird if you dress up. i did and so did my BF so wear something cute and take pics!!
the dalias were especially lovely.
its really humid in there so your hair will get all funked. 

~~

I really enjoyed the weird looking plants like the double coconut, pitcher plants, porcupine tree, and the edible plant exhibit. except dont expect to be eating anything!!
i also loved the lily pad pond. so beautiful
there was a hubiscus there the size of my face!!!
the potted plants room smelled amazing like cloves.
I showed the pics i took to my mom and she was really excited!!!
author: Katie F.

description: Remember last June when we had a few days when it was like 95 degrees in San Francisco?  Well my brother was in town and guess where we decided to take him?  The Conservatory of Flowers!  Where it's super hot and humid!  Brilliant!  Other than the fact that our faces were dripping with sweat the whole time, we really enjoyed our visit.  We went when they had the butterfly zone thing going on, which was pretty cool.  The area around the conservatory is nice to just sit around and people watch.
author: Eileen H.

description: What a beautiful Victorian Conservatory!  A nice albeit, humid sometimes :) stroll through these amazing flowers and plants.  Just a fun way to learn.
author: Sopla R.

description:
I went here this past weekend. Inside is quite humid (it IS a greenhouse), especially the aquatic plants room which was actually my favorite.
The CHOMP exhibit is interesting. Make sure you listen to the docent there because it's pretty interesting. She even cut open a pitcher plant for us and showed us all the dead bugs inside! XD
It takes maybe an hour more or less to view the entire conservatory if you're reading ALL the descriptions and taking pictures of ALL the plants and flowers. 

Overall, it's seriously just OK. Not too bad, not too heart-poundingly exciting. It's great for the price so I don't see why you shouldn't come by for a visit. If you don't have a camera with you, however, I believe you will be very bored. =X
author: Bonnie L.

description:
Had a half off coupon and hit it up for an hour on a Sunday afternoon. The entrance is phenomenal, the work done to maintain it, plus it added a lot of SF vibe that there was a jazz trumpet musician playing his music through a tunnel just outside the entrance. 

The exhibit was Carnivorous Plants. There was one young girl in there who was unbelievably enthusiastic to the point of near inspirational with her depth of knowledge and friendliness. Big ups to her whoever she is.
author: Nelson C.

description: The stroll through Golden Gate park just to get to this place (JFK road was blocked off on this particular Sunday... seems like its a regular occurrence) was pleasant and relaxing. Came upon the conservatory and was surprised to have to pay $7 to get in. My expectations just jumped from the ground floor up to a, "better be amusing." Sadly the conservatory was as my initial expectation, boring, small and nothing to get excited about.
author: Tommy B.

description:
Our final stop on a Golden Gate Park Adventure was the Conservatory of Flowers. Definitely, the best part of the day! You walk up to a big field of flowers and walking paths and go straight into the big white domed palace of flowers and other plants. Each room had a different environment filled with pretty flowers, carnivorous plants, giant lilly pads, and tons of plants we have never seen before. A great spot for photographers!

Check out the other spots we went to on our GG Park adventure and lots of pics here http://www.sanfrancisconoobs.com/09-08-2009/golden-gate-park-adventure-japanese-tea-garden-sf-botanical-gardens-the-conservatory-of-flowers/
author: Casi C.

description: This is one of the most beautiful places in San Francisco. Golden Gate Park never ceases to impress me with it's hidden charms. The elegant white building immediately sets the scene. It is full of gorgeous flowers. It is neat to walk from room to room experiencing the different climates for the plants. The Conservatory of Flowers is also surrounded by beautiful flower beds. Any time of the year, it is a stunning place to visit.
author: Kari G.

description:
What a GLORIOUS way to spend a sunny San Francisco day! Hike your way over to Golden gate park for an afternoon in the Conservatory of Flowers. Take a stroll through a well groomed lawn decorated with native Californian plants. Soak in the sunshine as you admire the poppies and fantastic people watching. For a $5 admission fee head inside the white double doors and enjoy the conservatory's unique collection of flora. 

A great place for dates, picnics, or passionate plant people - the Conservatory of Flowers is another fantastic San Francisco treat!
author: Caroline J.

description:
Amazing place, pure and simple. They have such an array of flora here that you won't be able to remember all their names. If you love plants and flowers (and who doesn't?) then you'll love this place. 

And as a bonus, all the plants are contained in that weird Taj Mahal looking building you know from tv and movies... so you get say you've been there! :D
author: Erin H.

description:
I love date night and I love old buildings, especially ones that remind me of what San Francisco was like in the late 1800s.

The aforementioned date night brought us here at 8 p.m. for the nocturnal butterfly exhibit. Until sometime in November (ish?) you can come here between 8 and 9:30 p.m. on the first and third Thursday of the month, flashlight provided, and poke around in the nooks and crannies all over this massive greenhouse. After first wandering around the beautiful plant life, including orchids of all kinds, water lilies, some Little Shop of Horrors-ish carnivorous plants and stuff that looked like genitalia, we headed over to The Butterfly Zone.

The Zone had butterflies here and there like we expected, and we saw several small, beautiful iridescent blue ones chilling in the rafters. Tons of information (largely to appeal to kidfolk), and a lady walking around with (dead) touchable samples of a moth and monarch butterfly. Since no educational Zone is yelling-kid free, steel yourself accordingly.

Several nooks and crannies throughout to sneak some private time (not THAT private, sorry) with your date. One of the cheapest dates ($5 each) you'll have, too.

Ladies love flowers; be a gent and take her here for a real show.
author: Tara R.

description: This place was awesome! I visited with my boyfriend and it's basically like a huge greenhouse full of exotic plants and prehistoric plants and lots and lots of orchids. All of it was amazing! OH and don't throw coins in the pond or the from prince will curse you for disturbing his pond ^.^ the smell in there is amazing it just so awesome everyone should go! I also used my out of town student ID and they accepted it!
author: Melinda F.

description:
an easy walk from the MUNI, not too expensive. very beautiful building and flowers.

it doesn't take too long to walk through but the surrounding grounds are also beautiful.
author: Teresa K.

description:
Just looking outside made us come back to visit inside, make sure you check their closing time before going

This is by far the most beautiful outdoor garden I have seen in some time. The best part is its free. The vibrant colors from a variety of flowers really makes this place attractive. But we had so much fun outside that by the time we actually got to the conservatory entrance, they were already closing. Being so impressed by the outside, we definitely had to go in to see.

The inside, while nice, cannot match Brooklyn Botanical Garden in NYC. But heck, $3 admission for students? You can't beat that price. The lotus pond and a few other flowers (one that looks like angel wings) are probably the best flowers inside.
author: Jack N.

description:
Apparently it takes a very smart person to know what the hell this place is because between one of us who grew up in the Bay Area and the other who has lived in SF proper for going on 9 years we could not distinguish the difference, upon memory alone, between the Arboretum, the Botanical Gardens and the Conservatory of Flowers. The one that is in the big white building, with all of the flowers out front, yeah, that one is the Conservatory of Flowers. Go figure. 

Anyhow, if you are seeking the help of Jenny Craig and paying $20 a day for her meal plan to lose weight you should just pay $5 per day and come hang out in here every day. Its like a sauna and will melt the pounds away, especially if you pair it with a nice walk in the park and avoid all of the hot dog and ice cream vendors set up out front on the sidewalk. 

They have orchids in here, many varieties of them, and mini Japanese landscapes built on slabs of marble. They also have carnivorous plants, but they will not eat the fat off your body so do not try to add that to your weight loss plan, those suckers only like water and insects. If you are lucky you will see an insect slowly dying inside one of the plants as it devours its lunch. They also have fruit trees, but you can't eat the fruit, even with the price of admission, so bring your own. 

Sometimes they have a butterfly exhibit, but not while we were there. The price of admission is $5 with or without the butterflies so I felt a little jipped, but a random stranger asked me to be in their happy anniversary video card and I got to make out with my boyfriend next to a cool fern or two so I suppose it was a fair trade. If you don't get to do the latter two I would demand the butterflies, or, unless you are there to lose weight, it might not be worth the price of admission.
author: Drue C.

description:
A beautiful Victorian greenhouse.  

The white palace standing near the northern edge of Golden Gate park is a greenhouse, imported and erected in the 19th Century.  Looking across the ridges and towers, one can see the influence of the Empire, in the echoes of Buddhist wats in the decoration.  One can see the British seafaring tradition, in the boxy bay window extensions in the odd corners.  One can see a sense of spirit as the white glass rises to a dome in the center.  One can see a sense of pride and craftsmanship in the hand-made detail.  

This palace was once destined for San Jose, but through a political affront was redirected to San Francisco.  It became a symbol of urban elegance, a jewel in the collage that inevitably appeared on the postcards tourists sent home.  The setting is positively European, and it looks much larger on the outside than on the inside.  

The interior is a collection of sealed chambers, presenting foliage from different tropical climate zones.  It is warm and humid in there, regardless of the weather outside.  

The Conservatory was destroyed in a wind storm in 1995, and lay abandoned until its restoration and grand reopening in 2003.  I was one of the thousands of contributors that funded the restoration, and I am very proud that this heritage landmark was not allowed to disappear.  

The plants inside are vibrant and alive today, including some of the originals.
author: David D.

description: It's a small relaxing sanctuary for plants and people alike. There were some interesting plants in there including carnivorous ones! Yikes! I liked the Wicked Plants exhibition because it was informative as well as surprising. For example, the outer casing of a cashew is poisonous!
author: Sheila T.

description:
If you use your student ID (you still kept your's from college, right?), admission is only $3. Now that's a price I can afford! The Conservatory isn't big but it is cozy with five main rooms, one with rotating exhibitions. Currently, the fifth room features carnivorous plants (my favorite!)

The aquatic plants room is very serene (when it's not packed with visitors) and it's the warmest of the rooms so if you're freezing your ass off in the middle of a windy fog-covered summer day at the park, it's a nice refuge.

The rest of the Conservatory is pretty interesting. Botany buffs enjoy! Others may not be so excited. It's a very pleasant way to spend an hour (or less.) Definitely the kind of place you can bring your grandparents.
author: Viv C.

description:
You may not be aware of this but I grew up in a jungle.  

No really - my mother owned and maintained approximately 60 houseplants inside our home on a routine basis.  One day we counted - 62!   We played hide and seek amongst the ferns on a daily basis and to this day my decorating style is punctuated by thoughts like "that corner could really use a good-size plant".

So the first time I stepped into the Conservatory of Flowers, it was almost like going home...but with orchids.   

I had to bring my mother here on one of her many jaunts back to the Bay Area.  She loved it - ferns and orchids and water lilies, oh my.  The biggest hit - the bromeliads.  For some reason my mother has a soft spot for those things though I still maintain that the scar on my knee came from the monster bromeliad she kept in the dining room.  (I took to calling it 'Audrey'.)

I think the Conservatory could use a really good interpretive sign/display upgrade to enhance the educational aspects of the place, but overall it is a place of beauty and interest.
author: Suzanne B.

description:
I think everyone here is on crack.  Skip this place and run, don't walk to the Japanese Tea Garden right down the street because it's way better.

The Conservatory of Flowers is the most boring place you could ever pay to go to in San Francisco.  I am all about the museums and attractions that this city has to offer but this one definitely falls to the bottom of my list.

Conservatory of Flowers?  What flowers?  I saw a half dozen half dead orchids and that's about it.

I took my sister there who was in town and maybe we are a little biased because she used to work at a gorgeous botanical garden back in Michigan (yes, Michigan) and that place puts the Conservatory to shame.

It takes about 15 minutes to get through this place and that's not including spending time in the section on house plants.  Not kidding, they have an area dedicated to domestic plants.

I'm glad to report it only costs $5 to get in but I'm not sure it was even worth that.  Save a dollar and hit up the Tea Garden.
author: Derek B.

description:
What...more flowers? You want more...they got more!!!
And you thought you couldn't have your cake and eat it too. 
But here...you can.

feeling sf's chill....come on inside and enjoy the warmth. things are growing inside....makes one feel...warm. the building itself....just makes me want to hose the entire place down....but I think that would be fun.

but above all else..bring a yard stick so you can whack all the ankle biters handling butterflies in front of the sign that says not to. devil spawn
author: John-Michael C.

description:
I have seen this place built up from the ground up and it took me this long to actually go inside.  I went yesterday and it definitely will not be the last time I go.  I am in love! 
I'm in love with the humidity that hits you in the face as you step into the Lowland Tropics room from the cold of the San Francisco fog. I'm in love with the orchids, the Bromeliads, the ferns, the Philodendron who is so much older than even my grandparents, the kumquat and tangerine plants blossoming their little hearts out with the most beautifully fragrant flowers.  I love the smell and the sound and the green green green everywhere.  This place is amazing! The Docents who give the free tours are so informative and knowledgeable about the plants and the history of the building.  Everyone should go...at $5 admission, it is a bargain to enjoy such beauty.

This place makes me so thankful to live in California where we get to see green things blooming all year (even outside the conservatory) and don't have to endure gray snowy months.
author: Nilu r.

description:
Nice place, especially with the right person and when stoned.

I loved the train set they had set up at christmas time...pretty elaborate set up its probably still there.

I love chilling some time away here with a good book while stoned out of my mind.
author: Eric H.

description:
How could anyone give the conservatory of flowers less than 5 stars? Its the GD conservatory of flowers! Oh well, to each their own.

I love this place, it is so beautiful and inspiring to be surrounded by such amazing plants and flowers. I do wish there was more info on many of the plants to make it a bit more educational, but I will take whatever I can get.

I also visited the butterfly exhibit, and I guess I was expecting something different...it was definitely aimed towards children. Which is fine, but there should have been more staff monitoring the exhibit. People were letting their A**hole kids pinch the butterflies and handle them...which pissed me off. Damn kids.
author: S F.

description:
I was expecting more.

Compared to other similiar places I've been (Phipps Conservatory in Pittsburgh, 5 stars!) I was kind of disappointed at the size, variety and signage.  The exhibit on carnivorous plants, "Chomp!," was cool and I got to listen to some genius kid talk to his mom and the presenter about the plants (I think he was like 9 and he obviously knew more than the old lady running the exhibit).   The majority of flowers appeared to be one variety of orchids or another, which don't get me wrong I love, but I just wish there had been more variety.  And signage?  The majority of the plants and flowers were unlabeled and apart from the info boards in the Chomp! exhibit there really wasn't much else.
author: Courtney N.

description:
Have mercy, this is a nice treat in GG Park, whether you have a thing for botany or not. They've done a nice job of showcasing plants from a variety of climates, to be sure it's not extensive, but it's definitely worth at least one visit.

The special exhibit when I was there this weekend was about Butterflies, and there were literally specimens flying around. You could get up real close and watch the colorful buggers suck some flower juice, very up close and personal.
author: Nish N.

description:
Yet another GGP gem, and just as essential for SF history/architecture lovers as flower fans.  The building dates back to the 19th century, when you could go off to Peru to make your fortune, then bring back some exotic plants and 600 pounds of chocolate (cuz, you know, carry-on rules were way lax back then), then buy a conservatory-making kit (I kid you not), and plop it right down in the middle of a city park.

Despite the building's grand, ornate appearance, it doesn't take very long to go through.  It consists of 5 rooms representing different eco-zones: tropical lowlands, tropical highlands, aquatic plants, temperate potted plants (sort of an example of what you could do in your own garden), and a special exhibit room.  The current exhibit is Chomp!, dedicated to carnivorous plants like the venus fly-trap (did you know it is endemic to the Carolinas? Weird.)  This weekend is your last chance to see it, by the way.

Admission is $5 but if you join the SF Parks Trust you can get free vouchers.  Also, you will get a lot more out of it if you follow one of the free guided tours, as there's very little signage.
author: Wes M.

description:
The Conservatory of Flowers is one of the best ways to spend 15 minutes on the first Tuesday of any month.

That's what I love about it: you don't feel like you need to spend your whole life in there to soak up some of its goodness.

I'm deducting a point because there are no fish in the aquatic plant pond.
author: Jason R.

description:
The milky glass walls of the conservatory have been calling my name for 10 years.  This Sunday, my husband and I decided to spend some time in childhood wonderment visiting the miniature train display.

But first we circled the misty trees, inhaled the sweet Pomelo aromas, and perspired in the humid tropical oasis of orchids and lush vegetation.  

Carnivorous plants.  Freaking cool.  

I've been to the Academy of Sciences twice and I appreciate all that it has to offer.  However, I was struck by the Conservatory's healthy and diverse plant species.  The $5 local ticket price is greatly affordable and easily encourages me to return with family visiting from out of town.  

This place is a treasure and I'm so glad we spent time here today!

btw:  Several people were shooting with large digital SLR cameras.  Our pictures from they day are gorgeous and I can only presume that everyone else is also in awe of what they captured.
author: Colleen C.

description: I have gone here since my childhood...and always loved it.  It hearkens to a bygone era....but sadly a bad storm deprived us of the pleasure for many years.  The restoration has been remarkable!  What a jewel! A wonderful, low tech way to spend a few hours, their collection exceed the previous one.   Don't miss it.
author: Katherine F.

description: I paid 7 bucks. 7 bucks so I could walk around a building slightly bigger than my house and look at flowers. I'm not angry, it just seems like I could have just gone to a cemetery if I wanted to see flowers.
author: Jarred D.

description:
This place is great. Went for the first time this weekend on a Sunday  Afternoon...Despite being a Sunday (that had relatively great weather) the place was not crowded! Even if you are not huge on plants/flowers, there are so many interesting things to see and learn in here. Moreover, though it is not very big, every room offers a different experience and you should check it out at LEAST once. There was a fact that in the foyer that said this whole place originally came in a crate in a kit of some sort...pretty ridiculous and crazy, yeah?

Went to the butterfly exhibit, and it was pretty amazing. Aside from the children thinking that they were badasses for picking up the butterflies  (which every sign strictly warns against doing) the exhibit was quite fascinating. My friend and I had purchased the butterfly guide from the front (very inexpensive) and were able to identify almost all of the butterflies in it. It made the exhibit almost like a hunt, not to mention we learned about the species we were looking at. I call this the point where you get a "nerdection."

Anyways, this place is super cheap to get in, and its very interesting. Every room had a completely different range of plants to display, so you got the whole gamut of  species. Stay away from the glass signs...although there are so many interesting facts that the conservatory could choose to display, they for some reason thought facts like "palm trees generally grow in warm areas" and "people of South America primarily grow bananas" were the most fruitful facts that could enlighten young learners...epic fail.

anyways, had a great time, check it out!
author: Samantha R.

description:
Like one of the earlier reviewers, I was underwhelmed.  Basically, three rooms of plants, that may or may not be in bloom depending on the time of year you go.  The only plants in bloom on my recent visit were just a few orchids.  There aren't that many plants housed in the conservatory, really.  The beautiful building looks much bigger from the outside than it does on the inside.  Plus, it's pricey at $5 for city residents and $7 for the rest.

There may have been a time when the plants would have truly impressed.  Now, it looks like they shop Safeway for their orchids.  I think people's front yards in some Bay Area neighborhoods have more impressive botanical specimens.

And they need to get rid of that toy train set with the San Francisco landscape.  First, the plants look like bonsai bought at Chinatown for $5.99 and the San Francisco landmarks look very cheesy, in part because the plants look cheap.

The park should have a single ticket for all the areas that require paid admission.  After spending a bunch on the family's tickets for the conservatory, we decided to save our money on the tea garden, to avoid being disappointed twice on the same day.
author: jeffrey k.

description:
James Lick is my Man

A huge thanks to James Lick who was so inspired while traveling that he had this Victorian greenhouse building brought to San Jose.  Unfortunately for SJ, he got dissed and shelved the project.  Eventually it was built in SF instead and today stands a glorious display of plant life and flowers to enjoy.  These are tropic plants so be prepared for warm rooms with high humidity worthy of your bikini.  I asked why the clear glass windows appeared white and learned that they periodically white-wash the glass to keep the UV levels down and protect the plants from sunburn.  Out of the some 1,700 plant species here, the collection of high-altitude orchids, towering banana trees and the aquatic plants room with giant water lilies are highlights.  Even though it would have been more convenient for me if it had landed in SJ, the setting among the flowers, palm trees and friendly lawn with many dogs and kids at play is perfect, so thanks Mr. Lick!
author: Laurie H.

description:
I risk my masculinity 5-starring this place, but it's just too ingrained in my memory. 

I used to come here as a kid and it's nice to see it's as grand as ever a flower hut can be.

Go when they have special events, like that butterfly thing. More bang for your buck that way.
author: Keane L.

description:
It's just one of those things-- when you're around flowers to want to talk. 

"Do you believe in me?" I asked Jack. 
He's needed a haircut for weeks now. Brown, curly hair swept across his eyes. 

"I think we should be together. Don't you?" he replied, let go of my hand. His seriousness surprised me. 

"I was talking about work. There's this scene where I'm not sure the girl should stay or leave Montana. It's cheesy to have an epiphany somewhere she'd only been to for the first time. The city-girl journey into nature's too campy," I said. 

I know my faults: how I can talk about work so much.


Jack and I went over to a lamppost near a circular garden bed. We sat at a bench.
 
He was giddy. We were around until midnight.
author: Jenny T.

description:
I needed a place to park some visitors for a few hours on Thanksgiving. And my hero Mia S. came to the rescue with this recommendation. Thanks Mia S.!!!

As most people say, the building is really beautiful. The best part to me was that it was Thanksgiving, a nice day in SF, and it wasn't crowded. The park was fairly crowded, but not many people actually inside the Conservatory. Guess they all wanted to be outside. It was cool to see all the plants and everything. I thought it was bigger, but it's a nice little stroll around.
author: The Sock S.

description:
I have lived here for 2 years now and have walked through the park a few times and never really checked this place out. I have always admired the outside landscape. It makes you feel as if you are walking towards a palace. Ironically after entering, I found it sort of smaller than my imagination was hoping for. However I did like what I saw.

My favorites were these blue flowers, not light purple, not faded purple, but actually blue flowers. (I don't remember their name) Its something so simple but something so uncommon, it just struck me I guess. Too bad these are on a special exhibit so they will probably get rotated out.  However the other regulars were good too, especially the giant orchids,very bright yet hard to get a close look at because they were way up high. 

Enjoyable overall. I might actually start going here on a monthly basis. Its a good place to practice some camera work and capture some deep colors. For 5 bucks not a bad deal. i just wish it were a little bigger, then again if you take the fact that it is inside of golden gate park I guess it goes a lot farther.
author: Greg G.

description:
The Conservatory of Flowers can be summed up with one word: charming. Its Victorian construction gives the place a sense of whimsy, and the flowers are gorgeous! It's well worth the $5 admission price.

An added bonus is the wonderful garden out front. It's a great place to lounge on nice days. You can relax in the middle of rows of flowers and watch kids rolling down the hills in front of the CoF. Check it out!
author: David H.

description:
I try to save this spot for times when things are really not going well at all. It has a remarkable ability to save me from disaster. 

If I come here in the morning, on a weekday, when it isn't very crowded, and watch the plants get misted, I really can't freak out about anything. I especially like the room with the giant lake that is always really warm. That place was built for bad days! 

They are always having special exhibits, but they really don't need them. The conservatory is magic and it will remind you of the limitless beauty of the world.
author: H G.

description: Great Entrance price. After my student discount and city resident discount, I paid a whopping $3.00 to enter this 100 year old historic piece of Golden Gate Park.  I took the free guided tour. I bought a few things in the gift shop.
author: Infodiva B.

description: Pretty awesome place to kill and hour or two. I took my girlfriend here to see some "killer flowers." There was an exhibit that had all the flowers that caused some kind of death throughout the years. Some deadly to the touch to death on ingestion. It's a great place to take pictures and i saw a wedding there so i guess it's a nice place to have a wedding. There is a small entrance fee. I had my student ID so i got a small discount. Parking was the most pain in the buns, but i went on a weekend so it was expected.
author: Garrett L.

description:
Try to drink a ton of liquids before going here, the indoor exhibit is very humid. The outdoor flower displays are nice and if you go during this time of year, you can see the beautiful outdoor dahlia garden. 

If you love photography, bring your camera, The dahlia area is beautiful to photograph, as well as the outdoor flower displays and the conservatory itself. If you're driving to Golden Gate Park and entering from the West entrance, I would turn right on the street just before the conservatory to park on the road behind it. Its so convenient and I always have success finding parking. Of course, I lock all my doors and don't drive a car I'm too worried about being broken into. So far, my car has been fine though.
author: Francine S.

description: Beautiful collection of flowers, good special exhibits and very educational
author: Lotta F.

description: This place gets 5 stars for the building and 3 stars for the flora.  It's not huge, so manage your expectation, and simply look to be captivated by a few special species that call out to you.   Apparently, you can rent the space for weddings and such...though, if your hair is like mine, consider the frizz factor before planning any major event.
author: L W.

description: Lots of really cool plants. An easy place to walk through. Is hot in some of the rooms but its really cool to see some of the interesting plants. I would recommend it!
author: Jen B.

description:
When Mark and I went on a road trip to S.F. last May we squished as much as we could into the visit. We came here the morning before driving back and it ended up being one of the best memories. The carnivorous plant exibit had just opened and was worth the delay of getting home. The variety was plentiful and I loved how close we could get to them to see all the ways the plants eat up their victims
. 
I lalso oved their lotus flower pond and the overgrown wildness of the plants hanging overhead as you brush past. I also learned useless but interesting facts, like that vanilla beans come from orchids, so it wasn't just an exercise at looking at pretty things, but educational too!
author: Ayelet I.

description:
The Conservatory is located in Golden Gate Park.  It consists of several rooms, each with various types of plants.  There is one room in particular that is much colder than the others, because the plants are usually up in the cold mountains.  So that was cool to walk through there and feel like you're up in some mountain.  I liked the water plants room the best.  I'm a huge fan of water lilies, lotus flowers, etc.  Made for great photos.  This is probably a place to go to once or twice.  Student price is $5, so that's not too bad at all.  

They also had some wicked plants thing going on, so that was cool.
author: R R.

description:
Okay, here's the break down: 
Conservatory of Flowers rating: 5
Stanlee Gatti installation rating: 1 (and I would give it zero, if that were possible)

Conservatory of Flowers, what were you thinking? I don't care how famous Stanlee Gatti may be in the Bay Area. The "ONE: An Earth Installation" exhibit is so contrived and cliché I didn't know whether to laugh or demand my ticket money back. Stanlee, did you consider including any LIVING elements in your tribute to life on Earth? The ludicrous "Tree of Life" sculpture (constructed basically from bric-a-brac found in the Michael's Craft Store clearance section) looked like a high school art class' attempt at conceptual sculpture. And you can thank Martha Stewart for the inspired giant dried moss-covered Styrofoam balls and polished river rock piles. And the blue circle stickers covering the conservatory windows---whatever you were going for here, it's not happening. Lastly, nothing is more irritating than a white guy pandering Native American spirituality. Gross! 

DO go to the Conservatory of Flowers, especially on a cold rainy winter day. 
But wait until the Stanlee Gatti installation has been replaced to get your money's worth.
author: Elina R.

description:
I love the building and the grounds! Oh yeah, and the green stuff inside. The dahlia garden is in full amazing bloom. There must be at least 50 varieties, pretty spectacular. I don't always love the special shows, Chomp, eh, okay. The orchid show was cool, missed the butterflies, sadly.
The interior is so cool. Lots of alien looking plants, lots of orchids, some steamy areas. Some great metal work! There is a giant lily pad done in iron work that is phenomenal. 
I love hanging out on the lawn also.
author: C B.

description:
I went here with my friend, Jen but it definitely has potential for romance.  I would recommend coming on a beautiful day with a beautiful date and having a picnic in the park afterwards.  Hey maybe I'll do that soon!  Oh wait, I will have to wait until spring when it's warm again.
The orchid collection exhibited brought me to a tropical rainforest - I felt like I had travelled across the globe.  This place will definitely make you smile :)
author: Lauren C.

description:
I walked in, and I COULD BREATHE AGAIN!  ahhhh, moisture....  Desert-natives may be uncomfortable in such a pleasant atmosphere.

If you like pitcher plants, and we love them, then you will love this place.  Huge, small, pretty, and not so pretty.  We never could tell which orchid was the vanilla, but we spotted other ingredients we use all the time.  The water garden at one end is gorgeous.  Too bad the huge lily pads are gone.  And there's one coconut on display that, well, I can't describe properly in an all-ages forum.

It's a lot of fun craning over and back and spotting new things every time you look at the same spot.  Really inexpensive for SF.  The downside is finding parking in Golden Gate Park if you drive.
author: Jason R.

description:
Please note. I am only typing this for my dog who wanted to write his own review...

Dear Conservatory of Flowers,

I like when I come here once a week. I like to walk around and sniff all the pretty flowers. I like to sit on the pretty steps while my mom takes my picture. I even liked the nice Australian dudes that asked my mom out, although she was not impressed, I did let them pet me. I do have one bone to pick with you. I do not like the children who have enough space to run after me on the lawns. It is unecessary as I am only 7 lbs. (please refer to photos) I'd rather them pick your flowers or jump off your pretty little bridge.

Thank you.
Weezer.
author: LJ S.

description: This place was beautiful.  There were so many gorgeous plants and flowers.  I enjoyed this place very much.  At times certain areas could be very hot and muggy, but that is the nature of the environment needed for the plants to grow.  My favorite part was the lily pond.
author: Brandy H.

description:
One of my favorite places in the City. The Conservatory of Flowers is one tranquil oasis.  I imagine being surrounded by the splendid display of enchanting flora in their native lands; the humidity wrapping me up in warmth, the butterflies gently landing on my clothes.  Aaaah. 

Since I have this wretched flu and can't make it further than my bed right now, I'll settle for the memory.
author: Sandrita R.

description: Beautiful conservatory. The grounds around the conservatory are very beautiful as well, especially with the Dahlias.
author: Eva B.

description:
Gorgeous building, fantastic plants.  While the space itself and its collection may seem small, several things expand the Conservatory beyond these bounds...

For one, almost every plant is a trip in itself.  If you look closely at an orchid, or a banana flower, or a venus flytrap, you'll keep asking more questions than you started with.

Second, the programming here is really great.  Go to their special events, especially the night time ones with catering and music, and don't miss when they have really wild stuff, like the blooming corpse flower!

Finally, the architecture and design are totally charming.  The price of a year's membership is so cheap, I recommend just getting that so you can stop in whenever you're at the park... it pays off almost immediately.
author: Jessica M.

description:
BEAUTIFUL PLACE
A must see when you are in san fransisco. The garden is pretty big and has a wide variaety of flowers. My mom loved this place. She loves flowers! Theres other areas to the park too but this part is a definate must go. Its somewhat of a romantic area to walk and look around. I suggest going here.
author: Andre W.

description:
From the outside, the conservatory looks like something out of Willie Wonka's Chocolate Factory; inside, it's a jungle filled with orchids, fruited trees, tangled vines, and giant pitcher plants. My favorite was the aquatic room, which reminded me of the underground garden in Nausicaa of the Valley of the Wind. 

Anyway, being inside the conservatory is like taking a trip to a green oxygen chamber. Totally refreshing!
author: Macheeks ..

description: Really neat- if you haven't seen it you should. At $7.00 per person you are not breaking the bank and the money goes back to the conservatory.
author: Janell D.

description: Their selection of orchids and tropical flowers is splendid!  A must see for any plant enthusiast!
author: Caroline D.

description: Lots of pretties, and not too expensive to get in. I must admit I was a little bit disappointed that they didn't have any Venus Fly Traps for the carnivorous plant exhibit, but they had a lot of other neat things so I'm not too upset.
author: Kathleen P.

description: This place was super cool.  Very beautiful setting with the giant white greenhouse, and while we were there they were hosting a carnivorous plant exhibit.  it was awesome!!  anyway, its definitely worth checking out.
author: Jody P.

description:
The Conservatory of Flowers is one of the gems of San Francisco. From the outside, it's a slice of Victorian England; and when you step inside, you're transported to a tropical jungle. An adult ticket is $5. It's not a big place, but it's worth taking a long and leisurely exploration of the plants and flowers.

I most recently visited on a Saturday. At the California Academy of Sciences across the way, there were long lines to enter the museum and to see its rainforest exhibition. The Conservatory of Flowers is less dazzling technically but more satisfying than the crowded exhibit in the CAS.

Until April 19, 2009, you can view the "Golden Gate Express", a model railroad that runs along some cleverly and whimsically designed models of city landmarks such as Coit Tower and the Ferry Building.

The Conservatory was nearly destroyed by a windstorm in 1995.  We should be grateful that the city was able to save the plants and restore this beautiful old building.
author: Robert S.

description: Maybe we went in the wrong season 'spring', but I did NOT see that many flowers!  It was mostly plants and leaves!  I figure if you're gonna have 'flowers' in your name that you will have lots of beautiful flowers to look at!  Well fortunately, we bought a groupon, so this trip wasn't entirely a waste.  We were out within 45 minutes.  It was educational reading the info on plants,  who knew that they could be more dangerous than an electrical outlets babies?!   The ppl at the info booth were very helpful with directions around the park.
author: Albert L.

description:
This is a great little oasis on a cold day.  The permanent portions of the conservatory still enchant me, as I am always game for looking at the odd pistol and stamen.  It's pg rated for family, but it's also fun for dates because if you stare long enough at a paphiopedilum or other sensual looking flowers it will give you naughty thoughts.  Or is that just me?

The orchid exhibit was incredible, and the stanlee gatti exhibit is worth a look too.
author: James M.

description:
My husband and I got married at the Conservatory of Flowers, and we were thrilled about it!  What a gorgeous venue.

Also, the Conservatory's event planning coordinator (Morgan Davis) was *fantastic*.  She was extremely responsive, helpful, enthusiastic, and accommodating.  We really enjoyed working with her.  She and the Conservatory staff really went out of their way to make it a special day for us.
author: Abby L.

description:
It's very beautiful inside, but $5 is a bit much for a place that's so small. There are only 3 or 4 rooms of flowers (granted, there are lots of flowers) but that's still more than I'd prefer to spend.

I really like the water plant room and the orchids that seem to be everywhere in the building. You see a lot of flowers that you wouldn't normally find elsewhere, which is very nice. Go there for some of their awesome special exhibits... the carnivorous plant exhibit last year was really cool, and the butterflies make me happy

This is easily a 4 star place, but I grew up in an arid environment and the humidity kills me.
author: Stephanie H.

description:
Alright. Did I come in on the wrong day in the wrong season or something? Granted, the place is beautiful to look at. I couldn't help but be excited since I'd been harassing my boyfriend for months to take me there. Now, when they say 'conservatory of flowers', I actually expect FLOWERS. Not exotic plants. 

Yes, the plants are beautiful and sensational, and ooh look - an orchid! Oh, look, another orchid! ... Oh, another orchid ... where are the other flowers? .. oh, yay .. another ... orchid -- OH A BUTTERFLY! 

That was me. 

That's not to say that it was a complete disappointment, staring at all the different-sized plants was amazing. Like the leaves that looked about as huge as J-Lo's ass, god that was awesome. But I was kind of disappointed since the only flowers that I really saw were orchids ... tons of orchids ... some carnations, I believe. Little ... tiny ... flowers. 

I wanted to see a more eclectic variety. I wanted to see miles and miles of daies, different-colored roses, tulips, lilies, sunflowers ... flowers imported from another country - hell, even another planet. 

So eh. It could've been better in my opinion.
author: Thea G.

description: Not impressed. The building looks very nice from the outside and the lawn is very nicely put together. That's it. The interior of the building is very small, dated, and looks dirty. Windows are not clean, actually they are filthy, and the floor is cement and cracked. And when I went some back doors were propped open exposing trash and other throw away items behind the building.The plants themselves are nicely arranged but everything else just overshadowed that in my opinion. The staff seemed friendly and available. But it's just not worth paying anything to go here. Don't bother. Frankly, I was shocked by the condition of this place. And that Chomp exhibit that was on display when I visited was nothing special. It was just bunch of plants thrown in a dirty, dark corner of the building with some sound effects and large paper mâché props that looked like they were made in a high school art class. And many of the plants were very small and in dirty looking fish tanks. Anyone who thinks the Conservatory of Flowers is great or gave it five stars has never been to a real conservatory or botanical garden in my opinion.
author: L. A.

description:
If you go by stars, you'd think I didn't really like the Conservatory. I did! It's just there isn't alot here and it feels like 5 stars would be too "big" for it. I love the outside of the building and the lily pond indoors. It is very impressive that they managed to keep the old tree in the center after the last Conservatory was destroyed and built the existing building around the tree. 

For the money, this is a great little trip, but . . . little. I've seen some very amazing Conservatories in other cities so I have to give this only 3 stars - but I do recommend visiting it.
author: Sarcastic T.

description: I still love the Conservatory of Flowers.  The building is absolutely gorgeous and the flowers are beautiful.  We came yesterday during Family Appreciation Day so all families with children under 18 yo get in for free.  With the current economy, even saving $5 for admission is a big deal.  Especially if it's for a bunch of adults, then the $5 for each person adds up.  But anyway, we went to check out the Golden Gate Express exhibit.  Two miniature trains zip around a model of San Francisco.  They have a lot of notable San Francisco buildings made out of recycled materials.  The Ferry Building was made out of coffee stirrers, forks, spoons, etc.  It was pretty cool.  The nephew was a little disappointed though.  I guess we had hyped it up so much that he had been expected life size trains.
author: Kris L.

description: Had a great trip here today - $5 for residents is a bargain. Great Wicked Plants exhibit (that's what got me there after seeing the posters around town). Really nice place. Ended my wander round the park by listening to the GG Band - treat!
author: Jo D.

description:
I like this place because the building is practically an antiquity, being one of the first of its kind on the West Coast.  There is definitely that old-time atmosphere present.

However, I wasn't delighted so much by what I saw plantwise.  The building is kind of dim and the plants look like they are struggling for life in some cases.  They had some orchids which were interesting, but again they did not appear in good health.  It did not take all that long to walk throughout the pavilion and be finished.

The butterfly section looks like it would be a good place to amaze children.
author: Femita J.

description:
This is one of those spots that I don't visit often, but when I do I'm always amazed.

We went to the Butterfly Zone and it was really cool. There were butterflies everywhere and a really neat glass frame with the cocoons in them. I saw 3 butterflies hatch (pretty neat). The bonus was this little boy who couldn't have been more than 7 who knew everything about butterflies and told us about the hatching process and all of the parts of the butterfly that had landed on my hand. 

I didn't spend too much time in the rest of the building as my little girl was teething and a little tired and a little warm from the glasshouse. 

I will definitely return soon. Well worth the $5 admission.
author: J B.

description:
Like most people that are from Northern California I have never ridden a cable car and I have never been inside the house of flowers. I did buy an HD camcorder so I may take some footage here.

I work out with Koi fitness right outside though.
author: William H.

description:
I love this place!  The building itself is an amazing example of a Victorian era conservatory.  One of my dreams is to have a greenhouse.  Until that happens  I visit the Conservatory a couple times a year and enjoy the lush green plants and vivid blooms. 
The damage from one of our wild Northern California storms caused the closure of the Conservatory for a few years and a major renovation was completed.  The small entrance fee (about the cost of a Starbucks coffee) helps keep it open for future enjoyment.
author: Rosemary B.

description:
I think the exterior of the building and the flowers outside, in addition to the name, made me think there would be way more flowers inside.  Perhaps my visions of a Willy Wonka like room with flowers (instead of candy) as far as the eye could see was too much. 

I walked through the conservatory quickly as a once over (it is pretty small) and then waited for one of the free tours so I could get a more thorough understanding of what I was seeing. The conservatory certainly has a variety of very interesting plants, many of which do have flowers, but many which don't (or at least, they're all not in bloom at the same time, which is understandable). I think it is laid out very nicely, with a different theme for each room. Some of the orchids are very delicate and lovely - the bat orchid is very cool. I'm glad I took the tour because the tour guide pointed out things I wouldn't have noticed otherwise.

I did also go to the Wicked Plants exhibit which was there and I didn't like it very much. I found it over-crowded, a bit too theme-y, and I was annoyed by how much text was on the signs. Each interesting plant had this whole story and all I really wanted was a clear sign that said what kind of plant it is and how it could hurt you. I don't need a whole short story that's trying to be clever. Just give it to me plain and simple.
author: Amy L.

description: This place is oddly comforting to me.  I usually find Controlled Nature to be disturbing, but somehow it works in this unique setting.  It's a beautiful old building, and the lilly pond is breathtaking.  It's not the best value you'll ever get, but I think it's worth seeing.
author: Peter Z.

description:
The place is surprisingly small.  I had looked at interior maps before heading out there and was a little amazed.

FYI, according to the brochure, it is the oldest glass and wood built conservatory in North America.

The waterlilies were huge!  The showcase right now is carnivorous plants.  Did you know there are some that eat animals underwater.  ::Shudder::  Cool.
author: Susan C.

description: Rather small and limited.  Waited 25 minutes to see a glorified greenhouse.  Good thing I had a "Go San Francisco" Card that included admission.  Recommend taking some pictures of the building and/or outside the building and then moving on to the other offerings at Golden Gate Park.
author: A. L.

description: I thought this would be a neat experience, but overall it was pretty boring.  A couple of interesting plants, but it could have been way better.  It was great since it was free, but I wouldn't want to pay for this.  I can't remember which days are free, but make sure and look that up before coming.
author: Jonathan U.

description: Every time I go here, I feel like I'm in some British romantic movie.  The humid room is always so beautiful, the water is breathtaking.  True this place can be walked through in a matter of minutes, but the key is to take your time look at the plants and smell some of the plants.
author: Michelle M.

description: Nice little green house.  Worth doing while visiting Golden Gate Park.  We happened to catch the free tour at 11am on Saturday which added extra value to our visit.  Even without the tour, I love trying to stop in when I visit to see what's blooming.
author: Melissa H.

description: Not artist-friendly if you were thinking about drawing there. It's a shame. People I know who like to periodically draw there go out of their way to be considerate and observe the rules but the staff makes it hard. Artists are told the only place they can sit is on benches when they're all wet from having just been watered. Pathways out of the way of traffic where artists have sat are blocked. With each visit another constraint is added to their rules for artists and they police your movements while you're there.
author: joanne m.

description:
WOW - The outside of the building is so impressive - I love the colored stained glass windows against the white gingerbread details. 

Go inside and experience something you never thought you would encounter in San Francisco - all varieties of lowland and highland tropical plants, aquatic plants - the water lilies are to die for -- and potted plants. The temperature is controlled depending on which environment you enter - be ready for humidity!! There were so many varities of orchids -- it was breathtaking!

The best place in the city to take your favorite "green thumb"!
author: Mariangela S.

description:
This is one of the stops on my Tour of SF that I give to visiting friends & family, so I've been here a number of times.  Sometimes I've come away awed, others I was rather disappointed.  It depends on the season, I suppose.  I recommend you ask the person working the ticket booth what's in bloom and what the special exhibit is to decide if  it's worth going in.

If you do make the trip -- try to go on Sunday early afternoon -- there's usually a jazz band (anywhere from 2 to 6 people) playing in the underpass directly in front of the Conservatory.
author: Eugene F.

description:
A lovely relaxing place to visit.  Plus, even when it's cold and rainy or foggy outside, it's still a jungle in here.

When the carnivorous plant exhibit was here, I had some great conversations with the little old lady volunteers.  They cheerfully pointed out the hideous giant bugs (cockroaches?) that had fallen to their doom in the larger pitcher plants.  These ladies are AWESOME.
author: Jess L.

description: This place is such a Bay Area treasure. It is only $5 for adult and $3 if you got a Student I.D So many beautiful plants and flowers inside and outside! It's just so beautiful and amazing, I highly recommend going if you haven't experienced it yet! Definitely one of my favorite places in the bay.
author: Lynn C.

description:
Beautiful place to spend an hour or so, even with kids. Today we went with my two kids and there was a wonderful train installation surrounded by gorgeous flowers. The gardens in front were beautifully maintained as well, while the structure itself is beautiful and can actually be regarded as historic as it was build in the last 1800's.  
Nothing incredible or memorable per se but a lovely pit stop while you explore Golden Gate Park. 

Just a 10 minute walk from the De Young and the brand spanking new Academy of Sciences
author: Rob G.

description:
This place rocks!  I just wished it was a wee bit bigger because even with walking around at the speed of the slowskys my date and I were able to cover everything in just about (under) one hour.

Ahem.  Going back to the date thing, this is a great place for dates y'all.  Well, that's if you like the outdoors but don't want to take a long drive for fear your date may be a serial killer.  (not from personal experience!)

But again, totally awesome place.  If I can save up enough money, I would definitely consider it as my wedding venue.  With the same date?  Maybe.  =P
author: Yohanna B.

description: We lucked out to visit on a "slow" day and get Don as our docent. He asked us if we had any questions, and we asked him instead, "Tell us about your favorite plants here". He gave us tons of info and lots of interesting anecdotes on everything from the banana tree (not a tree but an herb) to orchids. We brought our IDs and got the resident rate coupled with the senior rate. Can't beat $3!
author: Paula H.

description:
A good place to go on a cold foggy day, not so much on a hot sunny day. The conservatory is a glass building that is hot and humid for the plant, not so good for your hair. 

The temperature aside, this is a fantastic place to visit. They are currently running an exhibit on carnivorous plants, very interesting. The tropical orchids are also very beautiful. Bring a picnic and enjoy lunch in the beautiful gardens adjacent to the greenhouse.
author: Kelly P.

description:
I really enjoy this peaceful oasis. I was there recently (I wish I remembered which day) and there were very few visitors. It was a relaxing visit with beautiful plants to see. I chilled in the tropical room and just thought about life. Parking was very easy near the Dahlia dell.

Update: I just wanted to add that an average person will spend 2 hours here AT MOST. I don't know how some people can spend the day there!
author: Marina N.

description:
The Conservatory of Flowers is my favorite place in the city. During Bay to Breakers, it's the perfect backdrop for all those cute group photos. The contrast between the beautiful building and the gardens with all the scandalous costumes always amuses me. After the group photo, there are some great bushes surrounding the building where you can relieve yourself in the absence of clean restrooms that day. 

On a day when you want to venture inside the building, you will be entering a different world. The standard exhibits are fabulous but the rotating special exhibits are great too. Chomp! was fun and educational - did you know there are some carnivorous plants that can eat small monkeys and frogs? Poor little guys.

The absolute best part though is the dahlia garden outside which is free to visit. Visit in the late summer, early fall and be prepared to be amazed. Great place for a picnic and a date.
author: Cher E.

description: One of San Francisco's finest jewels. A classical and romantic building, overflowing with beautiful plants and flowers. An especially wonderful place to visit on a cold, rainy day - it's like entering a tropical oasis!
author: Alison S.

description: I've never seen so many live orchids in my life. I love how one room was really humid, it made me feel like I was in Hawaii. I could stay here for hours. Some of the flowers, plants and trees were very familiar, it reminded me of my mom 's garden. Don't get me wrong there were a lot of flowers I've never seen like spiky trunk tree and the spiral hanging plant.
author: Marie G.

description:
I've done some of my best thinking while in the COF. It's probably has something to do with the oxygen-rich environment. 

I'm not a flower-child hippie of the dirty sort, but I do admire cool shit. The COF has never disappointed in the "Cool Shit" department. 

I went to the butterfly exhibit last year, which was pretty cool. They had a little larvae hatching station that we could see the little cocoons vibrating. We were anticipating seeing a hatching, but nah...apparently the process takes longer than we expected. 

If you are a photographer and have skills....this is a good place to get some serious photos. 

This is also a great place to take family or friends that are visiting. It's a historic SF spot, and offers an experience you can't find in places like...Merced, Truckee, Fresno, Bakersfield, Colinga, Stockton, Los Banos,  Paso Robles, King City, Wasco..........
author: Dee J.

description:
It's hands-down beautiful here. The outside more so than inside. We went when they had a little exhibit of carnivorous plants, it was the best thing there. The "normal" stuff isn't anywhere close to as exciting.

It was only 4 or 5 dollars to get in which is good because it was incredibly small inside. It took us around a half an hour to go through the entire thing and then some. It was overall disappointing because it was so brief. Even though it was cheap to get in I wouldn't pay again to walk in the small circle.

Although, we saw them setting up for a wedding inside and it looked absolutely breathtaking. Maybe I'd kill to get married there? 

The gardens in front and the building itself is stunning and one of my favorite parts of the city
author: Sydney T.

description:
This place, for three bucks with a student ID, is a strange, amazing place.  Apparently, they have more non-dirt-requiring plants than many other collections.  AND someone has a wonderful sense of humor with those plastic frogs.

Five stars would have been amply given if we hadn't seen a butterfly nearly die at the merciless blades of the overhead fans on our visit this weekend.  Surely there is a way to keep air moving without such danger!

The immediate grounds are really nice, too, and pleasant for a sit in the sunshine.
author: KJ M.

description: This place is a gorgeous, inexpensive way to spend a lovely afternoon in the world famous Golden Gate Park. I have to admit, I was a little skeptical at first. I thought it was going to be the type of place that only your grandma or local horticulturalist would genuinely appreciate. But it is so beautiful that I believe anyone would enjoy it! I went during the carnivorous plant exhibit which was very intriguing. It was a little smaller than I expected, but nevertheless a spectacle.They had a pretty wide variety of species, and even your standard venus fly trap was anything but average: They grow in armies! In the end my favorite part of the regular conservatory exhibit was the gigantic lily pads. If only I could have stood on them to truly test their rumored strength....
author: Katie S.

description:
Wow.  Want to go photo crazy?  Goto the conservatory of flowers.  You can take millions of pictures there while looking at some spoiled plants.  If I was a flower, I'd want to live at the conservatory.  

It's really small, but really pretty inside.  It's pretty humid so be prepared to take some layers off.  

Okay, the butterflies.  Stephie had this fantasy about this room where hundreds of exotic butterflies would flutter around her and land in her hair and on her arms, decorating her like beautiful fairy jewelry.  Well, guess what.  They wanted nothing to do with her.  Although, they didn't seem to mind if you wanted to look at them up close or snap some photos.  But, they won't even land on your measly little harmless finger.  They're only going to be there for a limited time, so what are you waiting for?

All-in-all it was a nice little trip.  Everyone should go once, atleast.

Mikey says it's cool.
author: Steph and Mike A.

description: This is hands down one of my favorite places in SF! I have been here many, many times and am rarely dissapointed. The flowers are always beautiful and so much fun to photograph. The staff is kind and parking is easy. This is definitely a place that you must visit!
author: Heidi S.

description:
If you love plants, model trains and the imaginative use of recycled materials, you just have to go see the new Golden Gate Express exhibit at the Conservatory of Flowers.  I had so much fun and I'm old.  It is for kids of all ages.

http://www.conservatoryofflowers.org/insidetheconservatory/special.htm
author: Marten E.

description: Great way to kill an hour. Truly beautiful collection of flora and our son especially liked the special exhibit of carnivorous plants. The downside is I wish they had more detailed information on the plants they have throughout the structure. A lot of things had no signage at all. That said if you are going to Golden Gate Park this is definitely a place to check out if you've got some extra time.
author: David H.

description:
i love love love this place!

always drove by and never bothered to check it out thinking it was going to be expensive but it's only $5 admission! $3 if you're a student! 

i can spend hours in here admiring the flowers and taking pictures. the variety of flowers in here is absolutely amazing. my favorite is the lotus pond. it's just so beautiful and calming. definitely a place to visit. might be a cute date place too =)
author: Minda w.

description: Wow, this place is amazing. Gorgeous, historic building with some of the craziest bits of nature you will ever see. Right now there's a seasonal exhibit: a train setup running through a San Francisco made of all things recycled. And only $3 for students, $5 (I think) for other folk! Go! Now!
author: Allison L.

description: Parents were in town and it was the perfect place to take them for a walk around to see a variety of exotic plants and flowers.  It's usually $5 to get in but it's free every first Tuesday of the month. There are 3-4 main rooms to explore and filled with so much to see.  Warning: Since it's mostly tropical flora, it's humid and warm inside.  You may want to wear layers so you're not too uncomfortable.  The staff are very knowledgeable and welcome any questions.  This place is definitely a city gem.
author: Nina L.

description:
Pretty cool place.   I wish it could have had more plants for the price of admission, considering how quickly we were in and out.

Otherwise it was really interesting to see the different rooms with varying humidity and temperature, some really interesting plants from certain parts of the world.  Really liked seeing those pods that capture and kill small animals and insects, and the lily pads, and kumkuats.

The special exhibit was kinda useless, I'd rather see another room full of interesting plants!
author: Dan H.

description: I was a little disappointed in that I could probably see almost as many varieties of plants at the Home Depot. Some of the plants were really common species. The orchids were pretty and I liked how lush the room with plants hanging from the trees felt. If you love plants and have someone fun to go with you, it's still worth it.
author: Elicia S.

description:
A trend of botanical gardens began in Europe in the late 17th century, as a way of displaying the beautiful plants and flowers that were collected from around the world. It was a way of feeling the sophistication of being world traveled and exotic. Expeditions were sent out with botanists in tow, to gather plants, and as a result many plants were identified and named. Much of our taxonomic knowledge, and the start of modern botany owe some of their modern form to the worldy aspirations of 17th century europeans. (Zoos began in very much the same way).
The Conservatory of Flowers, built in 1878, is a gorgeous (and restored in 2003) example of the beautiful greenhouses that were constructed during the 17th, 18th, and 19th centuries to display exotic plants and flowers. This one is built in a dramatic victorian style, and is one of the architectural highlights of the golden gate park. It's a must see.
Visitors notes: It tends to get hot, so going on a hot/humid/crowded day may not be the most pleasant experience unless you layer. The carnivourous plants and orchid exhibits were extremely nice.
Parking in golden gate park is restricted/annoying, so just be paitient and try to find something in the Haight.
More historical information here: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Golden_Gate_Park_Conservatory_of_Flowers

Free first Tuesday of every month.

This buildling made the 2007 Best 25 Buildings of the American Institute of Architects
author: Kat C.

description:
neat structure. while i was not overly impressed by the variety of plants in the conservatory, i very much enjoyed the serenity and fresh air, and left feeling enlivened and rejuvinated. of course who wouldnt prefer canopying in the jungle, even so i appreciate this beautiful escape from my routine. entrance is only $4 and free the first tuesday of the month.

baby, are you reading this?! does wedding reception mean anything to you? hint hint.
author: Ligaya T.

description: So after 20 years of living in the bay area (5 of which were in the city) I finally went into the Conservatory of Flowers. I don't know why I never went before. ( I had been on top of the conservatory many times usually between the house of 1am-3am in a drunken stupor, but that's a completely different store that I won't tell here) Anyway, I've just finished taking a photography class and now I've joined the monthly Salon group. Each time I Say I'm going to get my butt out there and take photos so I have something to share and each time I show up to the group empty handed. The next group is in two weeks so I thought I'd give the conservatory a shot (you can see some of the photos I've upload in the photo section.) It's $7 for adults and $5 for students. The place is rather small, it only took us about 35 minutes to go through the whole exhibit. And we tried to take our time. In that 35 minutes I was able to take around 125 photos. we went on a Saturday around 4PM and it was pretty busy. Lots of other people try to take photos, so sometimes I had to wait my turn. There were a lot of great photo opps and I enjoyed my time there. Not sure I would go back anytime soon. I think one time is plenty unless they change the exhibits.  I think for my next outing  I'll wait until spring and give the botanical gardens a try.
author: Michele H.

description:
My 5 month old boyfriend's mom asked me to  take him somewhere special this morning. Since he doesn't talk and he can't really move around much on his own, we basically just need cool stuff to look at. His mom told me about the Stanlee Gatti exhibit at the Conservatory. The photos on the website made it look grand indeed. So we ambled over to the park with bottles in hand and high hopes in our hearts.
I've seen window displays at Pier One that were more inspiring than Gatti's sparse, contrived, over-the-top minimalist "exhibit". It's competing with the Metreon for the title of Biggest Waste of Space 2006. However, the rest of the Conservatory was out of this world entertaining for the midget and I. We asked for cool stuff to see and the Conservatory knows how to bring it. It's on the small-cramped end of the spectrum but the historic relevance of the site and building add a very charming touch. The water plants room rocked us hard and little munchkin totally had a few "moments" in there where he just stared at the water and grinned to no end. The potted plants room is appropriately located next to the Gatti/special exhihbits room and was only a little more exciting than the window-box herb garden in my mom's kitchen (sorry, mom!). It can be skipped.
The staff were extremely helpful and kind and the tours sounded like they were informative and substantial (though we didn't do the guided tour). There is stroller parking (as strollers are not allowed in the conservatory) and the staff are super nice to miniature visitors. I won't dock them more stars for the whole Gatti shenanigan. After all,  who says no to Stanlee Gatti?
author: Autumn K.

description: Constructed in 1879, this is the oldest glass-and-wood Victorian greenhouse in the Western Hemisphere and home to more than 10,000 plants from around the globe. It was badly damaged by a 1995 storm and closed to the public for eight years, during which time it was restored at a cost of $25 million. Located beneath the dome, in the warmest and most humid section of the building, is the conservatory's prized century-old imperial philodendron. The east wing houses the tropics collection and aquatic plants display, while the west side is dedicated to seasonal flowering plants and educational exhibits. This is one of Golden Gate Park's most popular attractions for good reason. Visit on a midweek afternoon in the winter months to avoid the crowds.
author: Gourmet G.

description:
My mom has a green thumb.  And when I say green, I mean every step, tabletop, and counter is covered with plants, flowers in vases, and budding flora.  And, despite my teasing of my mom and adamant statements that I will not become the crazy plant lady, I have to admit that  I love this place.
The changing exhibits are always cool enough to be engaging and interesting without making me feel like a total dork for reveling in them.  The last one I attended, full of butterflies, was like one of my fantasies when I was a little girl of living in a cloud world surrounded by butterflies flying freely around me (am I sounding a little crazy?!?!?).
And, despite what the humid air does to my frizzy jew-fro, I also love the standing exhibits of the tropical and aquatic plants.  Every time, I'm tempted to climb on the big lilypads and lay on my back and go to sleep, but I don't want to be kicked out or covered in pond scum.    
The best part, is I can walk here on a stressful day, take it all in, and chill.....even if I am becoming the crazy plant lady like my mom.
author: Jessica L.

description:
Overall I really enjoyed the Conservatory of Flowers!  I would go back again and recommend it to anyone!

When you first walk into the building there is a timetable of horticulture & The Conservatory's History. Very interest!

Tons of tropical flowers & plants.

We were lucky enough to run in to an employee.  He seem very interested and passionate about all the plants there. Giving us a mini tour and interesting facts about a few of the plants!  Made the experience even better.

My only suggestion is to go more in the summer.  We went the beginning of May and one the domes was not ready for viewing and the gardens out in front did not have flowers growing yet.
author: Stephanie K.

description:
Gardens have this tendency to remind me of sex and rebirth.  Something about all the orifices, the colors the shapes---you get the picture.  And then you have the room with the butterflies fluttering around drinking in the nectar with their proboscis'.  They use this spiral, straw like appendage off of their head to suck in the sweet juices.  Me and a couple young kids were held captive by some hatching butterflies.  They came out learning to flap their wings.  Their cocoons were amazing.  Some looked like little jewels and others like leaves.  Nature creates the most wondrous things...
But practically speaking:
Inside it is warm---and humid!  The space is not very large but does the job.  I don't really like huge museums because I find them overwhelming.  This one you can visit for about an hour and still feel like there are new things to discover upon your return.  The architecture is odd to me because it seems to be grand from a distance but once you approach it and get close the roofs are actually not that high. The whiteness of it is pretty and makes me feel as though I am traveling through one of the first world's fair exhibits or that I am in candy land.  Either way, I found it fun.  
So, I recommend this place.  It is peaceful.  Witness life, rebirth and yes elements of S-E-X.
author: Lauren S.

description: The building is maybe the most beautiful in San Francisco so go for that alone. The plants inside are typical rainforest which is to say a lot of them are common American houseplants. But there are some great orchids and other Star Trek-y original series blooms so just go. The humid hissing is very soothing.
author: patrick g.

description: Visits to the Conservatory of Flowers have always been transportative (until the inevitable whiny field trip kids interrupt).  Out of two public places I'd want to hide out and sleep in--the conservatory would be one of them.  The only thing they're missing is bird music piped through some hidden speakers.
author: Nobody M.

description: Simply beautiful. I adore this place, I've been going here since I was 2 and it still seems so fresh and clean. I just enjoy the atmosphere and the surroundings of Golden Gate Park. It's a wonderful place for families to enjoy each other's company or a great area for a bike ride also lots of trails for a great walk. Last time I was here I was able to capture a lot of gorgeous shots...The victorian structure is my favorite.
author: Annalynn L.
