description: This is one of my favorite buildings in the city. I am fortunate to drive past it on a daily basis. This past Saturday, I made arrangements for my photography group to photograph here. It was really amazing. Yes, there is the humidity factor but the exhibits are stunning. I highly recommend the Lunar exhibit. Also, a must if you are an orchid fan.
author: Jennifer S.

description:
on a cold day like today the warm humidity of the conservatory is always welcome. it's small, but it's great.  

you can't beat GG park and you can't beat the cool, exotic awesome that is the conservatory. if you're looking to kill an hour before getting some dinner this is a perfect spot to come, browse, and remind yourself just how cool the earth actually is.
author: Dave S.

description: My husband and I enjoyed hiking from the Academy of Sciences to the Conservatory of Flowers (we ended up taking the long way around, walking towards the AIDS Memorial Grove, and then cutting over on a downhill trail that went by a verdant water area). At any rate, once we reached the conservatory itself, I was immediately struck by the architecture of the building--its curving white walls, the beautiful red, green, and blue colored glass pieces,  and the like. It had a pleasant Victorian feel, as it were. As for the flowers themselves, I couldn't help thinking that I would have benefited more had I been sent there for a botany class, or actually knew how to sketch well. My favorite room was the "Special Exhibit" at the end, as it included some gorgeous flora as well as a cityscape rendered from household materials.
author: Beth F.

description: What a wonderful oasis.  As I walked inside, I was transported into a warm, deliciously humid, green palace of restoration.  I really felt enlivened around all the lush foliage.  That free first Tuesday I went, they had a GORGEOUS orchid exhibit.  I saw colors so vibrant, no one but nature could have painted them.  It made me realize I'm due for a trip to Hawaii.
author: M A N I K.

description: As expected, the conservatory of flowers was very green and beautiful! However, it was also very humid (well, one of the rooms was very humid and I know it was humid for the sake of the flowers that were in that room) and I wasn't completely blown away by the plants they had.
author: Narina A.

description: There actually weren't that many different types of flowers to see here. I was actually hoping to see some insects but there were none. Some of the plants and flowers were a little bit dry both inside and outside. Pretty mediocre. Dress in layers because a couple of the rooms are a bit warm.
author: Dijon Y.

description: Ah the Conservatory. One of the most beautiful yet inexpensive activities for everyone in your life.  Looking to impress your date with your sensitive awareness of nature and beauty? Wow her here. Need something for the whole family to do? Terrify you little sister by pointing out all carnivorous plants; shock you mom by talking the father of botany as we know him, Carl Linnaeus, a 1700s Swedish gentleman with a penchant for naming plants after people's privates; inspire your dad to make some backyard renovations. For yourself, it's the cheapest tropical vacation you can take! There's nothing like escaping the wet and dreary SF winters for an hour or two then slipping into the balmy orchid-filled rooms.
author: Camille H.

description: You walk, run, bike, or drive by this beautiful building over and over again. Stop. It's wonderful. The architecture alone is worth going for but inside, it's an exotic and fascinating world of plants. Yes, plants ;).
author: David D.

description:
after being bored with the asian art museum, we decided to go to another free "museum". this was definitely a better stop. 

i LOVE LOVE LOVE flowers. so being in here was fantastic. i just wish i had a better camera to capture all the beautiful orchids. it was a bit crowded, but still worthwhile. careful in the water plants room, it's a really warm and humid, but the pond holding all of plants was amazing.
author: Anh P.

description: This place is perfect to visit on a sunny day. When I walked in I thought I was in a tropical rain forest. Lovely flowers, plants and exhibits.
author: carol s.

description: I decided to spend some time exploring parts of Golden Gate Park I had yet to see.  I saw the signs and followed, and am glad I did.  Its on the small side, but $5 is a great price for what you see.  Beautiful flowers and  plants are obviously everywhere.  The fragrance inside is amazing.  They currently have a special exhibit with butterflies which makes the visit really worthwhile.  Hundreds of butterflies swirl about you in the room, posing on flowers, plants and some even come to rest on you.  Very easy to get loads of great photos.  It was fantastic!
author: Jen K.

description: While I love SF, I get seriously moody when it's foggy & cold for months at a time.  I think I've found a solution in the conservatory of flowers.  For $3 with my student ID (or free the first Tuesday of the month!) I can hang out in a beautiful 90 degree tropical sauna.  I figure that I'll get some of those tear away track pants so I don't freeze on the walk there, find myself a bench, & strip down to shorts & a tee shirt.  I'll pack some sort of tropical beverage in my nalgene, bring my stack of magazines, and be set for hours.  Much cheaper than prozac  or a trip to Hawaii to cure the seasonal affect disorder.
author: Katie S.

description: A treasure. The Dahlia Garden outside is a heartbreakingly beautiful fall experience.
author: Rebecca S.

description: I love this place. it's only $5 to get in, or if you bring student ID, only $3!!! How wonderful. Their flowers are so pretty and i feel kind of zen to be surrounded by them, so I like coming here when I am stressed out.  I also feel great thinking that there are tons of negative ion floating around that plants send out which is very good for your skin. so girls, get your ass over to the conservatory. I like the humidity inside, it feels very tropical. they have special floweres when some events come up, when I went last time, they had chinese new year inspired decoration, and they had some special plants and flowers for it.
author: chihiro i.

description:
i realized some time ago that for some reason i have the kind of face that people always say things like '..dont i know you?" or "excuse me...can you help me _____"   this sort of thing has happened to me my whole adult life.  two days ago, i was sitting, reading a book on a bench in the conservatory, and  in between reading and playing peek a boo with the cutest little kids sitting next to me on said bench , a woman, a tourist, comes up, and the following exchange ensues:

woman: "ma'am do you know where the white house is?"
me: "...uh...im not sure what you mean"
woman: "the white house...here in the park...yes? i need to meet someone at the white house"
me: "  well...THE white house is in washington d.c....buuut this is sort of a white house i guess... do you have a map or somethin?"
woman:  "this must be it...im meeting a friend at the white house"
me:  "ok...well...um..yeah"
woman:  "thank you so much"

when i left the park 2 hours later...she was still waiting for her friend to meet her in front of the white house.   she even came back and asked me if i ever refer to the building at the conservatory as the white house...to which i responded "..i think you should call your friend" 

the truth is,  ive never actually gone inside the actual conservatory of flowers. meaning, the building ("the white house")  behind the beautiful flowers outside.  instead, i have spent many hours and read many books and taken gorgeous pictures while sitting on the benches or laying in the grass.   on the days when san francisco has sunshine that's warm enough to do such a thing, this honestly is one of my favorite places in sf.  and i dont need to pay the admissions fee to know that.  i also enjoy watching the families take pictures, the friends play bocce ball, or the tourists wait for a date that most likely never arrived.
author: hollie m.

description: A beautiful, quiet place to get away from it all.  Lovingly preserved with some gorgeous plants.  They could use a bit better interpretive materials and signage, but it's hard to top this beautiful spot in Golden Gate Park.  Be sure to catch the themed outdoor gardens nearby.
author: Kevin S.

description: This was one of my favorite places when I spent a week in San Fran. It's absolutely amazing, I went back twice with my family. The building itself is really amazing from the outside, and belies the indoor size a bit. The only downside to wandering around and looking at all those beautiful flowers? It can be pretty humid! Oh well, that's the jungle for ya!
author: Irene F.

description: God, this is a slice of nirvana made physical on earth or something. I love just wandering around, peering inside flowers and plants. It's so much cooler to bring yourself really close to the flowers. The patterns...so many patterns. I always end up taking a bajillion pics. I just wish free days had fewer people. I want to take me time alone. I won't be selfish though.
author: Matt L.

description: I am glad I read your Yelp review before I went, because I thought this is a huge place.  It looks big from outside.  The collection of plants aren't that impressive for a plant lover like me. This is more or less close to Home Depot variety.  It is worth to go when there is a special event like the butterflies which are just magical.  They make me feel like a kid again.  The warm humid temp inside is a plus. The ground work outside is more impressive.  Hard to beats a quiet oasis in a busy and foggy city like SF. IF you put your expectation in control, this will be a positive experience.
author: Mar H.

description: What a beautiful place! I think I appreciate this place more because it's one of those places you go to and it makes you happy and in awe of what nature has to offer you.  I never really went here before--just passed by while in the car.  But when you go there you see all the beautiful flowers...Great place to go to spend time with friends, family, kids, yourself, or that special someone...just hope for sunny weather...
author: Mel P.

description: A nice place to escape from your daily routine, especially during the week in the winter when it's not too crowded.
author: Michael R.

description: I love almost anything that grows and almost all old buildings.  The Conservatory was originally ordered as a kit, in the later 19th century, at a time when people were first starting to feel the pinch and pressure of living in cities.  It is small in comparison to similar, modern facilities, but nonetheless beautiful.  When you look closely there is a new mystery to discover everywhere.  The geometry of the plants and flowers is mind blowing.  I am definitely going back.  Once to share the butterfly exhibit with my favorite two year old, and once again by myself, at a time that is not so popular with other people.
author: Amme P.

description: Do you like flowers?  Do you appreciate plants?  Are you a lover of botany?  Then please visit the Conservatory of Flowers.  The staff docents are friendly and very knowledgeable.  The building is gorgeous.  It's a pretty place to spend a Sunday afternoon at.
author: jen n.

description: We paid our $5 admission on a whim, completely unaware that a jungle awaited us inside.  This place is awesome!  Five rooms of various locales are filled with plants from all over - orchids, these crazy carniverous plants that have hanging baskets to catch water and insects, and currently, an entire room devoted to a butterfly exhibit.  What an interesting way to spend an hour.
author: Lauren L.

description: A great place for a date, to impress the in-laws, or to just meditate. If you can, check out the Butterfly Exhibit, but get there early as crowds can make it a bit irritating inside. Be nice to the employees there, they are kind people.
author: nina B.

description:
Reviewing the conservatory as a wedding venue.  We are interested in a one stop shop for both ceremony and reception, anticipating guest list to be ~160 - 180 ppl.

First off, I am a huge fan of the conservatory, it's uniqueness, San Francisco history, and flowers in general.  The conservatory was one my first thoughts as a potential wedding venue.  Luckily, my inquiry was a few days before their annual gala and I was able to check the venue out at night.

The pros:
- The night lighting is exceptional.  The conservatory looks absolutely magical all light up in GG park.  Fairy tale for sure.
- Uniqueness.  Love the idea of a wedding venue that functions as something else by day, and there really is nothing else that comes close for flower lovers in the botanical sense to the conservatory.
- Photo ops.  Countless upon countless photo ops with the gorgeous array of plant life and the conservatory structure itself.  Not to mention GG park.
- You aren't allowed to being many plants, etc, into the conservatory itself (which is understandable due to potential insects etc), but this really isn't an issue because the conservatory is already so decked out in plant life you really wouldn't need to bring much into the structure for decoration (although the orchid gallery is a different story).
- Morgan, the rental manager is very sweet and totally helpful with event inquiries etc. 

The deal breakers:
- Capacity.  Only ceremonies of 50 ppl or less can be accommodated within the conservatory structure.  Supposedly the new orchid gallery can accommodate 150, although it seems like that would be tight once you consider a dance floor and bar.  Anything over this and you're looking at jerry rigging some tent to tent action which seemed complicated.
- The grates in the walkways.  Ladies, am I glad I toured this space in my stilettos as I was on my tiptoes the whole time to avoid falling into the grates which line the walkways through the conservatory.  While this was noticeable, although not un-do-able for an hour, I think this would get super old for my guests, if not outright dangerous, especially after a few cocktails.
- The narrow walkways and the dripping humidity in the gorgeous room with the carnivorous plants and lilly pads.  This is my favorite room as a visitor to the conservatory, yet when viewing from a bridal perspective I was ultra sensitive to the condensation water drops from the ceiling every few minutes.  Water spots on your gown = not cool in photos.  Also,  I could not really imagine navigating those narrow moss laden walkways in the other rooms in a large gown.
- The port a potty bathroom situation and the walkway from conservatory to orchid gallery.  This was the ultimate deal breaker for me.   I drink a ton of water and have the frequent bathroom visits to match.  I expect this to be a legitimate issue while in a constricting and large gown on the big day.  This would be a huge headache here, even though the bathrooms are on the nice side of the temporary scale, I really don't know how this would work.  Additionally the port a potties are totally visible in the walkway from conservatory to gallery as are recycling bins etc.  This area needs to be better disguised for sure.
- The "theme-parky" feel.  In the classiest, most original and unique way possible, the space still emits a bit of a "Pirates of the Caribbean" Disney-ish theme parky feel.  Still upclass and gorgeous and memorable, but ultimately a bit too themey to me for a wedding.
- Price.  Not cheap enough to compensate for these issues.  Rental fees for site for 150 ppl for 6 hours ~ $8,900 without beginning to explore possible tenting necessities, back up options in case of rain to an outdoor ceremony, etc.

Bottom line: if you have a small group, a gown that's no worries to get around in, are laid back in terms of bathroom options, and have friends who fear stilettos, then the conservatory is quite exceptional in ambiance, flowers, and photo ops so you should check it out.

Although I love love love the Conservatory of Flowers, ultimately it wasn't the best fit for our wedding due to the above deal breakers.  I will continue to enjoy it is a botanical museum as it is exceptional on that front.
author: Kristen T.

description: This lovely and historic Victorian greenhouse is literally a block or so away from my apartment. It always has interesting exhibits and it's cheap! Great for dates. The surrounding garden area is a great place to have a picnic or read a book on a sunny day. I love coming here to just sit and read or just watch people.
author: Helena H.

description: I'm all for student discounts! After my visit here I went to the De Young and it was a perfect excursion for the day. I loved entering the rainforest and looking at the tall banana trees, gradually making my way to the aquatic plants. The beautiful pond was decorated by lilies and plants with fragile stalks that stood with strength and grace. It's definitely full of nature's wonderment and unique botany. If you get a chance to see an exhibit this winter, "One; An earth installation by Stanlee Gatti," is really special.
author: Kim G.

description: Wonderful, wonderful, wonderful! Even if you are not a flower or plant person, this place is a treat. We had a wonderful docent named Paulette (purposefully giving her the shout out she deserves) who was knowledgable, friendly, and engaging. Call ahead and see when the guided tours are. It will make your visit much more meaningful. It's a wonderful out of the way activity for a visit in SF.
author: Chris W.

description: this is the only place where you can experience hot/tropical weather in the city. cool but not as cool as the huntington library in LA county. :)
author: Moko R.

description: This is a great place to relax, warm up an snap some photos. I came here with my parents and grandmother, it was nice for all of us and a good activity when it rains.
author: Katie K.

description:
this is a place you drive by everyday and some people never stepped in here.  some locals here have never stepped in here because they're busy with the city life. so if you need a break next time, try coming here.  admission is $5 per adult.  

many beautiful flowers and plants in here.  i come here to take pictures of the different types of flowers/plants they have here.  my friends love the pictures i took here the first time and i came back the second time since i got a new lens for my dSLR.  if you love flowers, you HAVE to come here! 

oh, and don't forget your camera!
author: Kapo T.

description: The conservatory is expensive, but absolutely beautiful inside.  And they have an area where the butterflies buzz by and sometimes land on you - love that!
author: nicole h.

description: It's fun to go here on a gloomy, chilly day and be whisked to a different climate.  It's at its best when they have the giant lilly pads.
author: Tim G.

description: This place reminded me Lotusland in Santa Barbara but at a much smaller scale. They have a lot of different types of orchids and tropical plants such as cocoa, vanilla, coffee and spices. I wouldn't recommend visiting here on a hot day because it is pretty warm and humid inside (for the orchids) and frequently steam showered! There are about 5 salons where you get to see different plants. Currently, there is a special exhibit on butterflies and a room reserved for them. It is pretty cool to have butterflies flying around you...The outside is also great, you can just lay down and enjoy an afternoon on pretty gardens...
author: Burcin T.

description: Do you like pretty flowers but can't grow them?  Do you like fancy buildings but can't build them yourself?  If you answered yes to the previous questions then the Conservatory of Flowers is the place for you.  Even if you don't go inside the Conservatory the surrounding park area is lovely and the geometrically patterned flowers in front of the Conservatory is the perfect picture to show your jealous midwestern friends.  When I went the had butterflies in one of the rooms which was nice except for kids where fucking up their wings even though THEY WERE NOT SUPPOSED TO TOUCH THEM THE GOD DAMN RUNTS.
author: Christopher H.

description: First of all, get to the conservatory of flowers by February 26th, the last day of the "Modern Art of Orchids" exhibit. The collection of orchids is impressive to say the least, and the exhibit has been designed to highlight the beauty of these diverse flowers. Orchids of all kinds and colors cascade throughout the room, and the room smells so sweet and delicate and unlike all the other smells you are likely to experience in San Francisco. As for the rest of the conservatory, it is a great haven. Still and silent, (aside from all the irritating fake-shutter noises from the digital cameras of aspiring nature photographers) each room offers a different kind of escape. I especially like the aquatic plants room; the water lilies are in bloom right now, and you can see what rice, papyrus and taro plants look like.
author: Kathleen B.

description: A nice small educational place and the money seems to go to a good cause. Of course lots and lots of flowers and plants and a bit humid in there. Their butterfly exhibit is bit on the small side and there aren't that many butterflies (compared to like Six Flags butterfly exhibit and in general). Overall, awesome. =) Adult admission is like $5 and youth/students are $3 and I think 12 and under are like $2?? And 4 under are free???
author: Irene L.

description: One of the greatest places to throw a party in the city.  The building is an incredible piece of work, but don't expect too much from the flowers inside.
author: matthew w.

description: It is too small for a conservatory.  But the guide was very nice, and explain everything to us.  Very nice place for a sit down and enjoy the beauty of the  flowers.
author: Ame k.

description: This place is super cool. I really enjoyed the CHOMP exhibit, because I have a sun dew, and I almost became a Botany major. Anyways the Amazon room is my favorite. I also love all the air orchids.
author: Mike h.

description: I visited here for the first timejust the other day, although I've lived in the city for years. It's a great spot to get away from winter, with a diverse but somehow also slightly limited collection. The building, though....Ahhh colonial architecture...
author: Faisal Q.

description: gorgeous.  i took a little trip in here with some friends to come and see the flutterbyes (aka butterflies).  i got to have a little one perch on my hand and another gracefully fly around my head while i sung my disney favorites.  it was rad!  i loved the lilypads and all of the pink floyd-ish carniverous scrotum-like flowers.  coming here was rejuvenating and relaxing and i felt at one with nature, although nature is still scary to me in many ways.  it was really cool seeing how these plants have developed unique charasteristics to become one with their surroundings for protection and to have a better shot at survival.  deep shit. also, there is some really pretty iron work throughout the place - even on the floors.  i would really like to make the conservatory more of a fixture in my life.
author: Karen K.

description:
excellent
really beautiful and right in the middle of golden gate park. a beautiful stroll through the park, and a really nice green house exhibit.
they've got venus fly traps, pitcher plants, all kinds of orchids, lily pads, ferns, ponds, turtles, fish. it smells amazing, and the hot steamy air feels good.

$7.00 for adults (eh, kind of pricey)
author: King L.

description: truly amazing, "edible expedition" , humidity and real life "venus flytraps" how can you go wrong?
author: Jerry M.

description: We had our wedding ceremony here and loved it!  The conservatory is beautiful, they helped make sure our ceremony went smoothly, and we got a tour of the conservatory afterwards.  The day couldn't have been any better.
author: Emily M.

description: We were very disappointed today to shell out 13 dollars for about 20 minutes of walking around to look at plants? I was expecting flowers based on the name. I'll never go back again. Yes it was pretty, but not worth the money.
author: Tricia B.

description: beautiful and peaceful. perfect way to spend a nice day. took awhile to find it but was happily distracted by the botanical gardens.  once we got there, wandered around amazed for about an hour. then went to happy belly and laid around in the grass outside while basking in the nice weather. good day.
author: michella s.

description: A fabulous gem of a building filled with lots of interesting plants.  The greenhouse itself is a glass building in a very Victorian style - lovingly restored.  Each room has a different humidity and houses a different ecosystem of plant life.  The collection of orchids was especially nice.  The only down side to this place is it seems a bit pricey at $5 per person when you can see everything there is to see in about half an hour.
author: Brandon S.

description: Lovely exhibit of live butterflies that you interact with. Enjoyed the range of different plant species and the large water garden.
author: Marina D.

description: Magical.....My two little girls, age 3 and age 2 could not get enough of the Butterfly Zone.  Beautiful place to explore and go for a stroll.  The had all types of plants and flowers from all parts of the world.  Again, magical and enchanting for the young ones and those who are young at heart. Try and catch the butterflies before the exhibit is over.
author: J F.
